reviews.review: Just walk and look around. Very nice and quiet place located close to Old town, where you can relax, absorb the historical spirit and enjoy your stay in Prague. Just cross over the river Vltava through Charles bridge and you are here. Nice gardens, historical buildings from romanesque, gothic, renaissance, baroque can bring you backward. It is highly recommended to come here and see everything with your own eyes.

Fun to wonder. We happened upon Mala Strana as we wondered the street of Prague. Each corner had very interesting shops and restaurents and we just didn't have enough time to check everything out. Prague is a fun city to just walk and get lost.
Below the castle. This was a bedroom community below the castle. It contains two very impressive cathedrals and a unique palace with its man made grotto.
Wonderful area . What a great area under the Prague Castle away from the crowds. Great local restaurants along with some beautiful churches. Easy access to transportation
The charming heart of Prague. Too many tourists around, but it's always a great experience to walk thru the Charles bridge and reach the charming, enchanting heart of Prague. Beautiful!

Lovely district. Charming part of the old Prague where one can find everything: beautiful buildings and old streets, crowds of tourists and quiet lane as parks, cafes, restaurants, tourist shops, galleries. A number of famous touris objects are there, like St. Nicholas Basilica, Our Lady church with Prazske Jezulatko, etc. Prague Loreto is also in this part, though geographically it belongs more to Hradczany district. Take your time and wander away from the beaten tourist tracks. There are many lovely places to see in Mala Strana, for example Vojanovy garden or Cerninsky palace and garden and narrow, winding lanes around it.

Romantic. Mala Strana has got to be one of the most beautiful places in the world. Away from the hustle and bustle of the magnificent old town, it is filled with the most spectacular pieces of architecture in the many museums, churches, restaurants etc. If you like period hotels this is the place to stay. A short walk over the romantic Charles Bridge at midnight is a mystical experience. Mala Strana has a very Parisian feeling to it with the narrow cobbled streets. Down the steps, and under Charles Bridge you will find the lock bridges and a beautiful working water wheel. Kampa island along by the waterside in the evening is a lovely experience. Mala Strana will stay in your heart forever.
wonderful arcitecture. easy to walk level but cobbled streets, good atmosphere lots of interesting shops and cafes felt safe good transport links to the castle

A more authentic Prague experience with much to see and explore. This is a beautiful if lesser known area of Prague, best known of course for the Castle, although it has a lot more to offer than that. The architecture around the main road Nerudova Street is particularly inspiring, along with of course the beautiful St Nicholas Church. There is however much more to the area than this, with much to see and explore - among other things, Petrin Hill, Kampa Park and the famous John Lennon Wall, each of which are well worth a visit in their own right. This is an area of the city perhaps less frequented by visitors, but is in some ways even more beautiful due to the fact that is that much more quiet, giving an altogether more authentic experience of Prague, yet still within walking distance of the main sites across the river. If I were to visit Prague again, I would probably choose to stay in this area for all of the reasons stated above. It also happens to be home to some of the cities finest vegetarian restaurants, which is even more of a reason to visit.
Beautiful area of Prague within walking distance from all sites. Spent 4 days living in this area of Prague which is walking distance all key historic and city sites.

May be even more beautiful than the Old Town. We were staying at the Golden Star, in Hradcany which is adjacent to Mala Strana, at the end of Nerudova street, so of course for us it was easy, it was right at our doorstep, we were right in the heart of the quarter.The architecture is really different from the Old Town ... 17th and 18th Century, not at all less beautiful and really worth some walks.Some of my friends, way savvier than me in matter of pubs, beers, restaurants and good food are convinced that you eat better and drink better in Mala Strana than in the rest of Prague ...There are there very famous names so without putting in competition the 2 sides of the Vlatva River let's say that if you don't visit, stay or eat at Mala Strana, you have tasted only half of Prague.I believe anyway that you'll have no choice and be there because ... it is on the other side of the Charles Bridge, on your way to the Prague Castle and St Vitus Cathedral ...So .. Give it some more time and visit the Wallenstein Gardens, may be Strahov Monastery and Library, the lovely narrow streets all around... they all are so close .. .and even Petrin Hill...Give it a full day at least and you'll make the most of Prague ...You can take a look at some of the pictures I have attached to see for yourself if the place is worth your time .. I believe it is ...And if you have more time, wait till dusk and you won't regret it: the view on Prague at Night from the Prague Castle or Petrin Hill is superb and even unforgettable.

Beautiful castle. The castle is beautiful, with many smaller section inside that offers different activities (and entrance fee). This castle is surely a must visit place in Prague hence no wonder its always crowded. Accessible by tram, I would recommend any visitor to take a tram through scenic view of Prague going up to the hill before reaching the castle, then on your way back you can take either metro (from Malostranska) or another tram from the nearest stop. Here's what you should do around this castle:- Take a picture with the royal guard at the entrance (or, the soldier usually stands nearby).- Its difficult to get great picture of the cathedral because it has narrow space between the building. Try going to the corner of the front building to get better view, or go to the back of the the cathedral- Have a light brunch/lunch at Rozmbersky (palace Cafe) with full scene of Prague. - Another scenic photo stop of Prague city can be taken from small cafe at the exit way (before the stair down from Mala Strana).

Would stay here the next time. Forget the crowds in Old Town, and Hradcany, this is the place to meander. Wear walking shoes..tons of hills. Less crowds, secret gardens, plenty of places to eat and shop. Tons of cave restaurants. We kept walking over the Charles and heading back to here.

Gorgeous Mala Strana or Small Town. Mala Strana is just across the river from old town, around the foot hills of Prague Castle. There are interesting smaller shops, churches, traditional Czech Pubs, bars and restaurants, but all in a more quieter area away from the buzzing tourist area in Old Town. It just seemed more laid back and relaxed. This is a part that reminds me what Old Prague must have been like..... Lots of cobble stone streets and lanes, wear comfy shoes. Keep watching out for some of the beautiful big old gates, they sure are worth to take pictures of!

Must-go part of Prague. Just walk around - there are tons of historical places to see and even some contemporary like John Lennon Wall. Several very good taverns with tank beer, custom tours of the City on classic cars etc. - something for everyone!
Loved Mala strana. Wonderful walks everywhere. Great part of Praha. Be careful of drivers and trams. Cobblestone streets so wear comfy shoes.

Lovely part of Prague.....if you want to wrestle through the crowds!. This is a beautiful part of Prague; but the crowds between the Old Town Sq and Mala Strana (on a September evening) were horrendous. I guess if you are an early riser (not us!) then it might be worth trying to go there really early in the morning. I was there a few years ago at Christmas and it was much less crowded to be fair. There are good Czech restaurants there and loads of little quirky gift shops, as well as lovely, well preserved architecture.

On your way to or from the Castle. I would recommend visiting it when descending from the Castle visit (going to Castle is better via the Manesuv bridge - see why in my Castle review).From the Castle take the Nerudova street downhill. This is a great medieval street with lots of authentic shops, cafes,... After a pleasant 30 min walk you'll reach the Malostranske Sq.The highlight of it is the St.Nicholas Cathedral (see that review).

Very beutiful place. Be prepared to walk if you want a spectacular view, it is a very pretty place. Cobblestone streets, so be prepared for rocky paths, not flat and have the right shoes for sure!!!!!!

Mala strana. it is a district near Prague old town (cross the river), you can easily by tram # 9 or 22 (tram trip time about 14 minutes), then you can use the Cable car to go up to the Mala Strana (~3 Euros) or if you like the segway so you can rent (private or in group)-you can find many of them for private "guided tour" for 40 EUROS/HOUR.it is a beautiful green (you will like it so much if you like greenery
Charming. An appealing neighborhood, not like Greenwich Village in New York. Not much effort is needed to find some interesting restaurants serving local cuisine and Moravian wines.
Very Charming! . In the Middle Ages, it was a dominant center of the ethnic German. Actually a beautiful place to visit and enjoy the churches like St Nicholas which is a materpiece!
Very charming with fewer crowds. Good location with less crowds. Still charming with plenty to explore and great restaurants, and easy access to Old town
Absolutely Beautiful. Must visit for anyone coming to Prague. Just walk around the Mala Strana and soak in the beauty. Have a beer in any of the quaint cafe's and restaurants

Great area. Mala Strana is my favourite district to stay when in Prague. It is nice and quiet and has many cosy and good restaurants eg. Pastar, Cafe Savoy. Kampa Park is also in the area. Nice place to have a picnic (You can get a picnic basket filled with goodies at Pastar).

Great neighborhood for a great walk!!. It is very near the Prague castle so after you visit the castle you can walk the streets of Mala strana where it is easy to find a place to have excellent food and the greatest beer!

Best area of prague. Have now been to Prague 4 times. Have stayed in mala strana for last 2. Less frantic than the old town, and more beautiful. Wonderful romantic place to wander, see great sites and get a good reasonably priced meal
Beautiful district . An amazing district to walk through and look around and the souvenir shops, restaurants, and architecture. Highly recommended.

A little more expensive but has culture, restaurants, and is safe. I found the pubs and small stores in this area to be more expensive. Many of the embassies are here and there is a police presence here. Prague is a very safe city, as big cities go. Transportation connections abound here but it is also noisy because of the street cars and buses and car traffic. All of Prague seems to be a city that doesn't sleep.

Excellent area to take a stroll.. We loved this area to take a stroll in. Beautiful architecture, beautiful flowers and beautiful views all around. Make sure you take a walk through this neighborhood while you visit Prague.
Loved it !!. Our joy is to "WANDER" and that is PRECISELY what one does in MALA STRANA !! Just walk and stop and have a beer or whatever. UNBEATABLE !!!

Visit late afternoon. Across the river from the main square this area is for me the heart of Prague. Quirky little streets with wonderful buildings and cobbled roads make it a joy to wander and enjoy a more peaceful side of Prague.As I said in my title try and come later in the day when the walking tours have finished and it is quieter. Lots of small restaurants with hidden courtyards to enjoy a meal or just a drink. Take a selfie at the John Lennon wall whilst listening to the locals singing his songs......
Just off the Charles Bridge. Great area with old buildings be sure to see the markings on the buildings which identified who lived there. Also see the Lennon wall, great shops and places to eat.
Old world. Mala Strana is a long walk but worth the effort See the red tiled homes and the little Italy canal as well as lovely statues
Nice day in a historic burg near castle. Some interesting sites, including churches and Lennon wall. Some really pretty architecture and nice views of the Vtalva.

Amazing.. In my opinion this is the most beautiful place in Prague. It is worth there to visit not only on the most popular monuments but as well to go into many small streets. You can also find there some local and not expensive pubs or restaurant.
Lovely district. This is a lovely place to have a walk and gaze at the architecture, especially when the crowds of tourists dissipate a little around meal time.
Plenty of souvenir shops. This area packed with shops selling souvenirs, restaurants can be found there, and a number of beautiful photo points.
Magical place. In this district of Prague you really feel the magical historical atmosphere. If you visit Prague, go here!

Less touristy. We stayed in the Mala Strana area. It was very quaint and not as crowded and touristy as the Old Town area. It definitely had more of a local feel to it. Highly recommend wandering around.

Great visit. Makes Strana is located at the other side of the river were the old square is located. Just crossing the Carlos bridge you enter into Mala Strana were the Castle, the baby Jesus of Prague and others are located. Take into consideration that walking to the Castle requires good health since it is a steep hill (should you choose that route) or hundreds of steps (should you choose the other).
Nice area. Wonderful little streets where you can walk around the whole day. Beautiful architecture with shops and restaurants

Atmospheric . I walked in this area almost every day during my stay in Prague. Once I walked past the touristy shop areas, this could be very atmospheric. I liked to wonder off the back alleys especially closer to dusk. I could see the local lives unfold during the early evening hours. This area was used in several scenes of the movie "Amadeus". Retracing the route was interesting.

One thing spoils it. The old town is fantastic shops and restaurants to suit everyone. The old square is the place to sit and watch the world go by and surprisingly the bars not unreasonable on drinks prices.The down side is the endless touts trying to hire and sell Segway tours I can only compare it to the timeshare touts in Tenerife. They spoil the whole ambience of the town square.
Lovely quiet walk down here.. Lovely quiet street just down from our apartment leading to a lovely square. Such amazing little streets around the town.

Beautiful buildings and atmosphere . Loved walking through this area in Prague, really beautiful architecture. Made a nice change from the overcrowded Old Town and its tourist packed streets. Some lovely little cafes and restaurants.

Go ahead, take all day.. Very easy just to wander round and gaze at the buildings... and the people. It feels both old, yet somehow contemporary. It also feels much safer than many cities I've visited. As usual, cafes on the main squares are more expensive than those down side streets.

loved staying in this area--don't miss the park. If you like to run/walk while on vacation, this neighborhood is perfect. the challenging hills and nice paths are great for a run anytime. Also feels very safe. You can walk anywhere, but also take a tram anywhere--easy system to use--just like any metro. A ton of bars/restaurants/cafes to choose from.
Beautiful. Buy yourself a Trdelník when you get off the tram at Malastranska and spend your afternoon just strolling the streets here.

Excellent choice for a quiet nights sleep.. staying across the river allowed a short walk to the square but the ability to retreat from the noise and crowds when we wanted. We stayed at the Appia an uphill walk but close ot plenty of action and easy walk to the castle and monastery . Would stay on this lesser quarter again in a heartbeat.

Great place to stay.. My wife and I rented a very nice apartment in the Mala Strana in September. After several days, I believe we enjoy this side of the river over the old district. Lots of good restaurants and wine bars. Larry & Kelly, Georgetown, TX

Nerudova street a must. Nerudova street is a lovely cobblestone street with quaint shop and hotel fronts in the Mala Strana area. Take time to look up when walking along this street to see the building symbols for example 3 fiddles.

Awesome area to stay in!. We did the the Airbnb thing and tried to live like a local. Terrific area close to transport and all key sites. Can walk to everything! We arrived in Prague from Berlin by train and arrived at the central station. Took us a little time to work out which trams etc. we had to catch but once we did was easy to get luggage on and arrive in Mala Strana and walk to our apartment.Plenty of great cafes, bars , restaurants etc and depending on your budget they cover from high end to low end. Lot of tourists but so what.....reason there are lots of tourists is its because it's a cool spot and close to sights....recommend this area

Great Neighborhood to Stay In. We choose to stay in this part of town to get away from the summer crowds. So glad we did! The area is a lot quieter than the touristy parts of Prague. It was nice to take a short walk over the bridge into the crowds and famous sights, but to return to a more peaceful area was priceless. It was a nice retreat to not have to be kept up all night by the the tourists that flood the city, especially in the summer. The castle is on this side of town, which was just a short walk...although up hill.

Lovely walk. Its a old city with many attractions around this place.This place will be exciting to walk around for Non Europeans. The walk can be very rewarding, it feels like walking in time travel.There are many attractions around this place like : Prague Castle, Charles Bridge, Petrin Hill, old churches. Dont miss to hit few restaurants here.My fav are : Amorino for some gelato ice cream during summerDuring winter grab some hot wine or hot chocolate around Amorino.
Old part of the City. Mala Strana is the name of the area in the old part of the city (Near to the Castle and church)The architecture around the place is really beautiful

This Lovely Area Has a Lot to Offer. Mala Strana is the area on the west side of Charles Bridge and it offers a very nice walk to and from the Castle District. While it has about the same building architecture as the Old Town (Staro Mesto), it is much less crowded. The reason is probably the lesser amount of What-To-Do's compared to the Old Town, and the rather boring south area of Mala Strana.The main historic attractions worth visit are the St. Nicolas Church in Mala Strana and Wallenstein Palace with its Beautiful Garden. Kampa Island and its park are a nice place for a lovely stroll.But the best places are actually the "modern" ones: The Lennon Wall, David Cerny's statues of the Crawling Babies and the Pissing Fountain (and a few other modern monuments scattered throughout Mala Strana), The Kafka Museum, and the hidden gem of Mala Strana - the Karel Zeman Museum of Film Special Effects.If you are going to the Prague Castle from the Old Town (or back) by foot, I would suggest going through either Nerudova st. or Thunovska st. Both offer a nice walk along a line of colourful houses.I'm not sure if Petrin Hill considered a part of Mala Strana, but to me it seems like it does not have a lot to offer. Besides being a hill it also rather remote by foot, which means you likely be very tired afterwards. The Petrin Tower, Mirror Maze, the Hunger Wall and the Stefanik Observatory are the only attractions that seem to be worth a visit.
quieter but nice. Easy to walk around in, can get crowded but nothing like the main part of the city. Bring comfortable shoes. lots of little places to eat and drink and shop. Really nice area
Must Do!. A lovely area to walk around and soak up the atmosphere. Lovely buildings and tourist shops but nice stuff not tat!

Just on the other side of the Charles Bridge. Lively area that has a slight less busy feel than the Old Town side of the Charles Bridge. There are some good restaurants and shops to walk through. Just keep walking and you'll get to see another unique area of Prague.

Lovely area . Mala Strana is a lovely place in Prague. It has lots of little streets to wander around in and plenty of cafés and restaurants. It is extremely busy but worth a look as it is very picturesque.

Lovely place to wander. Clustered around the foothills of Prague Castle Malá Strana is less bustling than the Old Town once you get away from Charles Bridge & a little gem of an area. Picturesque with narrow side streets to explore, beautiful buildings, Baroque churches and many a place to refresh yourself. Just a lovely place to wander.

Charming district with hidden gems. Total must see when visiting Prague. You can take a stroll and dive in discovering the hidden places and history. There is John Lennon wall , the street art wall inspired by his work or Beatles museum along the all historic buildings. Highly recommended

Nice places and good view. Nice place to go for a walk and meet locals and tourists. You can find a place to chill like a park or coffee place but might as well just walk around and discover pretty/interesting buildings.
Beautiful place. I don't have much to say. It should be definitely on your places-to-visit-list if you are in Prague.

Mala Strana - Part of my life.... Mala Strana is my favorite place in Prague. I am overjoyed to come back for a visit and sad to leave Mala Strana behind. The narrow cobblestone streets, the fancy restaurants by the river with amazing views, the simple and cosy cafes in every nook and cranny. The small ice-cream shops. A gorgeous tiny flower shop. The mosaic sidewalks that add such richness, with designs made from small two inch granite cubes set in sand centuries ago. Clever, how the design often matches the site. A repeat pattern - row of crosses in front of a church, or a wine glass pattern in front of a restaurant. A small but well chosen detail that adds to the beauty to be enjoyed for years to come.My favorite churches on Mala Strana vary in size and prominence. The baroque St. Nicholas church is truly grand, one of the most beautiful and most visited in Prague. The church of Our Lady Victorious - Infant Jesus of Prague and the church of Our Lady beneath the Chain are my all time favorites.I love the well kept parks , Kampa, Vojanovy sady, swans on the river and peacocks strutting their stuff. The Funicular that starts out on Ujezd and takes you up to Nebozizek and top of the Petrin hill. Just steps off the beaten path are the hidden renaissance and baroque gardens. Vrtbovska, Wallenstein and Ledebour gardens are beautifully kept and in bloom most of the year. I love the aluring small crooked streets and the well known Nerudova street with the attractive house signs adorning the centuries old houses. The contrast of the large Palaces. Mostecka street with the beautiful pastel color houses, leading to the Charles bridge.The small Malostranske and Maltezske Square, the first one busy, the other almost serene.The Certovka stream with the ancient at times rickety wheel and the ever changing look of the Vltava river. And the Legii Bridge to watch fireworks from on New Years day.The centuries old monasteries converted into luxurious boutique hotels, with old pubs right next to them. Lenon wall...The beautiful old horse-chestnut trees...The screeching trams that always have the right of way... All that and more is Mala Strana - my favorite part of the world...

Different world. definitely one of most impressive highlights in Prague. Through the ages it has been very rich quater on the left bank of Vltava river, full of historical castles and noble houses of Czech and Austrian aristocracy. Czech parliament still sits here. Visit Kampa (on the river bank), walk to the castle through the old quater, it worth it!

Walking Tour - off the path of many tourists and tour groups. The views are stunning, every direction opens a hidden treasure, easy access to food and shopping. Lenin Wall, Kampa Island, historic churches, a great day activity.
Worth getting lost in this district. Wonderful area, building and architecture - slightly off the beaten track. Hidden shops and cafes. Inviting and quiet cobbled streets. Don't miss it!

Mala Strana. Great place to catch a tram 22 either back to New town across Vltava River or in the other direction, up the hill to the Prague castle.You may also walk up Nerudova Street from here to the top and the castle.

Great place to walk on a nice day. The Charles Bridge isn't the only bridge in Prague, and we crossed the river on the Most Legii and strolled through the area, passing interesting restaurants, parks, sculpture, boats, and more. There were plenty of tourist shops too, some significantly different from those nearer the Charles Bridge. For much of the area, crowds were smaller than those near the Charles. We eventually took the Charles back home, but not before we took a lot of pictures, ate some ice cream, and had a nice time.
Lesser Town is worth a stroll. This area was pleasant to walk in lined with shops and cafes. It is easy to visit when taking in the Charles Bridge and Kampa Park.

A world treasure that is a joy to stroll around. There's plenty to see in Prague, but arguably the two most fun things to do in this jewel of a city is strolling and dining. And you can do both in the Mala Strana. Just walking around, looking up occasionally to see unique art work on the outside of shops and buildings, stopping at squares to see outdoor monuments, window shopping at some very unique stores and just plain people watching will bring a smile to your face. Lots to photograph, and the higher up you go, the views back to the river and the Old Town get better and better.
Best place to stay. Mala Strana (lesser quarter) is the most laid back and lovely part of the city, I think. Easy walking, shopping, sightseeing, and you're never far from the river.

Lots of good bars and restaurants. Translating the Lesser Town this certainly is a good visit and in some ways nicer than the Old Town on the other side of the river. Lots of little streets to stroll down with reasonable places to eat and drink.

I loved Prague and I want to go back soon!. The old city of Prague is so very beautiful and filled with history and culture and good vibes. Was there for a long weekend (Let it Roll festival) in August and enjoyed every minute of it. There's so much I haven't had time to see and do and eat, but I will go there soon enough. Maybe in autumn or spring this time.
-. This is wonderful place to spend at least one whole day in Prague - I strongly recommend everyone to see it.
Baroque district. Lovely district in the city of Prague, beautiful baroque quarter just at the foor of Prague Castle. Wonderful, old architecture that takes you back in time.
Lovely. Great area in the new Town. Plenty of shops and bars and places to eat. The architecture is beautiful. Quiet at night and safe area to walk.

Beautiful, Not as Crowded. Mala Strana - or Lesser Town - is a short walk across Charles Bridge and offers the same beautiful atmosphere as Old Town but without the crowds. It has plenty of its own attractions, like Lesser Town Square, Prague Castle, The Lennon Wall, and Petrin Park. There are still plenty of shops, restaurants, and pubs in the area, as well as public transport. It's approximately a ten minute walk to Charles Bridge, and from there it's only a moments walk to Old Town. A wonderful part of the city.

The most beautiful area of the city.. Don't just walk through here to get from the Bridge to the Castle, but spend at least a good two days here exploring. One of the most remarkable places I've ever been to.
Great Area. One of the most crouded area in Prague. Famous area with nice buildings, shops, and realy nice for walking taking some photos! Many restaurants cafe and pubs are around to spend your day!
Get lost in Mala Strana. Take a step into the past, walk around the cobble streets of Mala Strana, explore the cave restaurants and many shops.

Vibrant.... After the old town, Mala Strana or the lesser town is the place that will hold your attention. Just adjacent to the Old town, the boundaries of both the neighbourhoods blur at some point. But it retains the vibrancy of its famed neighbour.That aside, keep you walking shoes handy. Best enjoyed on foot. The narrow cobbled streets remind you of an era that is never going to come back. But yes, you can relive it here for a while.
Beautiful. Mala Strana is a beautiful area of Prague. The architecture and beauty is a nice respite from the busier sections of town

Best area in the city!. We stayed in Mala strana at the Appia Hotel Residences based on reviews. I can't imagine staying in any other neighborhood. The best meal we had in our 15 day trip through Paris, Lucerne, Heidelberg and Munich was here, Santini Garden.

If you visit the castle, make sure to visit the New Town. Mala Strana (New Town) is similar in charm of the Old Town. Just cross over Charles Bridge in the direction of the castle and you are in Mala Strana. There is a town market, the Church of Infant Jesus of Prague, interesting cafes and souvenir shops. If you are in the area, why not see another interesting section of this wonderful town.
Peaceful. After a couple of days of the hustle and bustle in old town, it was refreshing to cross over the river to Mala Strana for a day. It's beautiful, quiet, peaceful and CHEAP.

Nice little neighborhood worth visiting!. Found the Mala strana area to be quiet and equally beautiful as the Old town area. Though less crowded, the neighborhood is charming in its own way. The best part is that the Mala strana and Old town are basically connected by the Charles Bridge! So you easily walk around and explore the beauty of Prague. The narrow alleys, buzzing restaurants and the sight of red colored trams running through this neighborhood makes you wonder if you are in some fairyland. Do check this out!

A visit to the residential area of the old Czech nobility.. Malá Strana (Small town in a free translation) was the residential area of the old Czech nobility. It is one of the most historic places of Prague. So be sure to walk there without hurry, guarantee its beautiful gardens and beautiful Baroque facades will make the visit. In fact, the whole neighborhood is a great way to observe the Baroque style of the Czech Republic.

A Beautiful Area Below Prague Castle. Very charming area below Prague Castle--not as busy as the Old Town of Prague--lots of shops. I love the many great views especially as you get to vantage points.

Equal in charm to Old Town Square.. Mala Strana (New Town) is similar in charm to Old Town. Cross over Charles Bridge in the direction of the castle and you are in Mala Strana. This is home to various attractions like the Franz Kafka museum, new town market, the churh of Infant Jesus of Prague, countless cafes and souvenir shops, a very very interestingly laid out bookshop near the Kafka museum, Petrin Hill, the castle complex which includes St. Vitus' Cathedral, the monastery where the monks brew their famous beer, etc.We even saw a wedding photoshoot taking place right in the middle of a busy junction in this part of town! Truly charming.
Lovely Area. Stayed here on our visit. Within walking distance for all the sites. Lots of lovely eating places. Noticed it was half the price of what you pay when in the Old town and Wenclass Square.

A wonderful district of Prague. . MALA STRANA ( lesser Quarter of Prague) is a wonderful district of Prague. The architecture here is awesome and a visit to St Thomas Church and St Nicholas Church are a must.The area is vibrant with some of Pragues best pub's including U Hrocha ( at the hippocampus) and U Maleho Glena to name but some of the outstanding pubs and bars here. If you jump tram number 12.20.22.57 or 91 to stop Malostranske Namesti these bring you into the heart of this district.If you enjoy taking your photos your in the correct area as it is a most photogenic district of this most gorgeous of cities. Well worth a visit on any holiday to Prague.
More relaxing. We preferred this part of Prague's center when we were walking around without special aims. It's not that much crowded like the old town. More relaxing.

Best Neighbourhood To Stay In. We stayed in the Mala Strana part of the city and managed to discover and explore much of this not so busy part of the city. There really is so much to see and do and every corner you turn something different to catch your eye.It really is the less touristy side but nevertheless it is just as beautiful with parks and gardens everywhere! So glad we stayed that side as we could enjoy the walk to and from the hotel every day!
Special place!. Beautiful district. You can stay and admire every house and Street. You can take hundread of pictures. Every building is special.

explore. don't just stick to the same as the sheep, explore. its hardly any distance from the square and just worth a look, its pretty dull just to do what everyone else is doing, do it if you have to then explore, for all of half a mile walk you could find amazing places that for some reason tourists don't go to. maybe because its over 400 yards walk.

the lesser town square. although staying in lesser town, we happened upon the lesser town square by accident when making a wrong turn in our descent from petrin hill. a beautiful part of the city, with a tram stop in the centre, it is a lovely place to have a coffee and admire the scenery and charles bridge is right opposite for easy access back into the old town.

Dreaming place to visit and to stay. This historical borough in central Prague starts to live as a german nucleus in Medieval times. It keeps many buildings and an incredible atmosphere from the past, with renaissance, baroque and romantic issues. You should walk all around and if you like, experiment to stay one or two nights in one of the multiple hotels inside the quarters. Many restaurants to choice too.
Nice neigborhood. Crossing any bridge next to Charles Bridge is Mala strana. The neighborhood is beautiful and full of good restaurants.
QUAINT AREA. Nice cobblestoned area to stroll around and visit the quaint shops, cafes/restaurants and gardens. Close to everything but not as crowded as Old Town Square area.

Not just about Charles bridge. You cant miss this spot when crossing river. Mala strana has unique atmosphere with lot of shops and hidden streets with great restaurants. Its like a maze but you will always get out :)

Great area for a stroll.. Mala Strana is the area at the other side of Charles Bridge to the old town. It has loads of attractive old streets lined with cafes, small shops and houses. Don't rush, take your time and enjoy the atmosphere.

Relaxed & Charming Neighbourhood. Mala Strana is a lovely and very charming neighbourhood within the ccity of Prague. Located on the opposite side of the Vltava river to the Old Town it gives a very relaxed area to have a slow afternoon in the sun as opposed to the busy streets of the Old Town. We stayed in a hotel in Mala Strana and couldn't have booked a better place to stay. It is short enough a walk to walk into the Old Town, upto the castle but is far enough to avoid any evening noise from the popular tourist areas.

lovely and layed back. I stayed here for 4 days. I immediately love it when i arrive. it's cosy and intimate. like the town that you have been growing up in. It feels so close and easy emotional connected. full of restaurant and boutique store with reasonable price and friendly staff. and it's close to almost all attractions. i would recommend you have a look or even stay here.

Great open space. Lovely place to walk down, shop and spend day relaxing and enjoy a bite from many places on the way. Definitely a good place to take a break from making the "tourism run" aka trying to see alot in a little time :)

Charming Town . Lesser Town is simply charming little town in between the busy Charles Bridge and Prague Castle. I wandered this place couple of times and love its quiet atmosphere especially on the evening in this summer. There are mainly embassies, restaurants and residences which makes this area not too overcrowded by tourists.

Old Town’s little sister. Like Old Town, Malá Strana (Lesser Town or Little Quarter) is a section of Prague adjacent to Vltava River. Charles Bridge connects the two, and towers at either end of the bridge are landmarks orienting visitors—all TripAdvisor designated attractions. Malá Strana houses oodles of other attractions: Kafka Museum, Lennon Wall, Piss Sculpture, Saint Vitus Cathedral, Charles Bridge, Saint Nicholas Church, and dozens of restaurants/pubs. An entire day can be spent here without seeing all that is offered. For budge conscious visitors, everything is offered at no cost, excluding entering some specific attractions—such as Kafka Museum or Saint Nicholas. Viewing the magnificent Baroque, Gothic, and Art Nouveau architecture, however, is an experience and photo op not to be missed.

Our favourite district in Prague. Plenty to do and see and some good restaurants and bars that are more affordable than across the river in the Old Town. A very nice laid back atmosphere and easy to access by walking or tram. The area is basically one huge geeen space on the hill, with rose gardens, newly planted apple orchards etc.

Heart of action in lesser town. This is the Centre of all activities at the lesser town. We stayed here and could easily walk to all attractions from here.
The tram stop right outside the hotel was super convienent

Beautiful area between the Castle and Charles Bridge. This area like most of old town and Castle area is filled with incredible buildings with stunning architecture and designs. There are lots of nice shops, gardens and restaurants as well as historical sites. Walking around here is a must! The area is quite safe and easy to see in a few hours. You can walk from here to the tower or old town, either way will have plenty to see and do. The only down side if you are staying here is that taxis might not enter certain areas, so you might want to to think about it if you are not able to walk.

Pretty end of town and less full of tourists. A less busy part of town that is full of hidden surprises and plenty of shops, cafes and restaurants. The John Lennon wall and narrowest street in Prague are some must see places here.

Stunning architecture. A great place to visit, very clean and a must if in Prague. Can be a little over crowded but again it is a tourist trap. Each little ally takes you on a different journey, do try some of the off the track restaurants, cheaper and the quality is as good as the main square.

Disney's Inspiration?. The best thing that can happen to you is to get lost here like we did. We found ourselves following signs for the WC that led us past embassies, thru neighborhoods and finally into a park, all the while discovering unique architecture, sculptures, museums and gardens.A perfect example of not taking the journey but letting the journey take you.
The other side. This part of Prague on the other side of the river liked me very much. It is very elegant and full of beautiful restaurants and pubs where you can eat or just have a drink.

Little Prague. Little Prague has a lot to offer from fine hotels, restaurants, culture, history, cafés, the castle and palace and so on.Everyone who visits Prague must have been there at least once or twice or even more.
Stay in this part of the city. We stayed in this area, as opposed to Old Town or Wenceslas Square area. Very quaint and much more quiet; less tourists in the evening.

Enjoy. The whole of Praque is just a sight to behold with the buildings being intricately carved or painted with frescoes. The best thing is to just get lost wandering the streets and stopping at a small cafe or bar for refreshments, even though they are a lot more expensive in the main tourist areas than bein just a few streets away!

More Relaxed and More Bohemian. Little Side (Mala Strana) is below the Prague Castle. For some reason it feels like there are less people in this area. It's quite quaint and there is a lot to see. I believe it dates back to 1257 and was mainly filled with Germans in the beginning of its existence. It has had some tough history having been burned down and ravaged by a fire. Today it is mostly in the style of Renaissance. Look for the Wallenstein Palace built in 1623, churches, Embassy's, the Petrin Lookout Tower, the Lennon Wall, several very sweet restaurants, great hotels... It's fun to stroll around.

Beautiful old buildings on a hilly street. The Mala Strana area is cobblestoned streets and fairly hilly going up toward the Prague Castle wall from the Charles Bridge. The shops, bars, restaurants, and hotels etc. are very old and full of character.
It is

Not as crowded. Walk across the Charles Bridge to Mala Strana and you immediately feel a different vibe. It is not as crowded and has a more relaxed feel to it. You can walk around the tiny streets without being jostled by crowds of people and there are some lovely cafes and restaurants overlooking the river.

Much like the old town across the river. The neighborhood of Mala Strana is very similar to the old town across the river. A lot of baroque and classicist townhouses and palaces. Herds of tourists. Do not listen to anyone who tells you its peaceful or relaxing. Pushy tourists abound, rivers of people pretty much everywhere. Its a pretty little district but other than the St. Nicolas church, the square it stands in and the royal castle, there is nothing to see, just bunch of streets that start visually blending together after a while. Rating would have been 4 ten years ago, but with the huge influx of tourists it is kind of impossible now to visit Prague and actually enjoy it.

One of the best parts of Prague. Get away from the throngs of tourists by heading to Mala Strana and enjoying the peace and beauty of this part of Prague. The best place to head if you don't like crowds!
Nice area. An area of the Old town with a bit less tourists than on the other side of the river. Many nice restaurants.
Nice area.. Nice area withing walking distance of the main tourist areas. Lots of good restaurants, kampa island and easy access to Petrin Hill and the Castle district.
Take a leisurely stroll. A beautiful area of Prague which is close to the action, but not touristy. Wonderful architecture and just across the Charles Bridge and below the castle.
A different taste of Prague. It is lovely to walk around the streets of Mala Strana. It is definitely less touristic and more quit part of the city
small beautifull place. Lesser town. small beautiful place where you can find a lot of pubs and restaurants. we had a lunch in Beseda restaurants. was not bad
Nice area. Nice area to stroll around in with lesser tourists and beautiful architecture. Recommend Cafe Savoy or Cafe Lounge for a lunch.

Wonderous Walk Across the Charles Bridge. We did this walk a few times and it is beautiful. Just below Prague Castle on the west side of the river. I like to look down on it from the castle. The red roofs make spectacular viewing and photos. Baroque architecture is everywhere in this quarter. Lots of great sights, shops and restaurants. Loved it!
Quite right area. This area of Prague didnt have as many tourists milling about it is very pretty tiny cobbled streets and lovely old buildings

Stroll through Mala Strana (Lesser Town) in Prague. During our visit to Prague, we had the opportunity to spend a lot of time in Mala Strana. We went on a walking tour to the Wallenstein Palace, the Schoenborn Palace (US Embassy), the Chuch of Our Lady Victorious, Malostranske Namesti Square and the John Lennon Wall. The streets are mostly cobblestone and are narrow and steep through most of the area so bring your walking shoes. After our tour we had dinner at one of the local restaurants before walking back across the Charles Bridge to our hotel.

Don't miss this beautiful area. We first encountered this beautiful area of town while rumbling through on board our #22 tram on the way from Old Town Prague to the Castle area. We noted how picturesque it looked, and while walking back down the hill later on, had dinner on one of the side streets and explored further. To me, it's just as pretty as Old Town but not as crowded. Don't miss it.

Quieter than the Old Town but just as pretty. I got the chance to visit Malá Strana whilst visiting Prague & I really enjoyed my time there. The streets were quiet; area was very clean; beautiful buildings & architecture. There were even Segways being used to get around which looked like a lot of fun & considering the area is so much quieter than the Old Town you would almost have the pavements to yourself.Malá Strana also covers as far as the base of Petrin Hill where the Memorial to the Victims of Communism is situated. This really is a must-see. A few minutes walk from the memorial is the Funicular that can take you to the top of the hill where you will find Petrin Tower.Malá Strana is a lovely area & is worth checking out whilst in Prague.

Quiet area to stay in. We stayed here for three nights enjoying getting away from the crowds of old town area at night. There are several smaller hotels and many good restaurants. Of course it is just below the castle with views ar night and ease of access in day time.
Picturesque Area. Across the Charles Bridge, on your way to Prague Castle area. Picturesque area of Prague with lots of quaint side streets.
Best part of the city. I have been to all parts of prague and I think this is the best part of prague to visit and also to stay.

A lovely part of Prague. We stayed at Hotel Golden Wheel on Nerudova Street. The hotel was brilliant, the street is delightful (busy, but not like Old Town Sq.). It is central located in the Mala Strana, close to Charles Bridge and the Castle. Mala Strana is a little less touristy than Old Town and just as beautiful on a smaller scale. It is nicer in my opinion because it is hilly with lovely streets, stairways and alley meandering throughout.

Best Location to Stay!. This area has restaurants, shopping and hotels. It is historically old and charming to meander the cobblestone streets through neighborhoods and only a short walk to Charles Bridge....where the crowded part begins.
Beautiful area of town. While initially focussed on the other side of the river, we found ourselves returning to Mala Strana time and time again. So much to see and such a nice atmosphere.
Other side. Walk over Charles bridge to this part of the city, with great baroque church and lots of museums, cafes and restaurants.

Stepping Through History. This was one of the unexpected highlights of my Prague trip. I found myself drawn to the hall-like winding paths. Shops and cafes of homemade, hand carved, local artisan creations delight the senses and tickle the imagination.From an absinthe shop to hand carved wooden marionettes (where I purchased one of my most treasured pieces) I meandered for hours, never bored and never feeling like I was lost.If local artistry, history, architecture, and wonder are your penchants then do not skip Mala Strana
Fun place to wander. This "lesser city" is a great place to wander around - lots of great buildings to admire, museums, cafes and restaurants.

The Montmartre, Soho and Greenwich Village of Prague. If you are the type of person who dislikes mass-produced consumer driven culture, then Mala Strana is the place. Imagine quaint 16-17th century Baroque town houses, cathedrals and palaces, nested on the bank of the river below the gothic Prague Castle. Now add cute shops, art galleries, cafes, restaurants and pubs, night boat rides on the Certovka Canal. Like the idea? :)

Quaint old buildings and narrow streets to meander around. Its a joy to walk across Charles Bridge with its artists and others selling their works to reach the Mala Strana area of Prague. Quaint streets with picturesque buildings and an assortment of shops and bars are scattered throughout.It is a nice way to make the walk up to the Castle area via fairly steep streets, however the tram stops near by to take the strain off from walking to the top

THE place to stay. It is quieter on this side of the bridge, the pace is slower and the food and drink just as good. We stayed right by the bridge but felt removed from the crowds once we came down the stairs. Lovely twisty narrow streets, gardens, shops and architectural details. Be sure to visit the Church of Our Lady Victorious and the museum tucked in the corner. The history is fascinating.

Quieter part of Prague. This side of Prague is a breath of fresh air after fighting the crowds in the Old Quarter. The streets are hilly and the view gets better as you climb to the top near the castle. There are little restaurants hidden down below steps and near the river. We went to a club called the Mala Strana Beseda and they had great music upstairs. There is a good wine bar and the restaurants are very reasonable and delicious.

A nice place to explore, full of charm and less touristy.. Not as busy as old town but this is one of the advantages. Plenty to see and do, some nice restaurants and cafes to enjoy at reasonable prices if you leave the Charles bridge area. There's a lovely park on the water front with some fabulous views of the city. If you are feeling energetic go to Petrin park!

Authentic medieval atmosphere. My favorite district in Prague. Not as crowdy as Old Town, a lot of great views and architecture and less attended restaurants. If you want to feel authentic medieval atmosphere - visit Mala Strana.

clean house fronts.. not many cities are so well kept and their architecture so varied in styles of once upon a time.so many various decorations that one must walk with the eyes up to the walls at all times so as not to miss a shape,a symbol.
Beautiful Area. Our hotel was in this area and we walked around most of Prague and the Mala Strana is a lovely area of this city. Would have no hesitation in staying here again.

NEXT TIME WOULD STAY HERE. Slightly quieter than other areas although delightfully attractive with numerous small restaurants, bars, hotels and just wonderful welcoming doorways and entrances - waiting to be explored. Streets are cobbled and winding,as always in Prague beautiful buildings all around, castle areas and parks above, river below, Strangely, in spite of being in the middle of a tourist area it feels calm.

Beautiful area in Prague. I love Mala strana, the beautiful old architecture, close to Charles bridge, lovely restaurants. It is a romantic place where you can walk around the cobblestone streets and there are busy and quiet areas.

A magical quarter. Although this neighborhood is not extremely in the center and on the west bank of the river, it is close to Prague Castle and has a very unique and old style. Of course it has many restaurants and hotels so I would recommend this area for your next stay. Just for notice, if I'm not wrong, the second season of "Outlander" was filmed there, demonstrating the 18th century streets of Paris,
One of the most beautiful places in Prague. Mala Strana is one of the most beautiful places in Prague - narrow streets, a lot of restaurants and coffee shop and interesting architecture.
Old district. This was a very quiet district when we were there, and it was a pleasure to wander around unimpeded by groups of people.

Less touristy, more real. The Little Quarter has a more unique, local feel to the (sometimes too) touristy and overcrowded Old Town. Just cross the stunning Charles Bridge and enjoy - the riverside locations, the Kafka museum, the little shops, bookstores and cafes, the Lennon Wall and Pub, the park, the old rivermill wheel, the swans and ducks on the Veltava... I loved the atmosphere of this little place.

Beautiful neighborhood. This neighborhood is a mixture of old and new. Beautiful buildings, tons of cafes, galleries, restaurants and pubs, and amazing views all around, especially as you go up the hill.
Wearing comfy shoes and go exploring!. Amazing little cafes in the back streets, hidden gems round every corner, and absolutely amazing views!!

Less tourist shops. Don't spend all of your time in Old Town! Give an equal amount of time to walking around lesser town. Less tourist shops, which means more attention can be put to architecture. It's very pretty and can be peaceful.

The real Central European feeling. Prague is a bright brilliant of Europe. Malostranske Namesti is one of the best places to enjoy it. Beautiful architecture, history at its best. Ther only negative thing is the crowd. Cohorts of noisy tourists spoil the feelig.
And do not forget to enter one of the many beer-pubs to have a sip of the best beers ever!
Best place to live. Dine and visit. Medival, old and stunning. Small streets with hundrets of restaurants, amazing houses, churches, museums...

We went back a second time. . We should have stayed longer our first visit.
Oh well, we just had to back a second time to take in more.
So take your time on your visit and, please enjoy the beautiful place.

Very nice part of Prague. This part of Prague is very nice to walk through, to enjoy quiet atmosphere of narrow streets, old buildings, small, cozy cafes - this beautiful place has served as a backdrop to many historical films, expecially situated to the age of "National revival", i.e. 1770 - 1848. Mala Strana is one of the most visited places in Prague by tourists and also by Prague residents due to the fact, that you can relax in a completely different place than the other Prague...
Nice. Very nice walk around here, specially if you're lucky enough to don't have rain when you're there. Anyway there is history every corner, very nice and interesting.

Cozy blocks and lovley church. I can really recommend this part of the town! Malá Strana is one of Prauges biggest pearls! Here you find meny old beautiful old houses and a outstanding church. So cozy, it´s a lot slower pace here, then in the old town. You can just find a nice cafe and take a coffe and then move on and see some more old houses. You must be at least a half day at Malá Strana! When you´re done here, you can take a walk up to Prauge castle. Really beautiful there too!Take the metro (linie A) to Málostranska or the tram to Málostranské square.

Charming, peaceful walk along Mala Strana's medieval town.... We walked from Prague castle all the way to the Church of Our Infant Jesus, thru Mala Strana…it was a pleasant walk, more quiet and peaceful compared to Old town. Walked to Kampa Park and Petrin Hill as well..all located nearby.

Terrific!. It was a great surprise. I was intending only to visit the John Lennon Wall, but had to extend my tour through the streets of Mala Strana. Got lucky to have a blue sky day. Everything was wonderful.
The famous avenue leading to the old town Square. I was staying at Clarion close to Mala Strana and you cannot miss this winding road through the medieval town.
Wonderful location.. It was a wonderful experience touring this district and its amazing old homes, gardens, etc. We plan to come back next Easter for another tour of this area!

Peaceful area with some green space. Enjoyed walking through this area on the way back from the Castle compound. It opens into a small square with a few cafes and shops. It was nice to be close to the river and see some green space. Went to the Kamka Museum. Interesting but don't feel you have to see it all.

Charming. A beautiful area that's steeped in history with stunning old buildings and churches. Lots of eateries and souvenir shops (only went in one). A busy area that's not on an even level but a nice active walk nonetheless. And take care when crossing the road, even at a zebra crossing.
Quaint. Nice here but quite a few tourist trap cafes here that weren't all that great. Nice for an hour or two, but certainly more going on over the other side of the river
Walking through time. Enjoy this charming walk through one of the most amazing historical areas that still is available for the public.

Beautiful alleys and parks and lovely cafes and restaurants. Great district to lose yourself in with quaint shops selling souvenirs and beautiful photo opportunities as well as scattered art works including Lennons wall ( a letdown as is just a graffiti spot really)

Great place to visit. Beautiful in each aspect - walking only, testing restaurants (lots of them) visiting churchs (plenty to amaze you) or following some of the tours availanle. It is an unique experience.

Great area.. I love staying in Mala Strana, our hotel was right by the bridge and it has everything and everything is within walking distance. It has character, there's plenty to see just be walking along and there are some great places to stop off for a coffee and cake.

Mala strana. not so much to see
on the way to Wenceslas Square from powder tower
a lot of stors to shop pandora and so

Great area to stay in. I was staying at a hostel in this area, and I do not regret it one bit. Yes, it is a fifteen minute walk from Old Town, but in this area one finds beautiful buildings, many restauarnts and several shops.
Just as beautiful as the old town and less crowded. Just by crossing the Charles Bridge and wandering around you can see some amazing streets and buildings with a lot fewer people.
Iconic Prague quarter. Connecting Castle District to Old Town, Malá Strana has Iconic historical look of Prague. Architecture here is just stunning and walking through just unforgettable.

I live in Prague and I am not Czech.... I live in Prague and I am not Czech but my friends and family visit me. Everytime someone comes I need to take them to this area, it's a fantastic adventure to let them walk here so they can get lost and walk and so many beutiful allies. My best advice is to start in old town square, walk on Charles bridge and get lost on the allies trying to go to the Castle, Old town and Charles bridge are not part of Malastrana but you should give like 5 hours of your day to do all this, you are going to see a big part of Prague like no one else, of course you need to do this by walking.

Fantastic Walking District Near the Castle and Abbey. The lower City below the castle is absolutely charming to ramble through after visiting the castle or the Abbey (a must go, if for one the brewery!). There are of course a great deal of tourist shops, but the trinkets are reasonably priced, and the store owners much friendlier than I'm used to in other big European cities. I highly suggest just going down strange streets to find all the funny Czech jokes spread around as restaurant names, architecture, etc.

close to the old city, fantastic restaurants, bars, parks ... not as touristy. slightly away from the madding crowds. Definitely not as busy as the old town, but far better value for money restaurants & bars.

More serene than the Old and New Town. On the west bank of the Vltava river covering the slopes below the Prague Castle is Mala strana or Lesser Town as it is commonly called. Surprisingly, it was called the New Town when it was found in the 13th century but later changed to the present name when the existing New Town on the east bank of Vltava river came into being. It is different from the east side of the river as it has steeper streets and stairways and my general feeling is it is quieter and more peaceful. With the Prague Castle looming above, Lesser Town has a lot of its own attractions notably the St. Nicholas Church at Lesser Town Square, the Church of our Lady Victorious, famous for the infant Jesus of Prague effigy, the Petrin Lookout and the Lennon Wall. There are also plenty of restaurants, pubs and eateries in this part of the City so together with the Prague Castle, a whole day could be well spent in this quarter.

Baroque Palaces and Beautiful Streets. From my point of view, the best way to approach this lovely part of town is to come from the Castle Hill through the vineyards. On weekends you can visit finest gardens of Wallenstein palace and then continue to Malostranske namesti with St. Nicholas church. Enjoy the beautiful houses and streets and finally, end at Charles bridge.

Lovely shops. This is the more peaceful end of Prague with plenty to see and do tough enroute to the Castle. Worth dawdling along to see what you can find. Look out for the Koh-i-Noor shop for the propelling pencils made in Prague

Take your time and take in the sights. The Lesser Town. This is a lovely area of old Prague, connecting the Old Town across the Charles Bridge and the Castle District of Hradcany. The architecture is unusual and colourful and the decorated buildings are a draw for photographers. There are numerous cafes and restaurants offering genuine Czech food or those with a more international cuisine.The area is a must for the first timer to Prague and just take your time and enjoy it.

Wonder around and see what you find. Pretty area of Prague, honestly though you can find hundreds of places just as pretty. Just wonder the streets and see what you find. Mala strana is beautiful and popular area, so quite busy most of the time. Lots of restaurants and bars to enjoy!

Peace and quiet in the middle of the tourist bustle. We stayed here - it was very quiet and there are lots of roads and lanes to explore, only a stone's throw from all the crowds. A peaceful, interesting place
Character buildings. Great Czech buildings, plenty of cafes/bars and restaurants and a great place to relax in,Just over Charles Bridge and close to the castle.
Just Walk the Streets. Every corner/every street is a treat. Just walk, explore, take lots of pictures. Wander down the streets with the least people.

Nice district . This district is connected to old town via charles bridge. The area offers good views and various shops to buy suveniors or eat good quality food.
Well worth a visit if you are in prague. Combine this with your visit to Prague Castle.

Worth visiting . Very nice and picturesque region. Absolutely worth visiting it and walking around. Be prepared for ups and downs but you will be very satisfied with the view. Lots of nice restaurants and coffee houses.
Nice neighbourhood . Such a lovely part of town! Not nearly as crowded by tourists as the Old town, plus it has its own charm. Definitely recommended! Just bear in mind, some parts are uphill.
Beautiful district . Mala strana is a beautiful area of Prague with many things to see,such as Lennon' wall, Kampa Island etc. Mala strana is connected with Old Town with through Charle's Bridge.
Great . This area is situated in the hilly area and it's wonderful area for a walk. The Prague castle is situated in this area and the view of entire city can be seen from here.

Just heaven. The Mala Strana-district in beautiful Prague is one of those cosy little neighborhoods which succeeded to still capture the heart and feeling of the soul of Prague throughout the centuries. Way to go, and very good! I can get lost for hours, and the people are kind (most of them are scared of strangers, though), and if the overload on churches and musea and deep sewer pipes don't get you running, than definitely, come and look for real estate in Mala Strana, for this place is just heaven.

Over Charles Bridge and youre there. A fantastically peaceful and yet totally interesting area of Prague away from the main city. Winding streets with little nooks and crannies to explore, beautiful little shops selling a wide variety of items plus some of the best small boutique coffe shops offering not only coffee but excellently prepared pastries and snacks.

Just over the river - and so different!. A piece of old Prague quite different from the other side of Charles' bridge. The cobbled streets running uphill have their own unique charm, if you manage to take your eyes off the gift shops, cafes and galleries lining many of them. However, some of those are interesting by they own right. If you have time, wander around and discover hidden gems - a view of the castle from an unexpected angle, a bust of Churchill on street corner, a figurine of troll fishing from a bridge, Alchemist's Tower museum etc. Warning: stiletto heels are NOT recommended!

Charming and quaint.. We were staying in Smichov, so just a short stroll to here 10 minutes at most.Would much rather amble about on this side of the river than the other side. Some very old and historic buildings to see. Just a nice pleasant way to spend the morning and afternoon.
Great . Really enjoyed the architecture around here. Lots to see and lots to do. Would recommend to anyone. Great restaurants and shopping.

Discover the real Prague. Prague has so much to offer, but most people spend most of there visit in "Old Town" Prague and overlook the quieter Malá Strana district, also known as "Lesser Town" section of Prague.

U can cover this in the walking tour. U can cover this in the walking tour.V didnt pay for any walking tours..V just strolled the praha streets and these are worth the visit...Very close to the vitava river

Come here first!. If you are looking for old-time Prague, this is the place to visit. Much less 'touristy' than Stare Mesto. The buildings are older and it is more peaceful and atmospheric than the other side of the Charles Bridge. I will definitely stay this side of the river next time I come. The restaurants are also significantly cheaper and of a more traditionally Czech style. If 'human statues', 120kr coffees and segway rides are not your thing, come here!
Nice place. Medieval type buildings. Closed in streets and right near the castle and bridge. Lovely part of the city. Some nice restaurants nearby over looking the river.
Wonderful area of Prague. We were staying in this area and it really was a fabulous place to be based. Much quieter than the old town with lots of lovely places to visit.
Beaurtiful and quieter than Stare Mesto. We stayed in Mala Strana, and it was quieter than the other side of the Charles Bridge. Nice restaurants, easy PT, easy walk in to Old Town.

The most picturesque area of Prague!. Lesser Town or Mala Strana is the place where you can see Prague at it's best. Do not make the mistake most tourists make that they hurry on to the Castle district and miss this quaint picturesque part of Prague. This area has lovely cobbled streets, historical burgher houses, ancient alleys and wonderful view of the river. It's nucleus is the Malostranske Namesti a Baroque square. You can see the Saint Nicholas Church here. There are lovely shops, eateries and pubs in this area. As the sun sets Mala Strana becomes all the more enchanting. The Lesser Town was established in the 8th century as a marketplace. It was ravaged by the war between the hussites and the Prague Army in 1419. Next the Great Fire of 1514 devastated this area. This is the reason most churches and palaces were built after the 17th century and are of Baroque or Renaissance style. When Amadeus was being shot Milos Forman chose Mala Strana rather than Vienna for several scenes to give the film the old time feel.Tip: Do visit Kampa Park and do try to walk in the back alleys of this district.

beautiful part of prague. This is the oldest part of Prague and well worth a stroll. Lovely cobblestoned, winding streets filled with Medieval and Renaissance houses. Lots of great photo opportunities, or just soak in the history.

Most beautiful area in Prague!. On our last day with extra time, we walked across the Charles Bridge and stepped into this beautiful area. The Bridge and old town are crowded and have a busy and more touristy feel. but we just wanted a walk in the sunshine and to visit St. Nicholas Church across the Bridge. We were not disappointed, as the closer you walk to the other side of Charles Bridge, the more beautiful the views. A mixture of sculptures on the Bridge, musicians, small cobbled streets, smaller crowds make this area perfect. We had read that it was picturesque, but really we did not expect it to be so beautiful. we walked the streets on our way to St. Nicholas Church, and even stopped in the very large Starbucks (clean, free toilets, lots of seating, ) to take a rest before heading back. The church is also spectacular, and we wished we had more time to shop and explore the restaurants. Next time I go to Prague I will start Here and bypass the Old Town Square!

Picturesque. After going over Charles Bridge you arrive at Mala Strana and it is worth having a walk around. In this area you will find Kampa Park, the Lennon Wall and giant crawling babies from Mr Cerny!! It is also easy to grab a tram up to the Castle from around here. It is easy to spend time getting lost in the beauty of the area

Walk through old Prague. Mala Strana is the historic old quarter of Prague and starts no sooner than you cross the Karluv Most. Walk the cobble-stoned roads and wide mosaiced footpaths as you drink in the history of Prague. Those of you less inclined to walk can take a Segway ride or a comfortable ride in the red hotrods (that resemble vintage cars). It is a little long and steep walk up to the Prague Castle for those who don't want the bus or tram rides to intrude on their walk through the times.Amble through the bylanes or follow the tram tracks to discover the Church of the Lady Victorius and the Petrin Hill a little further up.Mala strana has a big tram and bus stop at the square (mala Strana Namesti) and the metro station (across the Wallenstein Garden). Plenty of options to spend your time at Mala Strana.
What can I say...... I think I've waxed lyrical already about the beauty of this amazing city. This will not disappoint. Stunning.

Most wonderful neighborhood. We really enjoyed staying at Lokal Inn. Had a big suite so we could all fit in. Mala Strana has tourist shops but also lots of beautiful side streets and cafes that are more local in Character. There are beautiful mansions, parks, good transportation and a lot of views. Very easy for getting to the castle and other sites.
Wonderful place. A lot of amazing alleys. You can spend there some time walking. Keep in mind that there will be always a lot of people but it doesn't matter.

Don't Miss. The Mala Strana (Little Quarter) is home to many embassies, consulates, churches, small streets, and restaurants. Located at the base of the castle and as you cross the Charles Bridge from Old Town Prague this is a lovely area not to be overlooked. At a minimum I suggest talking from the bridge up to the Little Quarter square (where the trams stop), at this location you can rest at Starbucks or get a bite at a number of good restaurants (tourist prices do apply). From here walk up to the castle through the various squares and streets (well marked), if you prefer you can continue past the castle steps and cross into the park and climb the observation tower and return to central Prague via the funicular or any number of walking paths. I’ve spend more than a day (not all at once), just exploring this area over the course of many visits.
First time in Prague. Interesting area at the foot of the castle, a lot of shops to look at and well served by different trams.

This area is well wortyh it. Visiting this area on foot (how else), history leaks from every mortar joint! friendly locals (though they perhaps need to learn that smiling does help) and the walk up to the castle and the monastery was exhilirating

Amazing. I choose to revisit this area on my last day and took my time wandering along the Vltava river admiring the view and the buildings. So many beautiful buildings with so many variations. Archetypal delights. I was fortunate to have afternoon sun and then crossed the bridge to the other bank.

Very nice neighborhood. Nice walks. On my point of view It is much nicer than the old town. A bit less of tourists and places with greater value for money. Nice small typical restaurants. Excellent coffee shops. In general a nice place to walk around, I prefer the secondary quiet streets.
Worth it. Very beautiful location in Prague, one of the oldest as well. Really worth going to see all the magnificence hidden in buildings, and the neighborhood itself.

Nice walk. We had been to the Petrin Tower and walked around this area after lunch. The buildings are very picturesque, it's a lovely area. Most streets were pretty quiet but the main roads had quite a few tourists. Lots of nice little places to eat or drink. We always try to go somewhere that looks busy with locals.

Masopust - Carneval. Great square with history, It happened that it was the afternoon of Carneval.Czech got into masks and have some fun on the street even the police walk with them. TO make sure that is all safe! Love it!

Different view of Prague . . .. All of Prague is beautiful, but it is worth taking a few hours to explore Mala Strana. St. Nicholas is a top sight of the area, and a stroll up Nerudova well worthwhile.

Quiet and interesting. Our hotel was located here so we walked the area a fair bit. Less crowded than the old town, you get a better feel for Prague in this area. It has some nice restaurants and bars and being the "diplomatic quarter" it has some very interesting architecture

A walk on the Lesser Side. Remember that the Lesser Town contains the area under the Castle stretching from the Malostranska metro around to Petrin Park and includes Kampa. Several nice parks and gardens in the area and well known as a diplomatic area as it contains many embassies. Loads of stories and legends. Most will visit the ST Nicholas church and the Church of Our Lady Victorious (Infant Jesus) but there are a lot different attractions, restaurants and cafes in the area. Make sure you spend some time down by the river.

Get ready to use your camera!!!!. It is a lovely area...so many different quirky sights. Perfect for anyone to test their photography skills! Be wary of dodgy tour guides and currency exchange....there are plenty in this area.

Real treats away from the hustle and bustle. If you are folks like us who prefer to avoid the crowds and most touristy parts, but find joy in stumbling into delightful chance encounters and conversation, Mala Strana has lots to offer. Our week in January 2016 was perfect for wandering - dry and cold, with a few cms of snow to give that winter wonderland atmosphere. We strolled the back streets, seeing Malta Square, the Lennon Wall, the Church of St Nicholas, water wheels and a museum on the Kampa canal, the rather weird Alchemist's Museum, climbed up to Petrin Hill, and enjoyed the panorama from the replica of the Eiffel Tower (which does sway a little in the wind!), all the while trying various coffee shops. Our favourite area was just north of Charles Bridge near the Vltava river, where we enjoyed tea and cakes with a newspaper at the "Bakeshop", a tour de force of Czech Wines and digestifs at "Vinograf", browsing in the English bookshop (which is more of an international bookshop), to name but a few, and all with the adjacency and views of Charles Bridge. In the back streets of Marla Strana you are unlikely to get chased by ticket sellers or tour advertisers, and will find ample places to strike up interesting conversations, which give one a real flavour of Prague.

Another side of Prague. Everything in Prague is historical. This is another one of the must see. Have a local tour guide with you so he/she can explain everything and there are alleys that are interesting to tourist.
Less crowded area of Prague. This part of Prague is less crowded than the Old Town area of Prague. You can wonder around the streets for a long time and won't get bored of this place.

Wedding anniversay week in Prague. Our hotel was in the Lesser Quarter, the Hotel Constans. This is a very refined area with nicer restaurants and a very safe environment as there quite a number of Embassies here and consequently a lot of discreet police.
Roam the Town. It's a great place to roam around - especially when you are not with a tour. Free-and-easy walks will be great in this area.
A little less crowded. Less people, but equal in beauty and at the base of the castle. Can you imagine how this area has changed and who has come through here?
Must See. Indescribable... just loved it. The Baby of Prague is here, St. Nicholas Church (taxi driver will say to Americans: "Santa Claus Church")... beautiful architecture...beyond words.

December in Prague. Very nice area to explore with things to see at each turn. We went here on our second day in Prague after spending the first day in Old Town. In early december it was not crowded and earlier the better. You can also time your trip by eating at one of the restaurants recommended on Trip Advisor.

Cute part of town, essential as part of Prague visit. The castle, cathedral, cute streets with beautiful houses, monasteries and churches.
And great restaurants and typical beer houses.
Mala Strana should be on anyone's list when visiting Prague!

Nice Little area of City. Adjacent to city center it really merges with it, except that the buildings are less grandiose. Great area for shopping and seeing a bit of the Old Prague. Also great area for finding and buying granate in respectable, non touristy jewelry shops.

Must cover if you want to know Prague. Apparently all the rich folks lived here back in the day. So, you'd have to explore it to fully appreciate the disparity of wealth in the day. They even built their own St. Nicholas church!

so romantic in winter!. We spent some days in Prague in winter and Mala Strana was the most romantic part of the town. We took a long walk round this district visiting Malostranské náměstí - the main market square with Kostel svatého Mikuláše.
We were lucky cause we had enough time to spent there the whole day.
Historic. Just wonder in the tiny streets of the town and discover its gems. Take your time to contemplate the architecture all around you.

Best part of Prague. When you can, stay in Mala Strana. The streets are not as busy as Old Town yet the experience is better and scattered with nice parks, cathedrals, the Castle, good hidden bars and restaurants. Everything is walking distance, not as spread-out as Old Town

Peace in the city. We walked from the bottom of the hill to the peak! The view from the top of the tower was amazing!
We spent some time chatting on the grass near the tower,the atmosphere was great and the weather of Prague in March was perfect for a small hike! Totally recommend this spot! Must go!

Much preferred part of town.... For me, Mala Strana is the best part of Prague. With the narrow streets paved with cobblestones, with the many varied designs in the blue, gray and white granite pavers - walkways- that I learned to walk on and later skillfully navigate in high heels as a young girl years ago.
