The Prague girls always knew how to dress well:)I love it for the many palaces with their facades and interiors as fabulous as palaces in Vienna or Rome, for the great baroque gardens hidden behind thick doors or gates, for the other quiet and still undiscovered places by tourists. I love the wonderful parks with the same old benches, the beautifully restored churches and the many cozy cafes and elegant restaurants.Mala Strana is a very special place for me, place where I grew up and a place that I love to return to every chance I get. No matter how far away I live, this corner of the world becomes home again the minute I arrive...

mala strana. just across from the charles bridge,this is the quieter end of town and certainly the most beautiful.the reastaurants are quieter,and more intimate.went to the music museum,wonderful,no crowds,a great find on our last day.

The beauty of Prague. This place is where Prague's beauty shines the brightest. A place filled with amazingly beautiful buildings, statues, monuments etc.The street vendors offer some amazing bites at really low prices, which can be enjoyed with a cup of hot mulled wine or Mead.

Quiter part of Prague. Mala Strana is well worth going to. Lovely old buildings and small cobblestone alleyways, good restaurants and bars and best of all, not too many people. The John Lennon wall is in this area, follow the map to find it!
Picturesque. Right accross Charles' Bridge and under Hradcany the picturesque quarter with narrow streets and buildings taken out from a fairy tale is definitely worth a visit.

Perfect!. When passing through Charles Bridge you will enjoy this beautiful area built from the Middle Ages!It's full of restaurants,souvenirs shops and sweet little coffee shops!It's definitely worth a visit before or after visiting the Castle!

Again, it's easy to find beauty in Prague.. Another corner turned. Another road travelled. Another amazingly beautiful area discovered.
It never ends. Everywhere is just beautiful building after beautiful building. Great shop after shop or lovely restaurant after restaurant.
It's just so superb. You have to visit these areas of Prague or you will miss out.
Lesser Quarter. Well worth a stroll around. Beautiful architecture , lovely little shops and cafes. Also cheaper eats and drinks than Old Town. My second favourite part of Prague. Stunning.

Lots of back streets to discover. We stayed for a week in Mala Strana and loved it. So much to discover, lots of public art - Proudy, giant babies and the John Lennon wall. Some lovely coffee shops and some fantastic restaurants and all at the end of the beautiful Charles bridge.
Nice walk . As we were advised by our hotel reception "go there and get lost in the streets". That we did and greatly enjoyed our walk there.

Must see in prague. So much to do and see here its impossible to write it all. Great vibe and energy there plus so much history and architecture. Not as busy as center and just another cool place to mak sure you see to find out which area is your favorite.

Busy place but nice to see. We visited the famous John Lennon wall.Lovely small place to walk down from the castle and super nicely stocked small stores with loads of choice of souvenirs which leaves no open wish unfilled. Again many food choices from Italian to Japanese and yummy local Czech foods...If you have time and spen several days in Prague than this is not to be missed.

Quieter section of the town. Perfect for wandering. Located near to the Charles Bridge, this is one of the quieter 'quarters' but no less interesting. Lots of winding streets and watery avenues make the lesser quarter almost Venice-like. Great for mooching around; plenty of cafes & restaurants. If you want a change from the bustle of the main squares, take a look

Beautiful and quiet.. Away from the busy centre and a small step off the Charles Bridge lands you in a beautiful peaceful neighbourhood which can allow you to relax and enjoy a walk and a sit in the park on a good weather day.There are a few sight seeing spots such as the John Lennon wall and the Kampa museum(where an unfiltered Gambrinus beer can be found at a decent price in a restaurant just below).

BEAUTIFUL PART OF PRAGUE. PRAGUEI spent a wonderful few days in Prague with my hubbie John from 26 – 29th October. On researching the area, I decided to stay in Mala Strana, also known as Lesser Prague. The area is just a few minutes from Charles Bridge and is a lovely quiet scenic part of Prague. We stayed in the beautiful U Krale Karla Hotel, a four star boutique hotel. Looking at the pictures of the place alone, I was in heaven, an old converted monastery with stained glass windows and frescos on the wall. The reviews said the staff were very friendly and accommodating and we were not disappointed. We booked a taxi through the hotel, which was waiting for us at the airport. We booked our package with Cassidy Travel. I always assumed it would be much cheaper to book the accommodation and flights separately, but Cassidy Travel were much cheaper. We got four days in Prague with Aerlingus Flights in a four star hotel bed and breakfast for 450 for the two of us, amazing value. The only mistake I made really was not booking the transfer with Cassidy Travel as I later found out they do direct transfers to any hotel for 10 euro return.I had read up about the street our hotel was located on Neurodova Street, which was named after a famous poet and had loads of beautiful hotels on it. The sweep from Charles Bridge uphill to Mala Strana and Petrin Hill is truly beautiful with magnificent views from the top of Petrin Hill right down to the bridge and beyond.Hotel U Krale KarlaWe arrived after a 30 minute taxi ride at U Krale Karla. I loved the place immediately. We were welcomed in by a lovely friendly receptionist, who offered us sparkling wine as we filled in our reservation forms, excellent idea! We arrived at our lovely room on the second floor. The whole landing area was so ornate and pretty and our room had a reception area with a couch and coffee table to the front, and then into a quaint room with stained glass windows and beautifully decorated ceiling. The whole atmosphere was wonderful. We had enquired in advance about soya milk and margarine and the hotel told us they would provide same. They did and brought it out to us every morning. We did ask for beans and mushrooms with breakfast, which they also duly provided, though we should have rung ahead about same too. They also had a range of cereals, breads, teas and coffees including decaf coffee, which suited me great. It was a lovely welcoming little room with frescoes on the walls, very cosy. Adela, the receptionist on the second day was the woman who I had made all my enquiries through and like the first receptionist, Martina, she was extremely helpful. They front of house staff are very happy to go through the map with you and make suggestions and are there to answer any enquiries. I fully understand now how people go back to this beautiful hotel time and time again. We certainly would not contemplate staying anywhere else when we return and the area itself is so lovely, just 10 minutes from Charles Bridge, but as you walk past the bridge back into the area, the franticity level goes down a good few notches and so do the prices. A fantastic area and hotel to stay in.We had decided to roam around Mala Strana the first day so we duly unpacked and headed off. We were delighted to find we were right beside the historic castle and a few minutes walk to the bridge. We walked in and soaked up the atmosphere but being naturally nosey, we had to cross that bridge and see what was on the other side. The architecture everywhere is absolutely amazing. I actually cried one night crossing the bridge back to Mala Strana, seeing all the old buildings lit up and just trying to inhale the sheer beauty of the place. Prague cuisine, like most places, is supremely carnist, so we did our research and found some vegi and vegan restaurants. Other than that, we just pottered around the city and decided to stop wherever we felt like. Below are the restaurants and bars we checked out:Lo Veg Mala Strana:On our first night, after walking way further than we intended to, we decided to stay locally for dinner and after a drink at one of the lovely old bars, we headed to this restaurant about two minutes away from our hotel. We were warned about the large amount of stairs to conquer on the way up to the restaurant but braved it nonetheless. This is a fully vegan restaurant, with a terrace that has views of the castle. We reached the top of the stairs and arrived into a lovely relaxing room. We both decided to order two different types of burgers. It was great having so much choice on the menu. We had a bottle of organic wine. Neither of us are into desserts so we were happy with our mains and wine. The food was lovely and there was a nice cocooned atmosphere. Looking back on it, and the other restaurants we tried, I now realise there were better restaurants to go to so I would probably not dignify it with a return visit next time, but it was nice and fully vegan.Maitrea, Old Town:This is a vegetarian restaurant just behind the old town square. I was glad we had looked it up because with so many side streets, it’s not a place we would have necessarily stumbled upon. We were warned you would probably have to book. We had just completed a long tour and were quite whacked so we were having an early dinner before our walk across the bridge and a drink in a local bar. Maitrea is a lovely spacious restaurant. Their sister restaurant Clear Head is also meant to be amazing and housed in an old building further away in Prague. We will definitely try there the next time. We ordered noodle and veg dishes, that came down with abundant rice noodles and veg heavily flavoured with ginger and soya and tofu. The dishes were absolutely beautiful, mouthawateringly fabulous. The bill was very reasonable too.Postel, Old Town:We happened upon this place one day for lunch. It wasn’t vegi or vegan but had plenty of options as they had a lot of Mexican fare. Many of the menus in Prague are the same old goulash rich mush so it was nice to find somewhere different. We decided to order fajitas between us and we were very glad we only ordered one portion as they came down on an enormous sizzling platter with plenty of tortillas, absolutely delish, washed down with a delish Pilsner Urquel. Beer in Prague is very cheap, especially if you go a little away from the old town, check the prices but we were able to get beers for 30 – 40 kronas, approximately 1.20 for a pint.Medieval Tavern, adjacent to the Castle:I absolutely loved this place. Again, we just happened upon it one day whilst walking from Charles Bridge up to the castle. We were enchanted by the place, allegedly Prague’s oldest tavern. It was great fun, all done up with gothic delight, fake spiders and old lanterns everywhere. We were wondering why the staff were banging down the beers and shouting “more beers” when you finished, until we read the menu and it was a deliberate policy in their endeavour to emulate medieval times. Despite this deliberate brusqueness, the staff were actually really friendly and helpful. We also ordered a vegi platter, which was absolutely delicious, a selection of grilled veg, potatoes, courgettes, aubergines, mushrooms, corn etc, which went down very nicely with ye old beers!!. We had to go back here on our last day as nowhere beat this place for atmosphere and it’s right beside the castle.Mali Buddha, Mala StranaOn our walks around Mala Strana, we ventured up to the wonderful Petrin Hill and soaked in the beauty of all the nearby parks and views of the city. We walked right up to the top of Mala Strana as far as the square and on our way down, saw this restaurant. It was daytime and it was closed and we were checking it out for evening, and noted they had a huge vegi section in their menu. We went back on our last night and we were absolutely amazed when we walked in to the place. It was huge, with candles everywhere and a beautiful aroma of food. We were lucky to get a table. We perused the huge vegetarian menu and when we enquired about vegan options, the waitress told us that all their vegi options were also vegan as they didn’t use dairy or egg. We ordered vegi springrolls to start. They were absolutely amazing, so light and moist, unlike the processed ones that are hard and crusty. We ordered two tofu mains with loads of veg and they were fantastic. The spring rolls also came with rice and veg. The entire meal was amazing and it was our cheapest meal in Prague, starters, mains, sides, wine all for under 30 euro. Exceptional value, amazing food, atmosphere and service. Out of all the places we tried, this is the one I recommend most highly. In fact, it’s one of the best restaurants we have ever eaten in anywhere. Tours:Sandeman’s Free Walking Tour – I deliberately did not book any tours bar the free walking tour of Prague. There were other tours I had in mind but didn’t want to plan too far. We went on the Sandeman’s Free Walking Tour on our second day. We had walked around a bit beforehand and had lunch in the Mexican-type restaurant and were debating about whether we would go or not as it’s a three hour tour and my hip is bad. However, armed with anti-inflammatories, we decided to brave it and I’m so very glad we did. Sandeman’s meet up in the old market square and can be found under a red umbrella. Our tour guide was Tijo and he was fantastic. The tour was well divided up with a stop at a bar half way through. We were taken all around the old town and new town and then had a break in a local bar and then onto the Jewish Quarter. Tijo had the right balance of being extremely informative and very witty, whilst never being boring or pedantic. The three hours went in a flash and it gave us a brilliant insight into Prague, wherein we wanted to discover more, in our own time. The break enabled us to mingle with the rest of the tourists on the trail and a very nice bunch they were as well. We ended our tour with a talk by the river and I’m so glad we did this tour as it was pivotal to our break. The tours are free but you can tip the guide what you like. Everybody was delighted with the tour and I would definitely go back and pay to go and see various places of interest in the Jewish QuarterSandemans do a range of tours and if Tijo had been doing the castle tour, the next day, I certainly would have availed of same.The Castle - We set off to the castle on our own and decided not to buy the tickets into all the buildings, but to walk around and see them all and walk into the ones that were free of charge or let you walk around to a certain point. There was a huge area to cover dotted with many coffee shops and eateries. The day before we had endeavoured to do same but the president was there giving a speech so we couldn’t access the buildings. On the day in question, we had a coffee outside one and kept walking, so much to see. I will definitely do a more extensive tour of the castle next time but it was a lovely introduction and a beer in the medieval tavern nearby afterwards is mandatory!Boat Trip – As stated previously, I looked up a good few trips, including one which we will probably do next time, jazz boat trip at night with Prague Experience, they are worth checking out. The thing is when you are walking around all day, you are generally pretty bushed by night time, so I was glad we kept things open. Instead, we decided to play it by ear and we went on a daytime boat trip instead. There were a few to chose from including a boat trip with sailors advertising same that takes you down in a little boat to the Venice of Prague. We decided on the hour long trip down by Kampa River, which took us in a large boat, which served refreshments, very cold, so mulled wine was a great idea, and took us up and down the river to see the main sights of Prague. This was a good trip. Main Sights:The CastleThe Lennon WallSt Nicholas ChurchJewish QuarterCharles BridgePetrin HillStrahov MonasteryThe above are the main sights but really the whole of Prague from Mala Strana through to the old town is like walking into a beautiful fairytale. I have no idea what the shopping is like as I could care less and never looked past the periphery of the new town. So much to see and do. Highly recommended.

My favorite part of prague. Such a charming area, full of boutique hotels, restaurants, alleys, cafes, beautiful buildings and architecture. Even has a Venice feel near the river. It is the best place to stay while in Prague due to the hotels and restaurant and the quietness around.
Romantic walk in this part of town. Walk around the beautiful streets of Lesser Quarter. The romantic feel will leave a smile in your face.

Stroll around this lovely part of town. This is the quieter part of town with some lovely buildings and good restaurants, take a walk up to the castle and spend a few hours exploring the surrounding streets and taking in the excellent views of the whole city

Worth a long, lingering wander. Really wish we'd had more time to spend wandering the narrow lanes of the main thoroughfare that leads up to the Castle and the Loreta. What we did see was enough to make us want to come back and explore further. There's a quaintness and sense of history here, and some wonderful photo opportunities just waiting to be discovered. There are also numerous small shops selling far better quality items than the usual tacky souvenir shops which seem to abound. Take your time and explore.

Very picturesque. Not realising that there is a section for this, the write up for the castle area pretty much covers this as the Lesser town is between the river and the castle area. It is well worth a visit with many shops and restaurants and pubs in the locality.Look over the doorways for signs whether having or engraved, to show what sort of profession the inhabitants may have had in the early days.

Forget the map, just wander around. Besides some obvious monuments you can't forget to visit, like the Church of Our Lady Victorious, it is a wonderful place to get lost. Beautiful buildings, very cute and typical stores, wonderful restaurants and little places where you can just sit and relax with a cup of tea. A very good place to wander, just enjoying the view and the city life.
Stunning. A must walk , although a bit cold this time of year,stunning views and architecture is fantastic, quite easy to spend the whole day wandering in and out of the many shops also.

Pretty district. Although we didn't spend a ton of time here, we did tour a couple of the main streets and the richly decorated Baroque St. Nicholas Church (worth a quick stop). If you have several days in Prague, you might spend part of a day wandering and shopping in this charming district.
Loved this more than Old Sqaure. It is a matter of personal taste but we found the Lesser Quarter far quieter and quirkier than the Old Town. Quieter and less exepensive.

lovely part of town. lovely old part of town nice little gift shops and lots of restaurants. liked the atmosphere of the Lesser Quarter. lots of Currency exchange shops but be sure to ask about the commission as I was not made aware it was 25% yet asked to sign a piece of paper saying I had been told everything

Not as busy. We stayed near the Lesser Quarter and found it to be less manic than the main area - not so many tourist groups and guided tours - really nice to wander round, good quality restaurants and bars all reasonably priced cheaper than the main sights well worth visiting

The quiet part of town. See some different architecture and have a walk through the quiet part of the town. Many shops and eateries here. On the Old Town side of the Vltava River, walk by the National Theatre, cross the bridge to reach the park near the Memorial to Victims of Communism. Take a right and a walk through the park leads to the Church of the Infant Jesus.

Beautiful!. We had the chance to actually stay in that area and loved the fact that it wasnt as crazy as the old town part of Prague. There is definitely less tourists in this area making it a little more pleasant to walk around. Great restaurants as well as cheaper shopping in that area!

Perfect area to stay in!. We stayed at the hotel Sax here. Loved the close proximity to the square but just far enough away from the hustle and bustle. Walking distance to the castle, John Lennon wall and a great gingerbread shop. Very clean and safe.

Lovely architecture and a bit less busy than old town. Spent a day over this side of town visiting the castle and then walking over to the Petrin Tower. Lots of nice architecture and little side streets. Feels a bit more upmarket and it cost us a bit more than we expected for a couple of hot wines at the Red Lion, but it was nice just the same. It was just UK prices and I guess you get used to reasonable prices in the Czech Rep. so "normal" prices suddenly feel high! Overall a very nice way to spend half a day.

Take Time To Explore. While still on the Old Town side of the Vitava River, walk down to the Legii Bridge (by the National Theatre) and cross the bridge - walk straight on to the edge of the park where you will see the Memorial to Victims of Communism. Turn right, stroll through the park towards the Church of the Infant Jesus. Cross the road and walk through the back street towards the river but move generally in the direction of Charles Bridge. When you are in sight of the bridge to your right, you have a choice - go up to the Castle area, cross back over Charles Bridge, visit the Liechtenstein Palace, enjoy the shops, or spend more time in the park, perhaps retracing your steps and taking the Funicular Railway up the hillside. Don't spend all your time in Old Town…be a little more adventurous.

Worth the walk. Walking around the Lesser Quarter is an excellent chance to access the less commercialised part of Prague.take a wander down some of the side streets to access cobbled squares with little restaurants off the main drag

Old world charm. On our visit we really loved the Old Town, but our favorite was the Lesser Quarter. Although, not boring, it was quieter. We loved the Castle, the Cathedral and just walking the streets and sitting at the street-side restaurants. It was nice to just wander!

Pleasant walk. I spent a couple hours just wandering around the lesser quarter, peeking in shops, sampling local food, people watching and enjoying the architecture and history. Located below the Prague Castle, this place has so much history and beautiful architecture.

Less Crowded. If you are looking to see more of the almost as old Prague without the crowds then Lesser Quarter is just the ticket. Located just over Charles Bridge it has a quaint gentle smile about it. Plenty of streets to explore with hidden treasures and its much quieter than other locations in Prague.

The cool Retro side of Prague. Yes , the old square and Wenceles square are important to this amazing city but honestly stay in Mala Strana which has such a retro cool side whilst retaining the citys dark gothic nature. We recommend the Hotel Pod Vesi which is at the foot of Charles Bridge (castle side) This is the perfect base , for seeing Prague , the restaurants , castle , cathederal and beautiful streets with their hidden restaurants are a real treat as is the "lennon wall" memorial and the John Lennon Pub whose staff cannot do enough to help you !! Little Venice rounds off this beautiful side to Prague and Mala Strana offers a cool , hip , relaxing side to the craziness of the shopping and old town square on the other side of the water !!

crowded street, with overpriced shops, must walk thos way to old town. The street is very narrow ND very crwoded. Pushy tourists and and shop owners selling their goods. Some tourists are the pushy type so be careful.

The "other" side of Prague. Located across the Charles bridge, this "lesser quarter" is just as charming as Old Town, if not more. Lots of side streets to explore, walk around and get lost in, and enjoy the less crowded parts of the city.

An extension of the old town square. Mala strand is somewhat similar to the old town square although the buildings are smaller. However you can still feel the old Europe with the castle and St Vitus Cathedral.
Great period architecturemembership location. Stayed in this area. Loved the buildings and the history. Very closer to the St Charles bridge as well as the U.S. EMBASSY.
Great mixture of architectonic styles. As like on the other side of river Vltave, in old town, there in Lesser Quarter you can find really nice places.
Lovely. Like most of Prague, it is full of beautiful old buildings. It makes a refreshing change to see a city that wasn't destroyed and "rebuilt" (badly) after WW2 and the Iron Curtain

Good relaxing walk. The Mala Strana area would be 3rd on my list of (after Old Town area and Castle area). So if you have time, this is a good place to stroll around. Tampa Park is relaxing and the art museum there has some good artwork outside. It seems to be an area that houses many different consulates, and the walk is very pleasant. John Lennon Wall and the love lock bridge are must see when you are there.
MORE HISTORY. Very different to the old town lots of very narrow cobbled streets alley ways arches ..quieter .. still as many places of interest all with great history worth a visit

"Beautiful and Peaceful Area". Be sure to visit this charming and quieter section of Prague. Highly recommend visiting St. Nicholas Church which is extraordinarily gorgeous and also highly recommend Bar Bar Restaurant. At the restaurant, we had the risotto with mushrooms entree and duck breast slices with pea puree entree. Both dishes were heavenly!

peaceful and quaint. This is a nice area that is quite different from the old town area. It is quieter and has beautiful buildings and narrow streets. Lots of nice shopping and restaurants. A bit slower paced and not as crowed as other areas.

This is a place you must visit . You need top take a few hours of your trip to go here.. The buildings are spectacular and there are small alleys literally everywhere. The place has a lot of charm even if you are not intending to go inside the castle itself
Touristy but beautiful. Take the Charles bridge across from Old Town and wander the narrow streets. Small restaurants and shops with an old world European feel.

My Favorite Part of Prague. This is a completely different experience than the Old Town area. Mala strana is on the other side of the Vltava River and is a quaint jewel of barogue architecture and smaller buildings. All the native Czechs I know prefer this part of Prague because it is "Prague as it used to be." Come across the Charles Bridge and you are in the entrance to Mala strana and that is where your exploring begins--lots of shops and restaurants.

Peaceful in all the bustle. Wandering around Mala Strana, even amongst all the tourists, and there are lots, it was amazingly peaceful to take in all that there is to see and do. Almost every building is worth pausing to look at, and there are some fabulous major attractions to. Plenty of coffee shops and bars.
Beautiful walks. Loved the Lesser Quarter - the beautiful quaint streets, lovely restaurants and shops you can spend some time walking around and it has beautiful St Nicholas church.

Nice part of town. I stayed on this side of the river, though I often found myself venturing over to the historic district. There are many great restaurants and bars on this side though, and it seems slightly less crowded.
A Fun Walk. We walked from the castle with our guide through the Lesser Quarter. Plenty of shops & restaurants to choose from. The streets are narrow & the building are interesting.
Amazing streets. When you wonder through the tiny winding streets of lesser town you are amazed by the architecture, small shops and the fabulous local cafes and bars

Very attractive area of prague. Lesser town square is an extremely pleasant area of Prague sitting beneath the castle and close to Charles bridge. It is heaving with bars and restaurants, most of which are reasonably priced

Nothing Lesser about this place!!. Opposite the old town on the other side of the river, across Charles's Bridge is Lesser town, Just so quaint and comfortable, more beautiful , in my opinion, and far less crowded than old town, so definitely worth a visit.For me old town was just jam packed and Charles Bridge too, so to wander around the cobbled streets here, was just a breath of fresh air.
Very enjoyable walk. Beautiful buildings and areas to explore. Lennon wall, Lennon pub, parks, consulate buildings, castle views, medieval bars, swans, walking around was enjoyable for a few hours.

Calm and Peaceful. It is lovely to walk around Mala Strana. There are many interesting buildings with loads of restaurants and interesting shops. You can spend hours looking at the buildings and browsing through the shops. There are lesser crowd in Mala Strana compared to the Old Town. You could breathe easier in Mala Strana. Some people missed Mala Strana as the hypes are mostly on the Old Town and Charles Bridge. Cross over the bridge and you will appreciate the calmness in Mala Strana.

Worth exploring en route to the castle. A great part of Prague! Check out the hidden walled gardens and the area down by the river. There's a lovely park too and lots of nice little shops to visit. It is touristy but everywhere in Prague is like that. Go first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds of tourists on coach trips.

Hotel Aria in Lesser Quarter Is Fabulous. We loved the Hotel Aria in the Lesser Quarter, with its musical theme and private access to The Vrtba Garden, an architectural jewel and a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Beautiful Mala Strana. Wonderful to stroll around the glorious old streets, and browse in fab shops, take coffee in the outdoor cafes
Cute. Lovely buildings around here with cute cobbled streets...a few beggers but nothing to worry out. Some interesting shops. It's worth a look in the day and evening.

Bustling quarter, not to be missed.... Our hotel was only about 500 meters from here, yet we seemed to not discover this area until our last day. Loads of restaurants, people watching and souvenir shopping. Definitely don't miss - gets you to explore the other side of the bridge. Spend some time walking to the water and see the numerous swans in the river, or stroll over to the Lenin wall. Great spot!

Hidden Gem of Prague. In two trips to Prague, I have found Mala Strana to be my favourite area of the city. It is close to all of the major attractions, is easily accessible by tram and has many great bars, restaurants and shopping. Do yourself a favour and give crowded Old Town a miss, stay here instead.
Really nice. I really enjoyed this part of Prague. We wandered through coming down from the Petrin Hills. The architecture is stunning and the streets are quieter than the old town.
Much quieter quarter. After the hustle and bustle of the old and new towns - retreat to this side of the bridge where the pace slows and you can relax again.

Much less crowded than the Old Town. The streets are charming and cobbled, there are the usual cafes and restaurants, plus you are very close to the tram stop. The castle is above the Mala Strana, plus you are within easy walking distance of the Charles Bridge to get into the main town area. The main benefit of this area though is that it is less crowded, less noisy and less costly than than the Old Town. We found it to be a lovely place to retreat to in the evenings after sightseeing and enduring the crowds of touristy Prague.
Cobble stone , embassies and charm. Go for a slow walk here. You will see unusual statues, old buildings, narrow European streets. Our walk was on excellent fall day - add brilliant foliage to it.

The best Quarter in Prague!. The best Quarter in Prague! Our family stayed in an apartment right at the base of the Charles Bridge in this Quarter and everything there is perfect. You can walk to most of Prague from there, but, you are minutes away from the loud tourists' noise. It is classy and filled with history. GO!

A terrific area. We are staying in this area. Plenty of dining in all price ranges and Choices as long as you want ethnic food. The Charles bridge is 200 meters. And the square is 200 meters the other way.

Beautiful area to walk around. This is a lovely area to stroll around both day and night. Lots of shops, restaurants and next to Charles Bridge to connect you to the Old Town. Definitely worth a visit if in Prague :)
Worth the trip over the bridge. Lots of little cafes and winding streets to explore. We just kept walking and stumbling on picture postcard buildings - lovely!

Another Good area to visit. While so many people center there time in Prague around Old Town, which definitely is a must see, we enjoyed hopping on the 22 Tram (you can buy a ticket at any Metro station), and seeing so many other parts of the city. This tram goes everywhere, is on time, and easy to "hop on/ hop off" and inexpensive,too! We rode this to the cemetary to find my husband's ancestors, to the Lesser Quarter, and all the way out to the big Tesco store, about 25 minutes out of the city, and back again. You'll enjoy the Lesser Quarter, as it is not as touristy, and there are many good restaurants here; bring some CZK cash, in case they don't take credit cards.
I would stay in this area. This area is magical, romantic, memorable. Quieter than Old Town, which is too crowded and full of souvenirs shops. If I ever go back to Prague I will stay here.
Amazing!. A particular feature with a particular history and charm. It cannot be missed especially at sunset when you have to push your way to see it work.
Beautiful area to stay.. Old, classic architecture that is well preserved. I enjoyed my stay in this part of Prague. Walking distance to all relevant sites.

Beautiful and magical . This place is the most beautiful place in Prague. You'll find something interesting or different in every corner, and don't forget to pick up a famous Trdelnik on the way.
I would suggest to take a walking tour through this area, or just wander through it yourself. After going there you will understand why they call Prague a magic town
Absolutely beautiful!. This is an utterly gorgeous area of town. All the beautiful buildings and historic streets are enough to make a person want to get lost here!

The other side of the bridge. Mala Strana is at the opposite side of the Vltava River from Old Town Prague. It's a beautiful area, rising from the river toward Hradcany and the Royal Palace, with lovely buildings, churches, and museums. Well worth a visit.

Just walk with no direction and discover every corner. I just decided to put aside my map and walk and walk ad walk. Loads of beautiful buildings. The place is not as packed as the castle or Charles Bridge area so it's more relaxing. Lots of shops and places where to eat.
Gorgeous . I could meander in this part of the city for hours and still want to do the same thing the next day. One of the highlights of my trip.
Exceeded expectations. Make a point of crossing the Charles bridge to visit this area of Prague. Every corner is a surprise. Shops and restaurants were excellent.

Get lost!. I really enjoyed getting lost on the winding streets of Mala Strana. Of course you can't really get lost as you will always find a way to see the river. It has a less touristy feel than Stare Miesto.
Night in the streets. If you just wander and wander around these beautiful streets you eventually come upon some real nutmegs. We found so many nice places to look at and go in.

The charming quarter of Prague. Mala strana is for me the most charming quarter of Prague. I like to walk by the small, picturesque streets with many shops, cafes and restaurants. There are many historical monuments, museums and small galeries. Many important people lived there, Jan Neruda, famous Czech poet and writer, among them. When I am on Mala strana I like to visit also the Waldstein Palace and its gardens and I am going for lunch to the pleasant nearby restaurant Valdsteinska hospoda,

Off the Beaten Path. Prague is a beautiful city....filled with many tour groups. However, this neighborhood has quiet beautiful streets to wander about as well as those with more action going on. The restaurants are here and there and tend to be quieter and quaint.

Good area to base yourself to see the sights of Prague. We were staying in a hotel in this neighbourhood, and were very pleased with the choice. We spent 5 days walking and tramming around the city, and even in high season, it was always a pleasant relief to get back across the frenetic, packed Charles Bridge, and into Mala Strana.It's well populated with shops, restaurants, cafes and the usual beautiful buildings that Prague is famous for, but significantly much less busy, quieter, and you can therefore stroll around without feeling like part of a herd of Wildebeest. We even felt perfectly safe walking through the area late at night, as it's well-lit and not the slightest bit threatening.The area is well served by trams, so you can hop on in the morning, and get to wherever you're spending the rest of your day, just yards from your hotel. You're also close to the main road (Karmelitska/Ujezd) which runs down in line with the river and will take you past the huge hillside park where you can pick up the funicular up to the observation tower, and (after a walk) the Castle area. You can essentially stroll all the way down to Most Legii (the bridge with an island in the middle), and from here, get a tram or walk across to Narodni, and ultimately Wenceslas square.In summary, if you want to be based conveniently close to the action, but in a quieter, less hectic and "touristy" district, this is a good choice.

Serene Square!. Down from the Prague Castle is this quiet area know as the Lesser Quarter or Mala Strana. What is found here in addition to the Parliament Building are small restaurants with great character and traditional Czech food and beer, but also little streets with interesting houses. Try the U Hrocha for an idea of the local pub meals.

A good place to visit . Maybe not a lot of turists arrive there, on the streets of mala strana quarter,but it's a pity because could be one of the most relaxing walk to do, good to remember place and good place to eat traditionally at a reasonable price.

Below the castle. At the foot of the castle is the small quarter which has maze like streets and a large number of good restaurants and museums. You definitely feel like you have gone back in time wandering these streets.
Interesting Part of Prague. As you explore old town Prague don't miss the lesser quarter. Find out about the history and significance of the area.
A nice area. I have stayed in this area several times. It is less hectic than over in the square. Easy transportation . It is right at the base of castle hill

Romantic and quite . We've been here during the day and went back during the night for a traditional dinner The atmosphere is completely different Day time visit lennon wall and karl bridge on this side also there is a nice record shop hidden in one of the allies called an music antiquariat a must for the record collector Night time a lot of traditional restaurant serving czeck food after the meal we strolled in the back allies and square

Beautiful Area. In old times this area was where the common people lived, now a thriving place with several shops and eateries. The place is full of beautiful buildings, most impressive being the St Nicolas Church. The area is just below the Prague Castle. You would enjoy walking through its narrow but beautiful streets. Place also offers lots of shopping and eating opportunities. Easily one of the best areas of Prague.

Prague at its most stunning. The Mala Strana is, in my opinion, the most beautiful area of Prague. It's buildings are amazing, the roads picturesque and there are plenty of things to do whilst being less crowded than the other side of the Vltava river. Highly recommended.

Little Square. The Little Square is the hub of the Mala Strana. There are cafes bordering the square near the tram tracks and is a great place to observe the various people and activities. It is a short walk to the west end of the Charles Bridge.
Special place!!. An enchanting district, full of characters! Lots of unique cafes and shops. Must visit when in Prague.
Lesser quarter. Interesting area and not quiet as crowded as the old town. Stay on this side if you can. Narrow streets. Visit St Nicholas church
Mala Strana. great area with a lot of nice buildings, restaurants and shops. Easy to reach by tram or/and foot. Local hang out places included

Misnomer - lesser quarter has loads to offer ;-). The lesser quarter was known as such because it is where the commoners lived during the times when Prague Castle was in its heydays. But today, the lesser quarter has a lot to offer and is prime property in Prague. The lesser quarter sits on the left bank, between the Vltava and the Castle District sitting up on the hill. Within its confines you'll find St. Nicholas church - an impressive baroque with a blue dome, the Lennon Wall, several medieval pubs (try U Sedmi svabu) and most of the consulates and embassies. One can also dine at the waterfront restaurants in Kampa Park or at the famous Cafe Savoy. Plan to spend at least half a day within Lesser Quarter.
MUST visit when in Prague. My favourite area of Prague: full of beautiful streets, buildings, nice restaurants and pubs and a bit quieter than the Old Town.
Lots of history here. So many places to explore via its back streets and little squares. Lots of history here and easily accessible by tram and then on foot.
Fun to explore. This was our favorite place to get lost in. Fun to explore streets, little cafes, amazing architecture. Love it.

Nice neighborhood.. Malá Strana is an old neighborhood on the west side of the Vltava River. It is full of charming streets teemed with jewelries selling granate and amber.It is also a necessary passageway for those who plan to visit the Palace Hill and the Monastery.

Get more not less in Lesser Quater. We stayed here and much preferred it to the more touristy and noisy side of the city. Good choice of restaurants and bars enjoyed some lovely meals. Same range of shops smaller and less busy. Not as expensive as Old Town

Beautiful Prague . For most this will be either the start or the end of the walk across Charles Bridge. The lesser town is in my opinion the most interesting to explore. Walks by the river, the myriad of small streets and probably the most beautiful part of town. No matter how many time I have strolled the streets of lesser town I am always left amazed.
Love this area of prague. Loved that one could get off the main tourist streets into such quiet ones so easily. Liked that you could wander for hours and always see something new and interesting.

Our favorite. We also stayed in this section in town and was very pleased by it. There is a bit of tourism so you don't feel bad but its much less crowded and things are a bit slower, more laid back. I also think this side of the Charles Bridge was prettier and cleaner. There are some hills on the back side, but the views are amazing.

Best area in Prague. Favourite part of Prague, nicer than Old and New town. Between the castle on the hill and the river, all the best attractions and two lovely parks. Good eating (pricey) nice shopping and totally walkable.

Get off the beaten path a little. You come off the bridge and step into more tourist madness. But if you go just 1 or 2 blocks you are actually in a real neighborhood. A great place to walk around without getting too far afield.
Winter Wonderland. You could spend your entire break in Prague in this area. It has everything. Restaurants, bars and amazing architecture.

A great way to get your daily exercise!. A must see when visiting Prague, loved wandering around the whole area. Visited on two occasions as the amount of stairs can be a bit tiring if your knees aren't 100%. So much to see and lots of great eateries. We did a do it yourself walk and also a guided tour which put things in better perspective. Amazing architecture also.
My favourite. Is lovely and not quite so crowded as other parts of Prague. Lovely old buildings, and many nice eateries.

Worth a visit - Lots tosee and experience. This quarter is marginally less crowded than the other parts of Prague.Streets worth wandering and there are still restaurants frequented almost exclusively by Czechs.So, make an effort to walk through it and explore.

Nice section of city. Away from crowds.. Very happy with our stay here. Walkable to everywhere. Not as crazy as the other side of the bridge. Located up the hill so nice views of the rest of the city. Be prepared for some steep hills.

A place you get to know if you are in Prague for a few days. You will get to know the streets, stores and eateries well if you stay more that two days in Prague. Walking is the the name of the game and during the week is not very crowded but lots of people on the streets on the weekends. Lots of photo opportunities, lots of shopping and good to simply have a beer and watch the people go by.

Mala Strana -Lesser Quarter Should not be missed. Church of Our Lady Victorious--infant Jesus of Prague was a wonderful experience in Mala Strana ! Also many small local galleries featuring local Czech painters and artists.

Glad we stayed in Lesser Quarter. We stayed here at the foot of the Charles Bridge. Busy with lots of restaurants but not nearly as crowded and frenetic as the Old Town. Kampala Park is on this side of the Bridge. A good peaceful get away from the crowds.

A must see. The narrow alleys could be daunting when you first step into the area but one gets used to it after a while.perfectly safe late in to the night. Excellent nightlife, clubs , pubs, restaurants and just great walking around as well.
Beautiful frescos. Beautiful architecture and frescos. lovely break from the weather if freezing and away from hustle and bustle. Peaceful and breathtaking
Don't miss this. We walked through the town through its charming side streets. Every corner there is something to watch. Shops and cafes are every were.
Also known as "Little Town". It is very beautiful, but it is bettter to stay in Old Town because it has more restaurants, flat streets and easy access to transportation.

Staying in the 'Lesser Quarter'. We stayed in this part of Prague and it is a lot quieter than the Old Town, bur you're right next to the Charles Bridge and all the sights this leads to. There is however plenty to see and do in the Lesser Quarter with some excellent bars, cafes and restaurants to sample as well.

Enjoyable city visit. As with most areas in old Prague a must see the whole of the old town district is worth strolling around with so much to see. Allow yourself half a day just to stroll through and enjoy.
Worth a Walk. We visited this area to have lunch at the Monastery restaurant. The library was closed. I would definitely recommend the restaurant.
Lovely walk. Very different architecture. A nice area to take time to walk this area is not so populated with tourist.

A beautiful area of Prague. Definately include several hours to walk around this beautiful area of Prague. Wandering the streets of this quaint area is very enjoyable. The John Lennon Wall is in this section of Prague. I would not recommend going up the top of St. Nicholas - there are better views of the city else where.
Definitely a walk thru. Worth a walk around if you are in Prague. Totally different from Old Town, if you visit the Monastery and the Castle, finish your visit by walking thru Lesser Quarter.
A pleasant place to take a stroll round. Quite interesting architecture, some nice parks, restaurants and views, worth wandering round on foot if you have time.

Fascinating & beautiful, no $ required to really enjoy yourself. bring good map. Great place to visit - you can enjoy without spending a cent. There are many places to part with your money but it's not necessary. Strongly recommended as part of walking around the city. Bring a good map so you don't get lost.

Gorgeous architechture - great for wandering. After visiting the castle, we spent the afternoon just wandering the streets of Mala Strana. Every turn brought another beautiful building, garden or site into view. It was a fabulous way to spend the afternoon ...definitely wander around to find the John Lennon wall...
Romantic place. Another great place to see in Prague. Romantic narrow streets with cobble stones. Nice shops and restaurant and beautiful architecture.

Trip to the past. Splendid infrastructure, lesser conjuction, and fewer tourists - all the reason to visit this beautyfull part of Prague.
Walk uphill to the Cathedral and enjoy in the magnificent view of the city.

take a stroll around this district. We spent an hour walking around and there are quite a few things to do as well. The buildings are impressive and there are lots of shops, cafes and places to eat. There is a park to the west of the chain bridge where you can just sit as well as the lenin wall and little venice to look at and views of the chain bridge and the river. Make sure you walk around the smaller streets and not just the main ones to have the full experience.

The Street of gold. Our tour guide took us down the 'ruelle d'or' as she called it in French. It was once a row of slums and reputedly the location of 'alchemists' in the middle ages. It was a place where lived Kafka - the literary fellow who is famous for being famous. I was decidedly unimpressed.
Beautiful place, great pictures!. We passed through Mala Strana when going to Prague Castle. It is a beautiful neighborhood, great architecture and a lovely place to take pictures...

Where the main attactions of the city are.. This is a můst see in Prague. It includes Prague Castle, many churches (including the oldest medieval oné), great food and many beautiful parks. There's also several museums.

across the river Moldau. Do not just cross the Carles'bridge and head straight up to the castle.
Take your time to visit the Mala strana area, with many churches and other interesting buildings etc.
Or visit one of the restaurants featuring a view of the Moldau river.

immerse yourself in history. A walk through Mala Strana combines both historical perspective aswell as the opportunity to enjoy a cosmopolitan way of life.Beautifully decorated houses that sometimes contain some small museumor lots of interested small shops with everything from crystals,jewelries to art and an incredible multitude of small, cozyrestaurants or simply nice Slavonic origin treats. Mala Strana is full of alchemist symbols of Rudolph the 2nd's Prague so that in itself it is a trip down the history.I love being a tourist in my own town from time to time and despite the crowds oftourists, Mala Strana is an all time favorite. One thing I wouldntrecommend is Starbucks in that area as it is known in Prague for itspickpockets and its quite dirty + slow and not very courteous service

Far from the maddening crowds. Charming, less crowded area of the city, full of character, bBeautiful architecture, narrow streets, hidden courtyards, and good restaurants. Spent majority of our visit on this side of the Charles Bridge to avoid the crowds.

Great to visit or stay. We loved Mala Strana! We choose to make it the base of our week long stay in Prague. We stayed at the Archibald at the Charles Bridge and found that getting to just about anything we wanted to do in Prague was easy either by walking or public transport. We found that even though it was on "the other side" of river it was less crowded and hectic that Old Town. These is lots to do and see in this part of town. The architecture is varied and stunning. Many churches to see, lots of small shops, and the great Kampa Island Park were all great. Not quite as many good restaurants as in some of the other parts of town but there are great ones here nonetheless. A+

Nice neighborhood to relax after a visit to castle district. Great place to hang around after a visit to castle district (Hradcany). Nice to walk by the Charles bridge and see the art work being sold there, go up the Mala Strana bridge tower for a nice view of the crowd crossing the bridge, go up Nicholas church tower for nice views of the city. The funicular railway takes you to a nice ride up hill. There is a boat stop under the bridge that can take you to a nice relaxed time by the bridges.

Best of the Best. We really enjoyed the Lesser Quarter. It is filled with vendors, restaurants (even a Starbucks), churches etc. The walk from the lesser Quarter and over the Charles Bridge is an adventure.

real surpise. This area is well worth spending a day in. It has some lovely sights to see. Well worth seeing the lennon wall,also the bridge with the padlocks on kampa island. Lovely wall through kampa park.

Much to see. There is so much fun and strange sights to behold in this area. Everyone opts to push their way through the more touristy old town and new town areas across the river but I loved three lesser quarter better!

Charming area of Prague. Charming area of Prague, which is one of the most beautiful cities in Europe (a bit of a secret gem). A bit like a fairytale environment, wonderful for family or romantic visits.

memory lane. Nice place to wander about and just have a stroll , you can see the age old buildings with motifs and paintings on it.
Dont expect to enter the buildings as all have people living in them
Little Quarter BIG return. Absolutely the area to stay in while visiting Prague. It appears a bit less congested with easy access to the Castle grounds.

A quieter, no less interesting part of Prague, best seen on a guided walking tour. Containing many cobbled streets linedcwith attractive period buildings, this area has many "secret" less well known corners which are best discovered by participating in a guided walking tour. Many lunch spots here but avoid at all costs the exploitive tourist trap Restaurant Dvorak (see the many negative reviews, including ours, in the restaurant section).

Great place to stroll around. This is a wonderful area to walk and relax. Lots of restaurants, bars and bakeries. You can sit outside and watch the world go round. Lots of great attractions including the John Lennon Wall. Follow the canal for a more relaxing walk.
Lovely Neighborhood Across the River from Old Town. We stayed here, it's much quieter than old town but still has many old buildings and a lot of history everywhere. Perfect place to stay in.
Coffee Breaks essential in Prague - a lot of walking.. Everywhere you walk is amazing to see so much. Under every little arch you will find a really nice coffee shop and all is so cheap.

So nice . It's a place that oozes character and takes you back to years gone by. Sometime very crowded but there's no surprise in that as the area is so attractive.
Sadly theres plenty of the "kiss me quick" type shop but also some really nice souvenir shops too which makes it worth it.
Lovely part of Prague. This part of Prague hides a lot of nice attractions, shops and restaurants. Don't miss John Lennon wall or Kafka museum.

Hate the name, but love the area.. The name incites that it is somewhat lesser than other areas, but not so. Just like any area of Prague, it's all beautiful. Lots of shopping and right around the corner from Wenceslas Square.

Interesting area!. Plenty to see and do all around this area! In fact wear your most comfy shoes everywhere you go in Prague.......so much to see by just walking everywhere! This area is no exception with loads going on morning, noon and night!

Amazing views. My favourite place in PRG.
Full of great restaurants with good food and beer.
Architesture of buildings is spectacular.

Lesser Prague - worth the visit!. Less popular than the Old Town - but actually more interesting, and much quieter and less congestive. Lots of great restaurants - and there's the castle and the Petrin Tower - worth visiting.
A lovely walk. We enjoyed strolling around the streets. Prague has a rich history and the architecture is worth the effort of the walk.
What a great place. Definitely worth taking a look here. Not as crowded and just as much on offer if not more. Another side of Prague worth seeing

The Castle Return Jewel. Well, after a tram ride from downtown to the Castle Prague, here's a great suggestion afterward: walk down the hill to the wonderful Lesser Quarter Square and spend some leisure time sitting outside with a coffee or a great Czech Pilsner and watch the people and admire the marvelous architecture...then walk back across the Charles Bridge before hopping on a downtown tram or walking back to your destination. Such a great break in the action. Enjoy the day!!!

One of Prague's beautiful districts.. This is a walking city! Meander around the cobble stoned streets. Even though there are tons of people walking around, there are still plenty of quiet spots to discover.

Very Beautiful and relaxing. Good to place to meander and take in the ambience. Beautiful buildings, all ancient, but well maintained. Stylish architecture all around. Amazing sculptures and paintings on buildings. Very pleasant.

Good place to stay. I loved it here, right beside the Charles Bridge with the Old Town just the other side. It has its' own life and feel with fewer crowds than other parts but plenty of good things going on.
Interesting. Went to Lesser Town to see the John Lennon wall.. Wow, was fabulous.. Surprising how it's taken off and been added too
Worth walking through. A beautiful shopping area where you can roam the streets and alleys looking at old architecture and cute shops.
Attractive area on the left bank of the river.. Many attractive building, all very ornate. There are many interesting shops, churches and gardens in the area.

Amazing. One more must in Prague. I recommend to visit it after Prague Castle. Visit the church of St Nicolas, biggest baroque church in Prague. It is truly amazing. Then go through Prokopska str to the Lennon wall, which holds an amazing story. Do not miss a walk through Kampa. We went along the river to Most Legii and then over Masarykovo Nabrezje to Dancing House. Mala Strana might not be the best thing in Prague, but sure not to be missed. You can even climb by funicular from Ujezd to Petrin to the Petrin Hill where are the observatory, rose garden and famous Petrin Hill looktower. Middle station, Nebozizek has an amazing cheap restaurant with an amazing view of Prague.
Don't Be Overrun!. Less pack, the Lesser Quarter is more manageable and more beautiful in my eyes as you can enjoy all the architecture and the buildings spared by the war
A Perfect Location. We stayed in the Lesser Quarter and were delighted with our decision as it was peaceful and away from the madding high season tourists, yet extremely easy to walk everywhere.

Nice part of Prague. In centre of the Prague just behind Charles Bridge...very nice quarter with lots of restaurants and things to...just avoid typical tourist traps as overpriced restaurant when they will try to charge you 150 CZK for a beer as you can easily can get it for like 35 CZK.

Favorite Setting For Movies & Commercials. Lesser Quarter are the clusters of buildings & amenities around the foothills of Prague castle.I found it very picturesque with ancient Burgher houses,quaint side streets,international embassies housed in wonderful boroque houses & above all its primary landmark, the St Nicholas church.No wonder that over times it has become a favorite setting for movies & commercials.At its heart is the Malostanske Square.We loved strolling on its cobbled streets with small shops to browse,churches to admire,pubs & restaurants to gulp down some Czech beer & enjoy the fine views across the river.I specially loved wandering around the lantern lit nearly deserted lanes at night which turned out to be delightful experience of the older,golden period of Prague.There are some lovely palaces like the Smiricky & Wellenstein (Converted in to Czech Senate) with its lovely gardens still open to public free with its eye catching limestone grotto at the back.There are other beautiful gardens like the Palace gardens which are a series of elegant,terraced gardens.Vrtba is a lovely boroque garden.The other major attractions here are the Church of our Lady Victorious with its tiny wax doll,considered as Holy Infant;& visited by pilgrims from Spain & Italy.Lennon`s Peace Wall,Kempa park & Museum & NE Kempa,the tiny lanes to the Vitava river for some magnificent views of the Charles Bridge & Old Town Hall.

My favourite area of Prague. Beutiful area full of restaurants and shops slightly nicer than the old town which are more tourist. Great restaurants as well I would particularly recommend "the Alchemist", very reasonably priced for good food (Italian though not czech) and has a beautiful garden.

Great area to walk about. Walk down from the castle to this quarter, it is a short downhill walk & if walking down via Nerudova, you get to see all the interesting houses and sculptures on them. Then after crossing it, you can walk to the Charles Bridge and across it to the other side.

Explore a quieter part of Prague. Much quieter than old town, with plenty more to explore. Great hotels at a cheaper price than other areas. Food and drink a little cheaper on the back streets than in main areas of Prague.

Better bargains for your souvenirs. There are lots of tiny cafes, shops that worth visiting here. Charles Bridge is just minutes away. Stroll along the cobblestoned road and hunt for better bargains (garnet, wooden toys, crystals)
Lesser Quarter. We really did enjoy walking through this area. Quaint and more of the true feeling of Prague. One of my favorites places here.

Not as crowded as Stare Mesto but worth more than a glance. It is easy to walk around the center par of Mala Strana. Malostranske Namesti (city sqaure) is easily reachable by tram, e.g. tram 22. There is a minimart a few steps from the tram stop where it is easy to be tram and metro tickets and get cold drinks. The tram stop is also close to the end of the Charles Bridge and St Nicholas church and the street up towards the castle, if you choose to take a rising street thru the diplomatic area.

Don't overlook this part. I think this area gets overshadowed by other parts of the city, but it is a wonderful place to wonder and explore. Very different feeling at night compared to in the day. Find a guide to bring it to life.

Romantic and picturesque. A very good place to take your time and wander around. Slightly less crowded than the old town and the Castle area. Plenty of nice watering holes when you want to take a break. Superb achitecture and nice churches.

Packed during the day, quiet at night. We stayed here for four days, and found that even though the streets were packed during the day, at 6-7 at night, everyone went away and we could freely roam, looking for someplace to eat. Probably because pretty much everything in Prague closes at 6pm. Still, this is a very pretty area, situated right below the castle, and a little ways away from the Old Town. No problem finding places to eat here, though finding a good one with reasonable prices can be a challenge!

A less crowded-peaceful place. It is one of the district of Prague which clusters around the foot hills of the Prague Castle. The cobbled street has some Baroque churches ,many small souvenier shops, local pubs and restaurants one would like to spend time in savouring the local cuisine. A much quieter area, away from the hustle-bustle of the old town.
Beautiful place. The architecture is stunning and extremly well locked after. The place has to many tourist shops and missing genuine Prague/Czeck shops and food alternatives.

A lovely area.. Pretty cobbled streets, cosy intimate restaurants, lots of green space and peace and quiet-if you want it. Ideal location to stay (away from the melee) but close enough to all the action; this area has it all!

Quiet, romantic, safe, yet in the centre!. A must go, while being in Prague! You will explore Prague from a completely different prospective! Here, you have 2-3 streets, which are the main tourist sightseeing routes, just around a corner you will find empty narrow street with a winery, cafe, traditional czech pub, garden restaurant.
a great place to eat in Prague. Just off the end of the Charles Bridge and below the Prague Castle, the Mala Strana is full of shops and restaurants, including the Lennon Wall and the John Lennon Pub

More not less!. Very up market restaurants at great prices. Mexican good amongst others. Small canals-Venice like with many hand craft shops. A lot of atmosphere in this area. It should be renamed Morer Quarter.
Lovely . After a long day at the castle,part of the city is just the right place to cool off from the heat and enjoy a drink. Not crowded at all.

Wonderful wandering. Probably my favorite place in Prague...ok, I have lots of favorites over the past 7 years...but Mala Strana's side streets, alleys, and passageways are a delight to meander around in to soak up the atmosphere and make pleasant discoveries along the way. There actually are some quiet streets with few if any shops that give you a very personal feel of going back in time. And you can risk looking up to appreciate architectural fine points without being run over by crowds. :)
Away from the crowds, peaceful and pretty. This area is a bit quieter and has lots of interesting hidey holes, which is brilliant for photographers!
beautiful. quiet and beautiful. we loved the parks and the streets of this part of prague. it is less crowded as the main parts of old town

Very interesting area to visit. Malá Strana is one of Prague's most historic regions. It housesa large number of noble palaces (mostly German and Italian). Baroque architecture dominated when the style became successfully implanted on Malá Strana after the district was devastated by fires in 1541. The most notable building is the Wallenstein Palace. The most prominent church is the St. Nicholas Church. The famous statue of the Jesus of Prague is in the Church of Our Lady Victorious.

Its so lovely to see tiny streets. Its so amazing to walk thru those streets. Those tiny streets are lovely. Every corner has a cafe or every basement has a pub and etc. The way they built buildings is cool. It also gives you good feelings to walk thru those streets. Streets looks same and its easy to get lost.
We loved that part of Prague. Beautiful part of the old town. We loved its streets, parks, the bank of the river of Vltava. I recommend it

A tower visit is a great way to see the city. We went up in the tower, since is just outside our hotel, and though you have to climb many steps, it is a cool place to be on an August day. The history is everywhere you turn, and the view is spectacular.There are shops selling everything you could want, and restaurants of every nationality.

Historic area at the feet of the castle. Mala Strana is the lower part of the castle area, with numerous cozy restaurants, bars, hotels and traditional Czech houses. Just cross the Charles Bridge from the Old Town and you will find yourself in the middle of Mala Strana. If wandering around, undoubtedly you will run into one of the stairs leading up to the castle district.

Very pretty. Very picturesque especially if you venture off the main streets, lots of cafes and gift shops. Main parts are very crowded as it is the main route off of Charles Bridge and to/from the castle for pedestrians.

Walk in the steps of Mozart and Kafka. We walked over the Charles Bridge to the Lesser Quarter and walked the streets where .mozart had wandered. The fascinating Kafka Museum is close by and there are waterside restaurants overlooking the Vltava.

Best area of Prague. We stayed here in the Mala Strana and thought it was the best place in the city! You can be anywhere in just a few minutes walk, but the area is not as crowded as on the other side of the Charles Bridge. Even though it's not called the Old Town, this is an incredibly historic area of the city. The area is full of cafes and restaurants that, while they depend on tourists, are not tourist traps. Great food and drinks at great prices. The architecture here is amazing. I recommend the Nicholas Hotel Residence right in the middle of the square.

Lesser known must visit in Prague.... Kampa Island is not to be missed place in Prague, Great place to walk with many eating joints around...Start from Charles bridge and it is exactly at the foot of the castle. Very scenic place and highly recommended.
Nice buildings and not too long walk to castle Hradcany. Excellent walk towards the castle Hradczany. You can see nice old buildings on the way and it is very close to Karluv Most (Charles Bridge)
Not to be missed!. Prague is an easy city to walk when the weather is great. The Mala Strana lies right below Castle Hill where the architecture reminds one of old town Prague.

Lovely. Mala strana is really lovely place, with many good restaurants... Moreover its not so overcrowded as Old town, what makes it more attractive :) u can have a walk starting at Charles Bridge, via Mala Strana up to Castle...

The "other side of the river", from the Old Town and definitely worth visiting.. The "other side" of the river and over the Charles Bridge from Prague's old town. Not quite as pretty and traffic free as the old town, but still highly atmospheric. It also has the Kafka Museum that is worth visiting and is at the foot of the "Castle" which is must see for Prague.

Nice road for a stroll and shopping. According to our guide, there is a never ending debat between supporters of old town and lesser town. In our case old town with its numerous beautiful buildings and flair wins hands down. This place is a good road to walk around though.

The Place to Visit. Often relegated to second place by the Old Town Square, the Lesser square has a wealth of cafes, restaurants, pubs, interesting shops and lovely architecture which is so plentiful in Prague. The side streets are quiet but house some fine eating places. Perhaps the best way to visit the Mala Strana is to visit Prague castle quite early one morning and then walk all the way down the winding streets and drop into the Mala Strana and spend the afternoon there. Then cross Charles Bridge late in the evening and be struck by the compelling views and end up in one of the streets off Old Town square for dinner. On our next visit to Prague will stay in the Mala Strana, close to the river and then indulge in the revelry of the Old Town square as and when needed!

An interesting part of town, quieter and less touristy. we stayed in this part of town and it was lovely. lots of cafes and restaurants and plenty to see but not quite as frantic as other parts of town. if I returned I'd stay here again.

Went to the apothecary. I went to the apothecary here and got some medicine we had not been able to find elsewhere, so the shopping possibilities are endless. Just strolling around the old streets is a museum in itself.

Beautiful for a walk. Loved the gardens of the palaces.. We started our walk at the Malostranska Metro station, saw the gardens of the Wallenstein palace, walked past the Renaissance houses on Nerudova, saw the gardens of the Vrtbov palace (hard to find but worth the search) and saw the church of St Nicolas and of Little Jesus of Prague. The first part of the walk until the end of Nerudova is a steep climb but after that it is an easy walk down.
A complete gem!. An equally beautiful part of the city but much quieter and less touristy. Food and drink was much better value here than in the Old Town and well worth making the effort to visit.

Better than the Old Town!. The Old Town in Prague is the city's highlight for many tourists, but Mala Strana is equally interesting. It's less popular, so you don't have too elbow your way through the crowds all the time, and it gives you more authentic experience of the real Prague. There are a lot of things too enjoy - the architecture, small, cozy streets, nice cafes, restaurants and bars, the famous Lennon Wall, Petrin Hill, Kampa park and modern art museum... One of my favourite parts of the city.

Charming. Very charming part of Prague next to Vltava river. Full of history, charming old architecture, very calm with restaurants that offer traditional czech food. Great place to go for a walk and museums.

better than Old Town for atmosphere - do Petrin Hill in the morning and afternoon here.. imagine the Old Town but tighter, decidedly less crowded and over-the-top touristy, with more of a 'local' vibe - perfect for a leisurely ramble. Ideal to visit after strolling up and down Petrin Hill.
Don't miss. I still don't know why they call this the lesser quarter, because it is just as lovely as the rest of the city. Great shops and wonderful architecture. Much to see.
Love it. A collection of beautful buildings and churches, restaurants and places to visit. Really local atmosphere.

Cool and funky energy. The Old Town is wonderful, but the Mala Strana is absolutely my favorite part of the city. I loved the winding streets, the little hideaway restaurants, the generally funky vibe of the area. Might actually even be an interesting place to live if you're on a tucked away side street away from the crowds.
Historic and beautiful. Hilly but a great part of Prague just over the river from the old town. Historic and beautiful with winding roads and stairways.

Bohemian.... This area of prague is seemingly devoid of the change stores, souvenir shops and western fast food joints you see across in the old town. (and to be fair, those weren't as bad as expected). But the Mala Strana seems to have more authentic street cafes , picturesque yet old buildings and architecture, interesting shops and a really cool market under the Charles bridge. Worth walking around here. The river cafes you eventually come to are well situated with nice views, but the prices reflect that, in contrast to those a few streets away...

Love this area.. I love to come to Prague just to visit place's like this that are alive , vibrant and busy.MALA STRANA (lesser quarter,little square) is such an area.During the day it's busy as it's on some great tram route's,and has some wonderful tourist site's close by such as ST NICHOLAS CHURCH ( KOSTEL SV MIKULASE ) and ST THOMAS CHURCH ( KOSTEL SVATEHO TOMASE ) plus there are many pub's,bar's and restaurant's here and close by such as my favourite's U HROCHA,U MALEHO GLENA,J.J MURPHY'S IRISH PUB,JO's and many more .Later at night the area has a much more chilled out feel to it,less crowd's and a lovely atmosphere.Very easy to get to ,jump tram's 12.20.22.57. or 91 to MALASTRANSKA NAMESTI drop's you off in the heart of this area.If you enjoy taking photo's go at night as some of the building's look magical at night.A must go destination on any trip to Prague.
Quiet area. Quieter than the Old town square but quaint with sidewalk cafes and good restaurants. The famous John Lennon wall is in this area.

Small sized quarter of Prague but full of history. Different perspective of history away from the Old Town, as this neighborhood was sort of "isolated" from the happenings at the other side of the Vltava River. History includes how houses were "numbered" based on the symbols atop of their main doors, the apartment where Franz Kafka lived, were 27 citizens were executed because of their Protestant faith. Must see.

I'd choose this place to live. This is lovely section of town and the John Lennon wall is here along with museums and a park and restaurants. The square of our hotel is where a scene was shot from Mission Impossible. When we visited there was a French fair going on with several booths, live music and wonderful booths serving French food. Chacuterie with a glass of wine for 5 euros and great breads and desserts and lavender and all things French. There is a children's museum. We were just a block from the Charles Bridge. If you want more action and noise, stay in the old town. If you like a bit of quiet and a real neighborhood, this is wonderful place to relax.

PREKRASNA MALA STRANA!!!!!! Amazing!!!!. It may be called the lesser quarter but it is anything but! this part of prague has so much to offer. So much history, restaurants and sights to see! Not to mention the beauty of it all!!!

Just wander around!. We visited the Infant of Prague in the Church of St. Mary the Victorious, a very Baroque Carmelite church, in the Little Quarter. This neighborhood is a little quieter than many other heavily-touristed parts of Prague, with little shops and restaurants in a historic ambiance.

Somewhat away from the summer hordes. I stayed in a flat in Mala Strana, and appreciated that the streets quieted down after 10 p.m., and that we had some peace and quiet in the mornings. There's so much to do and see over on this side of the river too!

An important part of Praque to visit full of history.. The city is made up of mainly three areas and The Lesser Quarter is one of them. It is called this because it is younger than the Old Town Area and thought to be less important but in my opinion it is just as interesting. Interesting when part of the 4 hour walking tour.
Great place to stay. This, in my opinion is the best place to stay in Prague. It is close to everything yet you don't have the noise 24/7 like in the center of town.

Nice Refuge from the Crowds. After crossing the Charles Bridge the crowds seem to magically vanish into Mala Strana, which we found to be a wonderful respite from the thundering hoards of tour groups who always seem to be chasing an umbrella waving leader, ready to trample all who get in their path. The park is a nice place to picnic or simply enjoy the view from this side of the river. Ample restaurants are around to quench your thirst with a cold Pilsner. Very quaint and much more relaxed than Old Town.

Discovered by accident. Found it on the last night of a 4 day trip by seeing the overhead arch. This gave us a change of pace from the busy Main Street by the open square. We passed some interesting pubs and a sex museum. A little less crowded them the usual thorough fair.

Quiter part of city. We stayed in this part of the city and loved it, not quite as busy once you get off of Charles Bridge, quieter in evenings but very close to all attractions, metro and tram stops nearby but you don't need to use these as everywhere is within walking distance - after walking around Prague we were very glad we chose this area, very clean, quiet at night and safe with beautiful buildings, much much nicer than the new town area in our opinion, perfect for coupleas and families.

You!ll need to be fit. Just over Charles Bridge is very very busy but then everyone seems to disappear as the Lesser Quarter seems to be much quieter and traffic almost non existent, you can take your time to just wander. You'll need to be fit though as the hill up to the Caste is quite steep.

Check out the John Lennon wall- and the John Lennon pub!. Perhaps my favourite part of Prague. Quieter than the rest of the city, beautiful arches, beautiful churches, riverside walks, and access to the John Lennon Wall and pub. What's not to like?
