The most romantic part of Prague. Mala Strana is by far the most romantic part of Prague.It is less noisy and crowded then the other embankment, particularly the Old Town. It is the quarter when once nobility was living so you can find here beautiful palaces and lovely gardens. The true gems of Mala Strana are St.Nicholas Church and the Baroque Vrtba garden. If you prefer small hotels with personal atmosphere and historical background Lesser Town is the best place to stay overnight too.

Wonderful Neighbourhood. I stayed in this area and it has great restaurants, Lokal in particular serving up local cuisine and beer for great prices (€8 for the most expensive main). Vinograph a local wine bar was also superb. Some lovely parks including Kampa park are well worth a visit. Nice bars, shops and well worth visiting.

Oasis of calm in a hectic touritic city!!. Don't forget to find Kampa....an oasis of quiet and simplicity in the midst of the busy city. The old grist mill...the charming houses in a rainbow of colors....just perfect!!! There's a beautiful park tucked away near the Vlatava river...a great picnic destination!!
Less of a tourist trap than the Old Town Square. Less spectacular than the Old Town, and on a much smaller scale, but still very attractive and more genuine. Well worth the tram trip.
Very Interesting. We hired a vintage car to drive around this area. It was well worth it as the architecture is a treat.

Great Atmosphere...!!!. A great place to visit and in the middle between the Prague Castle and Karluv Most bridge, this is a beautiful area of steep streets, small alleys and great cafes. Everything its well maintain with lovely colorful buildings and lots of gothic and baroque details everywhere. A great place to get lost to see the true Prague.

Cobbled streets, sights and Petrin Hill. This felt like Prague should, you are slightly away from the very busy areas but plenty to see and take in. e..g St Nicholas Church and the square. There are also the free Waldstein gardens and Petrin Hill is nearby, not massive but a pleasant change from the cobbled streets. You get great views of the river and old town too, especially from Prague Castle and Petrin Hill (If you climb the tower). Prague Castle is reveiwed elsewhere. Sometimes it is good to get away from all the entertainment (especially on Charles Bridge or in Old Town), I kept thinking lesser town, e.g around Bretislavoa and Trziste would make an excellent film set with narrow cobbled streets and few cars (but no photos near the american Embassy).Cannot think of anything to dislike.

The infant Jesus of Prague. The infant Jesus of Prague is in this lesser quarter called Mala Strana. It is more a pilgrimage site. People from all over the world come to pay homage to the infant Jesus . It is a pity thou that the church has become more of a museum rather than a place of worship. A must see on your bucket list if you are from the catholic faith

Mala Strana, Prague. Great location at the foot of the Prague Castle and walls. A lot of small shops and steep cobble streets that gives it interest. Busy area with a lot of touristic attractions and restaurants. Great public transportation and many bridges to access the old and new towns.
Walk around. Walk around Mala Strana and discover the parks with hidden animals. You can eat at very nice restaurants that offer the typical Czech food for an affordable price
narrow streets at its best!. I really enjoyed strolling around Mala Strana discovering all of its beautiful streets. All the historical buildings are so pretty!

Prague Lesser Quarter. What a great area to visit while in Prague. Certainly a different feel that the usual hustle of tourist. Very quaint. Discover this area early in your trip by visiting a wine bar or walking the beautiful streets.
Lesser Quarter worth checking out. I really enjoyed exploring the Lesser Quarter. The architecture is beautiful and it was filled with interesting landmarks and nice little restaurants.
Beautiful walk on a Sunday morning. Best to go for a walk on a Sunday morning before the crowds build up to have the beatiful parts of Prague all to yourself

Great area with easy access to the Old Town via Charles Bridge. Quiet area with great history and some beautiful restaurants.
A great place to stay or explore if you are in Prague. Especially good area for
reasonable but very beautiful hotels and quiet in the evenings.

Mala Strana. We liked this area best.It feels more authentic.Less touristy at the time.Maybe winter time.The day seems to pass away so quickly....stopped whenever we felt tired to have a coffee or beer.

A calmer section of Prague. There are many beautiful art nouveau buildings on narrow cobble stone streets in this area. One of its most famous landmark is the John Lennon Wall. There are also many good small restaurants and cafés. This is best if you have extra time to roam around for low key site-seeing and taking beautiful photos.
Nice to walk around. Well-maintained, clean and picturesque area. Easy to walk around, also convenient for solo travelers

Away from the day-trippers at last!. A beautiful area of Prague, away from the main town, and the bustle of the Charles bridge, this is a delightful area. Full of lovely little shops and bars and restaurants, it was a pleasure to walk around and get a feeling of the Prague where Czech people live in. Simply super.
Crowded but impressive. It is different from all the other towns that I've been before. It is full of color, joy and history all together.

Walking into another world. There was so much to see and do. And it was all very authentic. We particularly liked all of the art galleries and the marionette stores that were in this area. They had interesting souvenirs and were far more interesting than the numerous souvenir shops in the middle of town.

Dosen't Worth It. nothing to see, a lot to walk, doesn't worse you time or strength.
there are better places in the city to see

Just get lost. Perfect place for getting lost in Prague. Not so crowed as other touristic places, but still as charming and "historical" as the rest. Beautiful to walk through if your traveling with your significant other

A less crowded version of Old Town. If you want a break from the crowds in Old Town or Hradcany, take a walk around Mala Strana. St. Nicholas is a great place to hear a concert (or just to see the Baroque interior and organ). The Kafka Museum is worth a visit as well.

Best part of Prague. A great neighourhood less touristy with a lot less crowds can stroll the streets and feel safe and will be away from the noise of the city but only minutes away from its centre. The area is full of embassies and the castle is situated here. Full of great restaurants and bars

if you would like to see Prague.. a must do. A must do if you like walking.. Cross over Charles bridge and contine to walk- you will see all those smaller roads, with a lot of shops, restarurants, terrasses.. perfect way to taste the old Prague :-)

Charming and lovely local neighbourhood. We stayed in a boutique hotel in Mala Strana, and we were so happy with our choice. Mala strana is a lovely local neighbourhood with a lot less crowds, and has such a lovely European charm! I enjoyed staying in this area and being here everyday because we were so close to Charles bridge and the centre, but we were still away from the noise and touristy areas. The neighbourhood has amazing local restaurants and pubs, and such gorgeous shops with antiques, jewellery, bakeries, it reminds me of the local neighbourhoods in other European cities such as St.Germain in Paris. Of course there are tourist attractions such as St. Nicholas Church and Petrin Hill, it is still lovely!
Walking tour. It's one of the best place to walk, it's very pleasent and calm area to walk and it have so many history.
Golden Prague. Vibrant and beautiful city, Didn't like the crowd but enjoyed beautiful weather. Prague Old Town architecture really is picturesque and attractive.
Great place to stay. Quiet compared to the Old Town which we liked. There are tourists going up to the Castle area but not as many as some other areas. Historic architecture everywhere. Beautiful.
Great Area to Stay. Beautiful area, close to all the sights and has a wonderful park that hosts concerts and different activities there
Beautiful Area to walk. I love this area. It remains the old neighborhoods atmosphere. Lots of small shop and interesting boutiques stores. You can easily spend three/four hours here.

Mala Strana still charming. The old buildings, churches and brewery restaurants are still as authentic and fun to visit as ever. Lots of new roads and parking around the castle complex - crowd control that was probably needed but makes it seem a little too much like a theme park.

Favourite area of Prague. If you've had enough of the tourists in the Old Town then wander over the Charles Bridge to The Lesser Town (Malá Strana). Here you can escape the crowds by heading into the hills or go and sample some of the excellent monastery beers. You'll also find great cafes and restaurants here, along with the English language bookshop, Shakespeare and Sons. Love this side of Prague.
Old world charm.. Great place to just walk around and enjoy the old buildings and restaurants, imagining what the lifestyle was like once.
The most beautiful part of Prague. Cross the Charles bridge and head up towards the Castle through the beautiful streets of Lesser Town, you will not be disappointed by it's beauty.

Calm and beautiful. In many ways better than the Old Town district, Mala Strana is far more calm and somewhat less touristy.
The cobblestone streets are tighter and more winding. Many points of interest as well as good dining options.
Take your time to wander the area, spend a day at least, it's worth it!

Like stepping back in time 500 years. Remove the cars, street signs and tourists and you'd think you had stepped back in time. The Old City (other side of the bridge) has more hotels and typical outdoor cafes but this Quarter is even more reminiscent of medieval days. It is on a hill, leading up to the Castle district; the hill is very steep; On a hot day I did not want to walk it. But Tram 22 takes you up. Catch it in the main square, after buying a Return Ticket from the machine at the Tourist Info center. (about 50 Krowns). Worth taking a half day to explore this area; put away the map and just get lost. (As long as you know where the river is, you will easily find your way back to it, and hence to the bridge.)

Nice neighbourhood. Mala Strana is a nice neighbourhood in Prague. I recommend having a walk here, visiting some of the restaurants or petite shops. There is a WWII memorial in a small park which is quite interesting.

Love!. I didn't want to leave Prague to begin with - this is a must-see city! The hotel I stayed at was located in the Lesser Quarter and my husband and I spent an entire afternoon wandering around the quaint, delicious streets. Give yourself some time, try not to have much of an agenda, and just enjoy what the area has to offer.
Take your time wandering around. Very beautiful, worth a visit for the very pretty architecture. I would take your time wandering around this area.
Busy busy. a great place to soak up the atmosphere and just people watch. A nice place to grab a bite to eat. Plenty of little souvenir shops around.

Sometimes "Less-er" is More. After crossing the vendor-filled Charles Bridge, you'll probably find this slower-paced area is a welcome respite. Charm still abounds, as do small restaurants that are a great place to sit and talk. The shops are also there, if that's what you're looking for. Yes, there are fewer historical sites, so you still need to cross back over the bridge for some things.
prague mala strana. we stayed on both sides of the river at the beginning and at the end in mall strana the quieter side to so for night life had to cross the charles bride

Good place to take a break. Step down from the Charles Bridge and find an altogether quieter but still interesting area to explore. Buy a drink and baguette and sit and watch the world go by. Wander around and come across gems like the Wallenstein Gardens and the Church of St Nicholas.

The place to stay. If you have the chance to rent an apartment tomstay in Prague, this is the neighbothood you need to choose. Central but non messy or noisy, bohemien but quiet, near the river, with good restaurants and well served by public transport, near enough to reach nove mesto and stare mesto on foot, you can even get to josefov walking if you wanted to.
Less overcrowded than the Old Town. This part of town was quieter and less crowded. Take the time to explore this section of town on your way to the castle.

worth a visit. Its a good area where all they have maintained the architecture of all the building. We visited Petrin Tower known as younger sister of Eiffel Tower that is okay but due to rain & wind we didn't enjoy here much but worth going. There was no one around to guide how to go there you can climb up or go by Funicular rail. We did it by funicular the fare was included in the metro ticket

A Little Quieter than The Old Town. Great parks and a little less crowded than the Old Town side of the river......a must see! There are loads of cafes and plenty of places to sit and relax. Don't miss the Lennon Wall

Scenic quieter section of Prague. It was great visiting the St Nicholas's church at Malostranske Namesti. Visited the Via musical shop for theatre tickets. Climbed up Nerudova to the Prague castle. Amazing David Wallenstein' garden at Malostranske. Don't forget to visit Petrin hill to see the gardens and observatory.
Hidden treasures. Crowded place but very nice. Take our time, look around and you will notice wonderful "jewels" in this small square. :)
mala strana. Cheaper food in this area as it's our of the way compared to the usual spots. Worth a look to get our of the tourist areas.

Wander. I enjoyed wandering around Mala Strana, to see its historical buildings, walk down a little street, find a little restaurant or cafe, and just be in this part of town. It is easy to get to with the trams. This is an area that isn't big on famous landmarks, but it is definitely a beautiful place to spend some time.
Okay for a stroll. Some cute cafe's in the area. If you are short on time, I would skip this section of the city. Compared to other landmark locations, there wasn't much to see or do.

Malá Strana ( literally English : Lesser Town) is one of the oldest districts of Prague.. The 17th century St. Nicholas Church is considered one of the most important baroque buildings in the city. The Lobkowicz Palace built in the early 18th century is one of the most famous baroque buildings in the city. In many of the older buildings in this district the embassies of many nations are housed. The district is also the main location of the Czech Museum of Music and the Museum Kampa .

Nice place. It's a vary nice & vital quarter.. It's very accessible from many places in Prague, many trams, buses pass by Mala Strana, from here you can walk to Charles bridge then to old town.. Prague is a very easy city to walk around.
Steep climb. We had to walk to the top as for 2 days the funicular railway was not running. Good bar with fantastic views halfway up. Nice gardens at the top.

Lesser Town it may be,but it ain,t "Lesser" tourists..... The #22 bus goes right through here and you will probably see a lot of it on your way to and from the Castle and the Royal Summer House; but it is worth a few hours to wander around the area cause it is very pleasing to the eye. Maybe when you walk across Charles Bridge, you continue on through the "Lesser" area and return via the Legionaru Bridge; or the other way around, if you are staying on the Castle side of the city. Tip; stay on the #22 bus right to the end and you will see Prague surburban life and at the Terminus, walk 100 metres further on and look at the ancient Monastery [ hopefully it is open ] called Poutni Cesta Hajko which is one of the few "Pilgrimage" churches and Stations of the cross, surviving in the old Communist Bloc; stations are set two kms apart and are being restored by the Government and assistance from the EU . Locals still attend their services here and it is quite atmospheric.
Just Get Lost. Explore the many small streets and sites -- grab a drink at a local pub/eatery and take your time exploring. Fun to walk around and see the many things that make Prague a destination.

Best part of town. Compared to the central old town on the other end of the Charles bridge, the Mala Strana is much more relaxed and not so crowded. And the old town style seems even better preserved here than in central Praha. There are parks where one can relax, and more than necessary of good restaurants and cafees.

Beautiful. We stayed in the Mala Strana and found it beautiful. The walk to the castle through it is a treat, if you don't mind the hill. There are lovely old buildings with iron signs. It is just a short walk to the Charles Bridge.

Lesser only in name. What a fabulous place to stay in Prague . Our hotel was located in the lesser town and it was a perfect fit for us . The castle and cathedral are on the Lesser Town side . Easy to walk to , although there were quite a few stairs. The Lesser town is close to the Charles Bridge , Kafka Museum too . While walking through the Lesser town one afternoon we noticed a doorway through which people were entering and exiting . My hubby suggested we check it out . To our delight we discovered the Senate gardens . It was a gorgeous little jewel of a place. The gardens were gorgeous and well maintained. Would recommend it . The Castle and Cathedral are also a must on your have to go places. You have incomparable views of the whole of Prague from atop the hill . The castle has beautiful spaces and gardens which you could spend a day roaming through .The cathedral is gorgeous but very busy with tourists , we much preferred roaming though the International gardens and eventually ending up in a park which took us back to the old town .The Lennon tribute wall is a fun place to visit . Great , colorful photo opportunities . We were lucky to be there when the Prague "Rent" cast did a video promo at the wall . It added to the great vibe of the place. Kafka's museum was more serious and dark but an interesting place to visit . Lots to do and see in Lesser Town ! Best place to stay in my opinion . Our stay at the Aria hotel was sublime !

Lesser correctly named. While a pleasant walk through there are few things here to see. Lennon's wall and the Charles Bridge area are two. Otherwise shops, bars etc. Not as pretty as the other side of the river.
Very interesting area. We walked through this area with a guide after visiting the Prague Castle. Very interesting tour, worth doing or you could manage it on your own. We are retired travellers.
Touristy. Many tourist shops, easy to look past it as you make your way to the castle district. Take time out to walk through and head towards Petrin hill and Wallenstein Palace gardens.

many tourist shops. A good place to find postcards, souvenirs and a few travel necessities. Some folk bought bread and food for simple meals. Stately government buildings (like Embassies, the Parliament).
Something special. Beautiful and genuinely special, think goth meets 22ct gold or go for the atmosphere alone and stunning photographs

Don't miss this part of town. It might be easy to overlook this part of Prague as you go between the Castle district and the Old Town, but I like it. There are lots of places to eat and drink and the whole area is far less busy than the Old Town. Make sure you go into the Wallenstein gardens where you'll find a remarkably green oasis ... and it's usually peaceful there.
Nice to wander. This area is full of quaint hotels bars, restaurants , shops buskers and highly recommended to take a wander

Beautiful and surprising.. Great area to explore. Many governmental buildings and embassies there. On top of it the presidential palace with Lobkowicz museum and beautiful church. Views of Prague amazing!
Great if you forget the car traffic. There are marvelous streets and houses, but also too many cars with reckless drivers going through and through...

Mala Strana. Though quite hilly, there are many better restaurants and shopping than old town. Best to traverse by taxi or tram. Hotels here are relatively inexpensive, and the restaurants are fabulous. Best area for shopping.

I miss it already. Beautiful. We spent two days at the other side of the bridge, in and around Wenslisas Square, the newtown and the old town square which while amazing were very different from this side of the bridge. The pace seems a little slower on this side. We saw the graffiti wall, visited the castle and dined over here- spending the day and evening there in fact. Well worth the time.

Visit to Church of Child Jesus of Prague. Stop 8 on the Hop On/Off bus. The small statue of the Christ Child is in the Catholic Church of Our Lady Victorious of the Carmelite Order. It is said that the statue once belonged to Saint Theresa of Avila. Adjacent to the Church is a shop that sells religious articles that can be taken to the friars in the church to be blessed.

The Lesser Quarter is Anything But. My daughter loved this part of Prague across the Karlov Most from Staromèstské nàmêste best because "people are happy". There is the long uphill slope to the Castle and St. Vitus, with ersatz antique shops, galleries, wine bars, etc. Along its bank of the Vltava are restaurants posh and grand, or hidden and local. There is a street to which you descend from the bridge that brings you into a boulevard down the middle of which is a line of trees and that is as quiet as the rest of Prague is buzzing. As you crest the first part of the hill, the enormous, impressive castle to your right, but cross the street and look down to your left to see green gardens and pasture.

Beautiful. Lovely little part of Prague. Beautiful Architecture. Nice walks. History in abundance. Walk to the castle and see great views. Nice places to eat and drink on the journeyWe will stay in this part of the city next time.
surprising. didn't spend a lot of time here during my first visit which was in the 80's. Bustling, lots of gorgeous architecture (Prague has to be up there in terms of eye popping minutiae).
Good places to explore. There are some beautiful churches here, and the funicular is a great way to experience something unusual as well as explore Petrin hill

Costume gala. Purely by accident we arrived just as a procession was starting in national costume and it was brilliant. Interestingly no-one at the hotel was able to give any insight to things like this so we were lucky to stumble across it. A great pageant and very colourful.

We stayed in a small apartment in Mala Strana. We loved Mala Strana. We were steps away from everything we wanted to see. We hiked up to the castle and walked to the Jewish Quarter and Old Town. St Nicholas Church is a must see. The Charles Bridge was a couple of blocks away.

Mala Strana is my favorite part of Prague!. Narrow streets, stair cases, many shops, cafes and restaurants. Great views, and beautiful walking destinations. For me it is the nicest part of Prague. If you go, be sure to spend time in Mala Strana.

Pictoresque place. Very nice place right under the Prague castle where you can smell the spirit of old Prague. Less tourists but full of tiny streets with buildings that remember pretty much. You can find here Czech houses with its typical house signs, beautiful gardens and you can feel the Spirit of Franz Kafka, Jan Neruda and other big personalities who lived in this area...

Don't miss this part of the town. At the end of the Charles Bridge, a nice area with baroque churches, palaces and hidden gardens, all in one it sends you back in time. Much more quiet than the city centre. Very nice area to walk in with a lot of small alleys and beautiful buildings (just remember to look upwards). One will also find a lot of nice restaurants and cafes. May be one of the best part of Prague. Look for a well hidden flower shop with an unique atmosphere, situated in a recess in an alley. Bouquets , wreaths and other floral decorations are fighting for space inside as well as in front of the shop.In the are one will find the John Lennon Wall, once just a normal wall, but since the 1980s it has been filled with both John Lennon-inspired graffiti as well as pieces of lyrics from Beatles' songs.
Quieter. This is a nice quiet little area, with cool little bars and bistros, Good area to stroll about in, not too hectic.
Lovely buildings. A great stroll around some beautiful buildings...just remember to look upwards as many of the beautiful parts are easy to miss...

Calm historical quarter. Male Strana is situated under the Prague Castle. It has great historical value, as a lot of old beautiful buildings are located here. It's nice to walk in Male Strana, because it's more quiet than the city centre. There are lots of restaurants and bars. Kampa island is also worth a visit. Here you will find a huge graffiti wall with images of John Lennon.
Favourite place. We enjoyed this area the most such lovely buildings and lots of streets to wind down and parks to explore plus ample restaurants bars and cafes very relaxing indeed
The best part of Prague. Don't miss this part of the Town. Very nice to walk in and a lot of small alleys and nice buildings. Also nice restaurants and cafes. I think this is the best part of Prague

Lots to explore from churches to parks and of course restaurants. Mala Strana is the part of Prague directly below the castle. Many visitors pass directly through it however do not explore it in their eagerness to reach the castle. Take time to explore the churches, gardens, streets, coffee houses and restaurants.Top Tip: go towards the end of the day when many tourists have returned to the Old Town Square side of the Charles Bridge. The restaurants in Mala Strana tend to be quieter then and just as good.
Nice, quaint place to walk. The Lesser Quarter is a place off the beaten path that is not too crowded. As a result it is a great place to walk, see beautiful architecture, and find some peace.
Not worth the trip. Made a special trip to see the Lennon wall which was really just a graffitied wall with some pix of John. No biggie.

Pleasant and interesting walk. My wife and I walked over the scenic Charles Bridge and wandered around the narrow streets here and really enjoyed it. Visit the KGB Museum, look for the peacocks on a walk thru the beautiful gardens of the Senate and have a nice lunch at one of the relaxing Cafes before you hike up the hill to the Castle. A great way to spend some time in Prague.

What a place to stay!. We loved being right here at the end of the Charles Bridge... with cafes, restaurants alongside the most fantastic historical buildings. The square and the churches and the friendly locals mingled with tourists. Wow!

Best Area to Stay. I stayed in StareMesto last time and wanted a change. This could not have been better, we were in Prague for 10 days and walked almost everywhere- it's that kind of town (and I do not walk much at home). We stayed next to St Nicolas, 3 blocks from the Charles Bridge, and an easy and interesting walk to two other bridges. There is always something to see here, including some very quiet neighborhoods and many parks. You can walk up Petrine Hill to get a great view of the city or take the funicular to the tower. Trams run from MalaStranska, and Old Town is literally across the Charles Bridge, about 5 blocks, depending on where you stay in the neighborhood. Embassy Row was at our backs, with its patina of quiet refinement. If this is too challenging for the urban traveler, you can just head for the Charles Bridge at any time of night or day-throbbing with vendors and tourists the only time all is quiet is early morning;Prague begins at 10.

An oasis of peace and calm. The park higher up the hill is a peaceful green oasis with pleasant walks and allows good views over the city. Then the buildings nearer the river give a feel of the 19th century high society.
So lovely but busy. Lesser Town is so much better than the Old Town. Lots of green spaces and beautiful buildings. Loved the walk up to the Castle, so much we did it twice!!

Confused by the signs. We Had a lovely lunch in the square. The tourist signs were all in Czech and therefore difficult to dicipher. It was out of synch with all commercial signs in Prague which were mostly in English. We folllowed all the signs to tourist information but went around in circles. There were pictures on the signs but hard to follow.

What to say about the history. Mala Strana takes you through the 14th Century. Your thought becomes true when you start to think the old times. You will become a part of it as it a natural tenant of this part of the city...
Lesser Quarter. This area is around 10-15mnt walk from Old Town area, still much tourist here but not as crowded as Old Town area. Its nice to walk around here, lots of shops and restaurant.

Re: . After coming from the Prague castle, we found our way to the Lesser quarter. It's not very touristy but lots of nice cafes. Vilma, our tour guide brought us there and we decided to go back there the following day. If you like to walk, then everything is walking distance in Prague. We stayed in the Old Town and used the Charles Bridge to walk back and forth to the other side of Prague.
Not really lesser at all!. Our tour guide took us to this area as part of our tour. All of Prague is wonderful. Take a guided tour on day one, and go back to places you liked again.

Glad we stayed here. We stayed in this area near the Charles Bridge and it was the perfect choice for us. It was 10-15 minutes walk to the Old Town Square and the same to the castle but Mala Strana is worth exploring on its own with lovely buildings, walks by the river, parks and some excellent restaurants and cafes. If we do go back to Prague we will almost certainly stay here again.

must see,but get the tram. at the top fantastic view of prague see all the churches and palaces.the lovely park with their excotic birds and views.must go ,the monastry great spot great home made beer.
Lovely. Mala Strana is not really a small town. In fact it is sizeable. It is loaded with cafes and restaurants and offers one of the best strolls in town.

Lovely, quiet area. We had a walk around the area, to the south of Charles Bridge, on our last afternoon. And decided that it was a pity we'd left it until then. Quiet streets with beautiful buildings, some of which I'd love to know the history of.In fact, my wife's decided that on our next visit, she'd like to stay on Kampa Island!

Worth a visit. While it is less grandiose and smaller than the Old Town, the Lesser Quarter are still worth a visit. There are several interesting and beautiful buildings and churches to see. The Wall in memory of Lennon and the Beatles is also situated in this part of town, as well as the Church of the Order of Malta.At the end of the visit, you can rest in one of the parks in the area.

Less is more. Mala Strana offers a boisterous oasis on the trip to Prague Castle with numerous small pub-like bars and dozens of small, quite good restaurants. Most of these are relatively inexpensive. It is usually filled with older folk during the day and students at night.
It is not so small. It is great place to relax, visit few parks / gardens and have a nice time in many small restaurants. You can see the quarter from Petrin Hill as well.

Lennon Wall and Atelier Red & Wine. I had already visited Old town and the castle area during a previous visit to Prague a few years ago - this month I discovered Mala Strana. I was surprised to discover the Lennon wall in constant change with tourists still tagging and the very good restaurant Atelier Red & wine, just at the foot of the Petrin tower.Much less people than around the clock or on the Charles bridge!
Don't miss this area. We really liked this area, the atmosphere, bars and restaurants had a more up market feel to it as well as plenty of historic buildings

Interesting neighborhood to walk around. This is a great area of Prague. I walked around here after descending from Prague castle. There aren't a lot of tourists around and there are some nice local shops.
Quaint. Very interesting part of the city,interesting and traditional little shops and not too many tourists around.

Ripped off at a local cafe. We were ripped off at a local cafe. They charged us at least 3 times as much as we paid else where. Please be careful. The ladies are in costume and call you in. It is next to a bigger restaurant also with the same name.

Buda of Prague!. I have been to Budapest. I liked the city for the view it had the view.When I visited Prague, I felt the same. To reach this part of the City - Prague 1 - you have a bridge which is connected to Old Town. Trams go in and out of it.This part of city, you need to walk... walk.. walk.. You will love it! There are many tracks for trekking... you can go for Monastery... You can go to castle... you can go to mini Eiffel Tower... You can go everywhere.

Beautiful part of the city. I loved this area. Very vibrant and yet peaceful and serene giving you a perfect spot away from all the tourist crowds and giving you ample space to enjoy this beautiful section of the city. It is filled with worthwhile places to visit. Lots of scopes for photographs and shopping and dining options. Not crowded. Views are amazing . A beautiful part of beautiful city
Sense of History. Cobbled streets and narrow lanes ,new vista around every corner, churches, embassies,cafes and restaurants, the essence of Prague

In my opinion, the most beautiful side of the city.. Prague is astonishingly beautiful overall, but in my own opinion, this is the nicest side of the city. Of course, Prague, is full of amazing places, no doubt, but I kind of like the Lesser Quarter more than any other around here. Might be the stunning Castle and its views, it might be the beautiful streets and the Lennon Wall, maybe Petřín Hill, perhaps all the riverside, or maybe just the whole place itself, I don't know, but I'm sure you will enjoy and appreciate a bit of every thing you will stumble upon here. It's just a must-visit place when you come to Prague!

Wander round the side streets. if you want to get away from the hordes of tourists around the castle or on the Charles bridge, head off for Mala Strana. Lots of hills, parks and loads of history..And very good cafes and restaurants

Walk around and marvel at the sights. Every corner you take will be prettier than the previous... Prague is a beautiful city and lesser quarter has so many sights cathedrals, monuments, restaurants and even the Swan park in the evening for you to wander around!

Lots to offer. We stayed in Mala Strana at the Lokal Inn. Fabulous accommodation right near Charles Bridge. Highly recommend this area of Prague which is not far to Prague a Castle and a short stroll to the Old Town.
A lot of character. We stayed in this part of Prague. It has a lot of character and history. It has Prague Castle, beautiful park and many beautiful churches!

No less than Old town. Why lesser Quarter? I really don't know, it is something from history when this part was over the river away from the centre.But today it is just as much a must see as the old town. You pass trough this quarter on you walk to the castle,
Not to be missed. All of Prague is a "must see" and this area is no different. A beautiful city with much to offer. Be ready for the long walk up to the Castle from here

Pretty crowded but well worth a look. We were lucky enough to stay here and it is very convenient to the castle plus St Nicholas Church the embassy's and the Charles BridgeLots of loveley little shops and cafes and restaurants and less touristy than in the old town

Great views and a place of calm in a busy city. It was nice to walk in the large park and see red squirrels, jays and many other birds. The views are fantastic especially from the top of the replica 'Eiffel' Tower

The way to the Castle. There is more to see than you might imagine - after three visits we have only just found the Wallenstein Palace which is an amazing building, now used by the Czech Senate. We came across a super Italian restaurant in a side street where we had pizzas, and a bottle of very good wine which cost only 285czk/just over £8. An area which has the bustling main streets to the quitter ones which still have interesting buildings and excellent bars and restaurants. Don`t just go up the the Castle (which of course must be seen), but wander around and you will be amazed at what you can find.

Best location to avoid the stream of people like us ( considerate tourists ).. We loved the tram system and the Café Savoy, the Loreto with the incredible monstrance all on trams from the Mala Strana Namesi. We loathed the Graffitti and self absorbed teenagers taking selfies especially on Charles Bridge.

Not lesser whatsoever. Although a big fan of Stare Mesto myself, I definitely enjoy the strolls in Mala Strana. Not as crowded, with many quiet caffes and restaurants, small shops and beautiful streets to wander in.

The real Prague. This quarter is very special and "hidden" from the normal tourist hussel and bussel. It is very quiet and there seem to be "hidden" streets with exceptional architecture Quiet, old buildings, real character of Prague.
Quaint but too commercialized. Too many touts, trying to sell tours... Local maps were difficult to follow, not enough directional signs

Sacre Couer of Prague. This quarter seemed very special to us especially if you try to find even some hidden streets. So quiet, old buildings, real character of Prague. Find few hours for to discover.

Lesser Town of Prague. After visiting the Holy Infant of Prague I walked up the Petrin Hill. This place had always attracted me when I worked in Prague in the past. If you're in Prague for at least three days and want to take unforgettable shots, go there! You can access Pertrin Hill also from the side of Strachov Monastery (walk along the wall on the right)

One of the most preserved places behind iron curtain.. The narow streets with ancient buidings transport you to another era. Litlle family stores sells memories that you can take home! Stop for a while at a café or a brewerei. Observe people and the surroundings.

Lots going on here.. This is located on the other side of Charles Bridge from the Old Town and although not as lively as the Old Town , it still has lots of good bars and restaurants such as the Pod Vezi. So well worth a visit , particularly if you are on your way back from the castle and cathedral.
yes it's pretty. but again, when it's not crowded with tourists. watch out for pick pockets if you are going in summer.
beautiful, but expensive. its an important heritage site of Bohemia. The lesser town has a market which I found was little expensive. Though, the view of charles bridge from this area is good.

Wonderful just to wander about. Seriously, you should just wander about in no particular direction and with no particular agenda, and you will have a wonderful time! There are hundreds of interesting squares/shops/churches/museums/cafes/restaurants and the best way to discover them is to just stumble across them!
Very charming. I loved walking around checking all the well kept buildings and nice stores. Street vendors sell a pastry cooked on a hot rolling iron, light, not too sweet and very good

an interesting part of the city, but a little too commercial. Another interesting part of the city. However, we found it a little too commercial, with lots of bars, restaurants, shops catering to tourists and not always very authentic.
Lovely and quirky.. We walked up here from Charles bridge. It is up a bit of a hill, but well worth it. Some lovely architecture.
Wonderful Area. Just walk around and admire the buildings. Had a great time just enjoying the scenery and architecture.

Atmospheric Area of Prague, Cheaper & more Czech!. This area is great for pubs, clubs and cafes, and restaurants - it is a short tram ride, or a 15minute walk from the old town, and well worth making your way over here. The streets, and gardens are all cobbled and narrow, and full of czech's. So, if you want to visit an area where the locals are, this is it. The prices are definitely cheaper than the old town area (which is still nice). But, 2 Large Beers for 78CZK is pretty awesome!I took advice to come here, from a Czech woman I know, and I am glad I did, it was a great experience, and I will be back!

The most romantic neighborhood of Prague. Undoubtedly the most romantic place in Prague: from the awe-inspiring "Gardens below the Prague Castle" (a must-see especially in spring and early autumn!) to the sprawling series of connected palaces, courtyards and gardens which cover almost 70,000 square meters, Mala Strana definitely deserves an entire day visit!
bit more quiet. Lovely peacefull setting, little square with more shops, bars and restaurants, easy access to the castle

Beautiful Quarter of Prague. Lesser Town of Prague was founded as a town by the Czech king Přemysl Otakar II in 1257. After extensive fire (in 1541) the new buildings were established in the Renaissance and the Baroque styles. The St.Nicholas Church at the Malostranské náměstí square is most beautiful Baroque building in Prague. Only part of my photos is from Malostranské náměstí square. Not all buildings on my photos are important in history. (Note: The fire in the Lesser Town of Prague in 1541 like the fire in Chicago (USA) in 1871 had given rise to a new architecture of the world importance.)
Cute neighborhood. Mala Strana is a cute neighborhood to walk around, enjoy the buildings and "inhale" some more of the beauty that the city of Prague has to offer. Do not miss it!
On the way to the HRADZIN - a walk through the past. A walk through the past -but everything is converted for the tourism.Obviously like that.Plenty of small places to dine, or to shop souvenirs.
Fantastic area to explore. Such a beautiful area of prague, just stroll around and explore the many streets and buildings. Narrow streets and impressive buildings!

Wander the beautiful streets. You can see where Bach and Beethoven lived. Not too far away and near the mall you can see where Mozart lived. Walk up the hill to the tower. Stroll over to Hradcany. Enjoy a coffee at Starbucks near the Parliament. You will love it here.

A Charming Section of a Beautiful City!. After the hustle and bustle of Old Town and the Castle District, we enjoyed the beauty and quiet of Mala Strana. Its charming, winding streets were wonderful to explore and we were thrilled to find the church where " the Infant of Prague" is located. Take the time to see this lovely section of Prague!

Great place to stay. Much quieter than the rest of Prague, with cobbled streets, some lovely architecture and lots of bars and restaurants, some very tucked away. I stayed in a hotel in Mala Strana and it was lovely as there was virtually no traffic and it's only a short walk to Petrin Hill, Charles Bridge and the Castle

Lesser Quarter, a bit quieter!. Unless on the main road up to the Castle, the back streets of Mala Strana are much quieter than the old town, lots of lovely old buildings, cafes and bars, well worth an afternoon stroll around in your way up or back for the Castle
charming. charming lanes to wander in below the castle - several bars & restaurants to choose from too. Beautiful.

Lots of steps to the castle. I was just expecting to see the castle and a few shops on the other side of Charles Bridge, so was surprised to see that this lesser quarter was pretty big.We ventured up to the castle despite the numerous steps leading up to the grounds.As in the rest of Prague, there is fantastic architecture everywhere.

Graphic neighbourhood of Prague. A must visit in Prague. Go early in the morning, first to visit with the funicular the Petrin Hill, then walk down through the gardens to Mala Strana and see the wonderfull buildings and monuments.

Good place as a base. Handy for the castle and the trams run intoit so the entire city is accessible. Local bars and restaurants are good – you could easily spend a few days here without crossing the river!

Beautiful. Close to the castle, I visited these areas while returning from the castle tour. The place offers a lot of interesting view. The buildings in itself are beautiful and spread out nicely. The only problem is the tourist crowd which is expectable considering that these alleys have a lot to offer from small galleries, cafes to restaurants. It is a good place to soak in some of the local culture and enjoy strolling as well.

Saunter through Mala Strana. Lots of cafes, restaurants, souvenir shops and as you get further up the hill on Nerudova, crepes shops selling "shots" of hot honey wine and pastry ...what you need on a February saunter
Maze. This is a maze of cobbled streets, filled with a multitude of cafes, restaurants, shops an quaint tiny cottages.

Nice to wander through. Very busy now so in summer it must be almost impossible to move here! Usual shops selling tourist tat mixed with better quality shops selling authentic Czech glass, and wooden toys - Moser, Blue, Manufakturer. Everywhere feels safe & there are police around but as in all cities keep an eye on bags etc amongst crowds.

Simply amaizing. Mala Strana - the best part of Prague. Start exploring from Pohorelec and go down Uvoz street. The view to the old town, marvellous buildings all around, tiny streets ans small shops and cafe's. Even try to get lost there - and then appreciate the beauty. (It's still the center, close to the Castle, but there is less tourists than all around.)
Explore and enjoy. Lovely side of town that you can easily walk and enjoy for a whileBeautiful place to eat, shop and enjoy. Not too far from the centre of town

Worth every minute day and night. Note: Everything I am writing and wrote is my opinion, taste and experience only and could be different to others.Beautiful, quite and old area. On day time include the Church of St Nicholas. Some galleries in the small alleys, restaurants, bars, caffes.Night time many restaurants, bars, caffes and more.
Quaint and atmospheric. A great place to just stroll around not far from the old town. Lots of shops and restaurants with loads of atmsophere
Amazing feel walking the street....... Mala Strana has a feel of ancient time......A sunny day is quite good for strolling around filled with shops for food,drinks,souveniers.......

Mala Strana, don't miss it. Worth every step of the way...visit it all from top to bottom, don't miss Kampa Island either, its quiet streets, little restaurants, the Lennon wall, the architecture and so much more.... prepare to walk your steep way up to the Castle and then to the Petrin park and down into Mala Strana and Kampa....surroundings of the Karlov Most (Charles Bridge)...lovely!

Walk back in time, but choose when you go!!. Although not as touristy in season as other Prague attractions I recommend you pay in visit to the "Little Town" on a cold February evening as I did when you can easily imagine Mozart stalling these atmospheric cobbled streets in his warm cloak!!

Best of both worlds!. This area has plenty of shops, bars and restaurants, but is less touristy, yet you are only just across the river from the old town.
Beware of using the exchange on the corner of the square up from Charles Bridge.
Best cakes Cafe Savoy
Full of atmosphere. Full of atmosphere but only had a short time wandering around in the evening. Definitely worth pounding the streets and searching out hidden byways.

Peaceful. This is a very nice part of Prague which seems to cater to tourists. I stayed in this area for 10 days- it was very quiet at night, and close to a giant park (Petrin) and a great pub. It is only a short walk to Old Town. It was a nice place to stay while visiting Prague.

The Quarter with many interesting leads. Malostranska Residence was where we stayed. The management reception staff, Marketa and Nicole were very friendly and looked after our household needs wonderfully. This included a bottle of champagne for my 60th. I was really chuffed. They explained the genesis of the building to me when I was chatting to them. They offered to book the ballet for me the next time we visited. I enjoyed they're sweetie dish when I passed reception. We had exceptional views of the Castle, St Nicholas's and other business buildings. The Beer Museum was on the same block at the end of the road. There are many attractive shops housed within arches and protected with strong heavy wooden doors. Really different and many types of crystal, sparkle, art and creativity. We crossed St Charles's Bridge at least twice a day and I loved it every time I had different panoramic views. Trains that frequented this spot were, 12, 18, 20,22 Perhaps there were more I will be back to check.
Mala Strana. Nice place to stay, near everything but more peaceful and silent than Stare Mesto. Beautiful streets, very nice restaurants
Couldn't be romantic. Simply beautiful and breathtaking - the atmosphere is simply magic, especially during late evening hours but also day time walking around and indulging the oldest town...

a rather different looking bridge of Sighs. Having visited both the original Bridge in Venice and the replica in Cambridge, there is a large two bridge construction that resembles the two structures on a busy street. At the time, the weather was cold, and I feel to be appreciated in its full beauty best seen in sun shine.

Less is more. The best place to stay and eat etc. Not as touristy as the old town, zero stags on tour, classier and better value. You will find hidden gems that locals frequent as opposed to the rip of places in the old town. I frequent here and stay here only. The old town for me is only for the Christmas markets. Cross the Charles Bridge and walk up Nerudova street, it was called the Royal Way in the old days. Its steep so its tiring and not for the faint hearted or mobility challenged. In peak season its busy and its only got one way traffic so its busy but great vies from the Palace ones you make it to the top. There are lots of places to stop and have a coffee if you need a rest. I prefer off peak season, its much easier to walk around.
Great. As every area in Prague, this one was beautiful too. It is right below the castle and the views from here are amazing. Don't miss it.

Soul of Prague. The Lesser Quarter (Mala Strana) is located on the west bank of the Vltava River, while the Old Town (Stare Mesto) is on the east, with the Charles Bridge connecting the two via a 10-minute walk. Malostranske namesti is the main town square surrounding the St.Nicolas Church with its famous Tiffany blue dome, which serves as the logical starting point for any tour of the Lesser Quarter due to its location; at the top of the hill just north sits the Prague Castle (Prazsky Hrad), to the south is Petrin Hill and its tower overlooking the city, and to the east is the Charles Bridge. Mostecka, the road from the Charles Bridge leading up to St.Nicolas Church, has been hailed as one of the most colorful streets in the world, which you'll quickly discover as you make your way into the heart of Mala Strana. Shops, restaurants, and cobbled roads with narrow alleys make this neighborhood the soul of Prague, while the Old Town is the history of Prague. This is a must-see on your visit to this city.

Quaint. Between the castle and the famous Charles Bridge this area has lots of small streets, found a couple of great bars and the shops are numerous. Walk down the river and through the park area, there was a museum near the park on the river bank, can't remember what it was for though
quite boring. nice but alive anly in the day, evening time is very boring there because there are no locals, only offices and administration

Exquisite walking district. This district lies at the foot of Prague Castle, and lies to the west of Charles Bridge. There are any number of narrow cobbled streets to stroll through with quaint architecture among the houses. Be sure to walk along the river a bit; there is a park where many swans congregate because the locals feed them.
Ate our way down the Mala Strana!. Lovely shopping and lots of great local cuisine along the Mala Strana. Prices for meals were slightly cheaper than across the river near the town square.

Old times.... This part of Prague, together with the Old Town area are the oldest communities on both sides of the Moldau (Vltava) River. The main point of the Lesser Quarter is the church of St. Nicholas, which main tower is 6 yards higher than the Petrinska Rozhledna (Observation Tower) shown in the back of the enclosed photographs. For those who are interested in the history of this part of the city, there is a book (also in English) from a 19th Century writer, Jan Neruda, entitled "The stories of Lesser Town". You can walk for hours through the area, look inside the medieval yards and taste genuine Czech food in tens of local little pubs. Great place for taking photographs!

Don't miss it. Many people don't get over to the Lesser Quarter. It's an easy stroll across the bridges and the streets are very interesting with different statues and buildings. Go up the tower by cable car while you're there for the best views of Prague.

Walkable, quaint with some touristy spots but many hidden gems!. Wow! Just how more quaint can Prague be and then there's Mala Strana which is filled with Cathedrals, adorable small pubs, restaurants and of course, a Starbucks! There's a public WC on the main square but make sure you have small change as there's a fee. There are many hidden gems in this amazing area! Just a hint, we took the tram up to the castle area, then walked down to Mala Strana which is much easier than starting from Mala Strana and walking up to the castle or Loreta.

Narrow alleys and fun shops. I loved wandering around in this area of Prague. The little shops are fun to explore, and the views of the city across the Charles Bridge are incredible. Take time to see this quarter on your way up to Prague Castle.
Interesting. Really enjoyed walking through the small streets and looking in the shops. Really enjoyed walking through up to the castle.

Busy area. The buildings in the Lesser Quarter differ from the ones in the Old Town in the sense that they are more modern. It was a good place to just wander around and enter the shops as you like it. Like Old Town, this area was bustling with people.

Don't Miss Mala Strana. We wondered over Charles Bridge to find ourself in Mana Strana, we just let our feet walk where they wanted and we loved it. We got lost a few times and that was when we found the prettiest houses/ buildings. It is truly unlike anything else I've ever seen. Don't miss this area, have fun and just enjoy the time and the beauty of it! Stop in for a drink at a pub or lunch at a cafe - we loved Cafe Savoy. We also enjoyed trying to locate all the embassies!

Lesser Quarter (Mala Strana). Very different from the other side of Charles Bridge! The streets are more ordered and easier to follow for a first timer. Maybe Christmas Eve morning at 08.30 wasn't the best time to visit as most of Prague either side of the river seemed to be asleep, but it was a very cool way to wander around without stumbling over fellow tourists!St Nicholas Church is definitely worth a visit, and the castle - which we didn't go to - is also supposed to be impressive. It's hilly and there are trams (too confusing to contemplate, for me) to get to both, and also a fleet of vintage cars with drivers for personal tours of these places as well as the other side of the bridge and around the rest of the city. They're not super cheap, but won't break the bank either. Holidays are to be enjoyed, not done on a shoestring IMO and so if you want a bit of luxury transport, with drinks included, and have had enough of walking over cobbled streets for hours, why not!?!

Get lost here, it is worth it. The really enjoyable part of this area is to wander as many of the back streets as you can, and to do this I suggest ignoring the map and simply wandering around. Lots of different architecture, apparently different levels of wealth (there are a series of embassies in here) and corners to poke into.

Completely different atmosphere from Old Town. This area though is not so far from Old Town, only separated by charles bridge, offered completely different atmosphere with Old Town. Lot of nice shops are there, if you like to do shopping. The food was nice as well, the price was slightly lower than what offered in Old Town. A lot of ATMs are everywhere to help you when you are running out of cash, no need to buy koruna at money exchangers due to high commission.

Again as in previous review on Pragues attractions find Ross the tour guide. Ross brought Prague to life taking in many attractions and all of the including this one were a delight, find him in the square with the astronomical clock, he does free 2 hour tours or a full day for around £26 english per person but that included taxi from hotel full tour, lunch (which was delicious) in a traditional Czech inn, boat ride and tram, started at 11am finished 5.30 worth every penny and totally made our stay.

Prettiest Part of Prague to Walk Around. Its a lovely part of Prague. In my view the best part of Prague with the quiet neighbourhoods, canals, Kampa Park, the river bank, the Churches of St.Nicholas, Infant Jesus of Prague, Lenon Wall...

Not only churches and buildings!. Mala Strana is not only about buildings and churches - although they are very impressive. It was also a protohipster place in the communist times, where alternative artists, hippies and counter-culture activists lived and worked. There is the famous John Lennon Wall with pacifist graffiti all over, there is the Kampa Park where young people like to hang out, etc. Also - there is a wonderful medieval restaurant called U Krale Brabantskeho if you go a bit up the cobble-stoned hill a bit north from Malostranske Namesti. Highly recommended.
walk up the hill. Do take a stroll around this part of old town and walk up the hill to the castle. if you go on a foggy day the cathedral looks very mystical and "creepy".

A real atmosphere in this area. Baroque architecture at its best. Stunning buildings. Wonderful in atmosphere. Make sure you go into St. Nicholas church and pay the entrance fee. It was built to demonstrate the power of the Catholic church and it is incredible. In my opinion it is as equally incredible as St. Peter's in Rome...oh and Mozart played the organ!
Wondrous!. Don't let the name fool you…this is not "lesser" in any way. It's lovely to take a leisurely guided tour and enjoy the history and buildings here.

good for a walk round. there are shops and cafes under the arches to the side of the street, we loved the cafes, one selling hot chocolate with rum!. You kind of pass through this quarter having crossed CharlesBridge, on your way up to the castle and cathedral, but it is worth stopping a while, visiting St. Nicholas church, and having a browse in the shops and cafes, and looking at the stunning architecture
So much to take in. Firstly make sure you wear comfortable shoes as there is so much to see there is a lot of walking involved on cobble stones.

Stay here. We were recommended this area to stay rather than the old town and I'm really glad we did as its not so usy and still has a lot of character. Great choice of restaurants, everything within walking distance but cobbles everywhere you'll need flat boots/shoes no heels.

A beautiful part of Prague. This part of Prague is very beautiful. The palaces are amazing. The houses are well preserved. It is located under the Hradčani district. The restaurants are great. Take your time and explore its streets. There are a lot of souvenir shops.

Good place to stay. My husband and I stayed here, and it was a very classy place. It's a hilly place if you do not mind the climb, but it offers spectacular views of the city and is close to Prague Castle and the Lady Victorious Church where you can find Infant Jesus of Prague. Souvenir shops and quaint pubs and restaurants dot the place.

Great for strolling, bistros and Christmas markets. Less crowded than old town. Wonderful little bistros around every corner. Great shops and sites. A wonderful way to spend an afternoon or morning, or both.

Quiet, Relaxing and Lovely Area All Around. This area is just a short walk over the Charles Bridge from the Old Town. As if Old Town was noisy (which it isn't), Lesser Town is very quiet and relaxing. There are plenty of areas to explore including a few museums, shops, restaurants and Prague Castle.You should definitely visit this area at least for a couple hours strolling around!

Very cool and relaxed.. Combined with the Castle District, this felt like a really nice part of Prague - even though it is just across Charles Bridge once you get away from the main street it is a much more relaxed place than many of the main parts of Prague.

One of my favorite parts of Prague. I love just wondering round the quaint streets of Pague with its grand houses & palaces and getting away from the hussle & bustle of the Old Town. After you walk across the Charles Bridge you are in a much quieter and gentle place. Don't miss the 'John Lennon' wall where those who believe in Peace & Love come to pay homage to the 'Prophet' and leave their artistic tributes onthe wall and padlocks on the little bridge
Tourist area. Pure tourist area, interesting in its own way but not interesting enough to make us want to hang around for long.

Fun walk. Walk over the Charles Bridge and you are in the Lesser Quarter area. It's fun to wander through this area and browse through the various small shops or stop in to a cafe or restaurant for something to eat. Nice leisurely walk.

The best part of Prague. Cross the Charles Bridge and you'll end up in the charming Mala Strana. This area of Prague is filled with beautiful buildings and narrow cobblestone streets. Put your map away and just get lost here! And getting lost is quite easy to do, as the winding streets twist and turn in every direction - you hardly have to try to lose your way! The Lesser Quarter is filled with plenty of little cafes where you can grab a bite to eat (although if you want better prices, head south away from the touristy center). There's a lot to see here, as well. Obviously the Prague Castle complex is a major draw, but the Church of St. Nicholas is in this part of town, and absolutely worth stopping in (not to mention, it's much cheaper than the cathedral at the castle, and more breathtaking in my opinion). A park called Vojanovy Sady is here, too - it's a quaint little place filled with locals (and peacocks!).
Explore on foot and get lost!. Best way to see any city - it's no 'lesser' city. Enjoyed just walking along and entering the pubs cafés to thaw out and soothe the tired legs!
Quieter part of Prague. Lots of lovely buildings and streets, set below the Castle and St Vitus Cathedral. Several Embassies located in the area. Easy to walk across Charles Bridge into Old Town.

Watch your step. Another perfect walking area of Prague, just when you think you have seen it all, it just keeps on going. Love the narrow streets, overhead walk ways between buildings. BUT, because one is always looking around clicking the shutter button, it is very easy to tumble on the cobble stone streets. As usual , when you feel like a drink or meal, there are a lot of choices, be daring, try something different! or each stop, try a different beer! I'll bet you could go for days of drinking and not repeat the same beer. Love Czech beer.

More of the real Prague. Just off Charles Bridge, have a leisurely walk round and marvel at the architecture, walk up to the castle and generally browse the shops whilst stopping off at one of the many restaurants.

Great neighborhood. This area of Prague is perfect for tourists. There are many cafes and restaurants serving authentic Czech cuisine, as well as international, and also many fast food venues.the area is very close to Prague castle. Near the castle the view is truly spectacular.

Quiet and relaxing. I stayed in this section of town in Nov/ Dec and was concerned I'd be too far away from the Old Town Square and Wenceslas Square to enjoy myself without freezing my buns off. But it was easy walking across Charles Bridge in the 30 degree weather. I was perfectly comfortable and pleased to be staying in the quieter part of town where I could sleep rhe night through. Also found the resturant food better and the prices less expensive than on the other side of the river.
Visit the Petrin hill. You should climb up the hill to see the view of the city or to climb up to the mini eiffel tower at the height of 60 meters
Perfect. I liked the shops and ease of movement around the streets and along the river bank. Less noise, traffic and people.
Peaceful beauty. stroll around the silent quarter to break from bustling old town, admire the kafka museum, the john lennon memroial and the beautiful buildings
Enjoyable. We love just walking through neighborhoods and looking at the beautiful buildings. The most unique architecture that is very different than other European cities. Take your time and enjoy.

Nice to wander. It's a nice wander around the Lesser Quarter, but not much in the way of touristy things. That's good and bad, I guess. Let's you feel the true area and enjoy the places and the people. Just don't go expecting lots of "things" to do.

A walk through time in Beautiful Prague. The ,Mala Strana (lesser quarter) of Prague (although there is NOTHING lesser about it) was wonderful to walk through. Architecture was amazing. Excellent places to shop and just wander around. Would definitely recommend this part of Prague for an overall experience of this truly WORLD CLASS city.
My favourite. Take a walk to Mala Strana - or go by tram or by metro, but then just walk down these medieval streets and look at the squares, buildings and monuments. Don't forget your camera!
Good walk down ancient history. Nice walk down history for families with children might be a bit tiring, some good restaurants and touristy shops on there too,stroller for kids will be good.

Try the less hectic side of the river. We really enjoyed staying in Mala Strana. It was a respite from the hectic Old Town side. We enjoyed sight seeing in Old Town, then coming back to dine and stay in Mala Strana.

Favorite part of the city. I fell in love with this part of Prague. The architecture was unbelievable and the food was amazing. We ate at several places while we were in the area. It was a great place to shop and just wander around. Next time I go, I will be staying in this part of town!

Old Town's Equal for Culture and Cuisine. It being our first time in Prague, we stayed in Old Town and spent much of our time seeing that side of Prague. But later in our visit, we spent time on the west side of the Vltava River, in Lesser Town, and we loved it! From the splendid St. Nicholas Church and the Czech Music Museum, to the lovely labyrinthine streets leading down to the Charles Bridge, we found ourselves wishing we had more time to explore this part of Prague. Next time, I'm sure we will do just that!

My favorite place in the world. Love this part of Prague and there is a very good reason for it. I was born and raised here, and can't think of a better place in the world to grow up in. The view of the river and the National Theater from our windows was hard to beat, the parks nearby- Petrin and Kampa were our backyard. Detsky ostrov -Childrens Island and Strelecky ostrov - Shooters Island and Zofin Island were favorite places to visit. There are many beautiful churches, among them Prazske Jezulatko and the baroque church St. Nicholas, Loreta, and of course the famous St. Vitus Cathedral and and the St. George Basilica.The many boutique hotels make the visit to the Castle and Charles bridge a very easy one. I love the manicured gardens Vrtbovska and Waldstejnska, and the gardens right below the Castle. The many restaurants that have been in the same place for years and the new ones too. The beautiful houses in Mostecka and Nerudova streets. The Funicular at the base of The Petrin Hill. The cobblestone streets. The amazing views of Prague. Mala Strana is my favorite place to stay when I come back home to Prague.

One of the most memorable parts of Prague!. One of the most memorable parts of Prague! I remember walking through on my solo trip in early 2006 and being awed by the architecture and history of this part of Prague.I imagined as I was walking through this part of Prague that I was in Lord of the Rings a time in the past. Super nice!
A gem. This was amazing, the whole of prague city was beautiful and magical but the lesser town over charles bridge did what it said on the tin and was like stepping back into the 18th century

Great area to visit, shop and eat.. This is an area that not everyone gets to because they need to walk about a mile or so to get there from the old city center. great shopping and places to eat. A must see if you are in Prague. THis area becomes vey busy on Saturday mornings with shopper and people just strolling the streets. If you want to eat in the this area on a Friday night, a resevation 4- days in advance is a MUST.

After the Castle down to the river. After our walk up to the Castle Hill we walked down to the river and a well deserved beer and sausage lunch at one of the many restaurants. Don't miss out on this side of the river.

Charming and full of interesting sights.. I've stayed in this area on each visit to Prague and highly recommend it. Quiet, winding streets, interesting Embassy buildings (the Romanian Embassy is my favorite), and easy access to the Prague Castle, the Charles Bridge, St Nicholas Cathedral, and Our Lady Victorious Cathedral where you'll find the Infant of Prague.

Lesser Town. the hotel i stayed at was in Lesser Town and I would definitely stay there again as its much quieter than Old Town. nearby attractions include Prague Castle with St Vitus Cathedral, St Nicholas Church, Charles Bridge and John Lennons wall.

Wonderful. We visited the Carmelite Church to see the figure of the Child of Prague. We wandered all the small streets, drank mulled wine, delicious, warming and cheap! Lots of Embassies in this area. Saw the John Lennon Wall and crossed the bridge where all the engaged couple place their padlocks. Up the steps then on to the Charles Bridge.
Nice area.... Make sure you find the 'Beatle/Lennon' wall, interesting to see. Too bad so much 'tagging' over the real artwork. Lots of little streets to wander, nice along the river.

A quiet and nice area to stay and visit. It is an old and elegant part of Prague where many embassies are located. We stayed in a nice hotel (Kampa Garden) situated a 5 minute walk to Charles Bridge. You can find here many landmarks as the church of St Nicholas, Lennon Wall, Charles Bridge, church of St Mary Victorious (with the Infant Jesus of Prague), Memorial to the Victims of Communism, the Kampa park, the Petrin Park and Tower. The area has many good restaurants, pubs and cafes.

Much More Interesting/ Authentic than the Other Side of Old Town. I enjoyed how much I stumbled upon attractions in Mala Strana. I was drawn to almost every street I passed, and found myself bring led by one beautiful building, or parklet, or street after another. I accidentally made my way to Prague Castle, the Franz Kafka Museum and the castle gardens. I wish I'd known how amazing this part of Prague is before traveling to the city. I certainly would have made more substantial plans to visit.

Liked it most. I've heard so much about Prague and how lovely it is. Well, this is the loveliest quarter in Prague. All the rest is just average. Just wander through the streets of the lesser quarter, and enjoy yourself.
Less Busy than Main Square. Some restaurants, independant small shops , lots of narrow streets and the approach to Charles Bridge. Petrin Park and funicular near by.

"'Old' Prague is lovely everywhere!". The walk from Charles Bridge across the Moldau through Mala Strana to Prague Castle is steep in places but beautiful everywhere. The combination of the square with St. Vitus Cathedral and the castle complex beyond is just breathtaking!
lesser quarter. lesser quarter is a wonderful place for walking, lots of sights makes the lesser quarter too interesting place. I highly recommend an evening walk

Beautiful...and a little quieter than Old Town. We stayed in Lesser Quarter and it just felt like home to us. The square was a hub of activity, but as you moved away from the square it became quieter and was simply beautiful. Definitely a good choice for us!

excellent place. I liked this place the most in Prague. It was very nice to walk up through the park to the Strakhovsky Monastery and enjoy panaramic views on Prague and the river. There were a couple of restaurants around. Nice place to look at Prague from the hill.

A fascinating and varied place, worth wandering around. More sedate than the Old Town, full of beautiful houses and gardens, some great little shops. Fun to wander round at random (but avoid the main roads like Valdsteinska at rush hours, as they get full of fumes).

Nice part of town. As a part of the city center just on the other side of Karlsbridge,it's bound to be crowded. But not as in the old town center. Much of the same atmosphere though. Plenty of nice places to eat. A narrow alley away from the main streets and the elbowroom gets much bigger. Would recommend this part of town. Either for a visit or to stay there in a hotel. Also, it's quiet at night there. Will for sure stay there next visit also.
A little gem. This is where we found the John Lennon wall and a wonderful outdoor cafe next to the water mill wheel. The chairs had sheep skins on them and also blankets to use.
Perfect!. A beautiful neighborhood, best part of Prague. Great restaurants, beautiful architecture. Don't miss the gardens.
picture perfect. beautiful old buildings full of character, cobble stone streets, restaurants, churches, with the Castle in the background.
Abolutely charming!. The architecture of the buildings and narrow and charming alleys are amazing. Restaurants, palaces, the embassies are neat.

Amazing Heritage. I was glad to be there. The settings were kept so well and the people were very nice and kind. My wife and I got very good price on Bohemia Chrystal in one of the shop in that areas. Good food and good bars.
the church where thw Infant of Prague is. Went to see Infant of Prague. We did nt know we could have viewed the costumes which are in a separate room off the church.fine church

Crazy crowded. There are things to see here - such as a few of the house signs, but I'm not sure this part of town has the charm other parts of Prague have. Way too many junkie tourist shops. And the crowds are nuts.
Hidden secrets. In Mala strana you can excitin small places, squares, palaces, restaurant and pubs. And dont miss the John Lennon wall.

Prague-delightful. all of prague is wonderful. Each of the area's that you visit prove to be perfect. The buildings, history, people; just amazing. Our visit to this part of the town was nice. We did not stay during the evening and were grateful that we choose our hotel, which was on the other side of the Charles Bridge near the castle.

Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful, breathtaking, architecture. Far less people then Old Town and The Square. Take a walk down any street and you will find shopping, restaurants, drinks, building to tour, just go and get a little lost. Take a walk up to the palace district.

Don't forget to take the side streets around this area. Fantastic, felt like I was on a film set and expecting a horse and cart to come the other way !
Found some really interesting buildings by skirting the area around the Lesser quarter, even found a local's coffee shop where local prices apply! (pastries to die for!)
romantic walk. Lesser Quarter is one of the most romantic, cozy places we ever went to..the small streets are amazing adventures for all lovers. Must see.
Wonderfull. Must see! Wonderfull, somewhat out of the way from mainstream tourist paths. Nice restaurants & pubs, something for everyone.

Lovely. It's nice to stroll along and look at alle the marvellous buildings, all the shops and perhaps grab a latte on the way ... there are so many things to look at as in the whole of Prague, really.

breathtaking buildings but full of tourist shops. Love the architecture, lunchtime concerts, castle district,Lennon peace wall,contemporary art gallery.
Dislike shops and restaurants.

Amazing city!. It sounds a little negative calling it the "Lesser Quarter" but it's really beautiful as it has the older and more traditional architecture! The prices for things here were a lot cheaper than in the more touristy areas!

Not a lesser experience!. Loved it all the way! We had to go back the second day to see everything once again! Lovely architecture, a lot of things to see and visit, lot of restaurants, cafes and stores. Something for everyone. Be aware of the thieves and don't sit down if you don't see the prices first, since some of the restaurants are quite expensive.
Spirit of history. All these little and historical houses, monuments, church, it makes such an incredible atmosphere of historic (old) town that you really need to come here when visiting Prague.
Great Archtecture. The lesser town or quarter was most impressive for it's extensive Baroque Archtecture. The Wallenstein Palace is a great example of this.

Quaint place.. As you stroll on the castle side of the Charles Bridge you have the opportunity to avoid some of the massive crowds found in the Old and New Town areas. The John Lennon Wall is an interesting work of art and the locks on the little bridge near the water wheel is also an interesting spot.

Pleasant mix of renaissance and baroque. A great area to stroll through which isnt quite as busy as the New or Old Town region, quaint and beautiful buildings mainly of the Renaissance and Baroque style with converted Burgher houses, great to walk through after visiting Prague Castle before crossing Charles Bridge into the Old Town district.

Prague's Little Side. Crossing the Gothic, stone Charles bridge (Karlův most) - which spans the Vltava - you arrive in Malá Strana (Little Side), also known as the Menší Město (Lesser Town). We spent a day of our week-long stay in Prague exploring the Malá Strana, which (among other things) is home to the Prague Castle (Pražský Hrad), Saint Vitus Cathedral (Katedrála svatého Víta), and the Franz Kafka Museum - with sculptor David Černyits's animatronic statue of a couple of guys urinating into a fountain shaped like the Czech Republic. (He also did the babies who crawl up the Žižkov TV Tower.)The lesser town square (Malostranské náměstí), and the Baroque Church of Saint Nicholas (Kostel svatého Mikuláše) - one of three churches of that name in Prague - are also worth the visit.Just as picturesque as the Old Town, with lovely views as you come down the Petrin hill.
