Lovely area!. We loved Mala Strana. We actually enjoyed it more then the Old Town! This area is truly enchanting and there's a few great attractions over there. A must see while visiting Prague!
Excellent beautiful charming. Must see... Stay on this side... No Starbucks in site...we took a personal guided tour starting from prague castle to Charles bridge.. Lots to see and take in
Nice walk around!. Nice walk around, a lot if good shops with high quality souvenirs! Also walk to Prague Castle and Gardens !

Every bit as beautiful as the old town. But remember to see the side streets, and not only Nerudova which leads from Charles Bridge to the Hradcany-area where the castle is (it is not strictly speaking part of the Malá Strana-district). It is in fact a larger area than most people realise and it covers different styles of architecture although I would say that the area immediately to the left and right of Nerudova are the most picturesque as well as the most visited. For those who remember the film Amadeus about Mozart: quite a lot of footage was shot in the small archways leading off the square in front of Sv Micklase (Nicholas) Church and further towards the top of the hill, to the left of the Hrad (Castle). By the end of September several rather rude and impatient waiters were to be found in the restaurants and cafes lining the Nerudova, so it was nicer to walk into the more quite and equally beautiful side streets. Also the prices went down. Loads of gorgeous palaces owned by the aristocracy of the Habsburg Empire, now every so often turned into embassies.
Nicer part of town. The castle, the buildings, gardens, the views, the restaurants all within a small area and also the more pleasant side of the river for a ramble.
Very Inviting. It is a very nice area to go walking and find restaurants that are not as crowded. The area is highlighted by the castle district at the top of the hill.
great!. Very nice district with a lot of nice palaces that host feregin countreis embasses like Germany, USA, Poland or UK.Great gardens!Also many good restaurants but beware st. Nicholas!

Impressive Architecture. There are quite a lot of palaces and churches in this area which are impressive to look a but there are also some fabulous gardens where you can sit in relative peace and quiet. Take a padlock with you to attach to the Lock Bridge if you want to declare your everlasting love for someone and a felt tip pen to add your name to the lennon wall.
Wonderful district. We had or hotel accommodations here. Perfectly located for the Metro, buses, bridge, museums, restaurants and other tours!

Great. We loved this area, loads of narrow streets and authentic. Also not super busy which as relaxing. Also great prices for drinks and food! Watch out for the narrow staircase with traffic lights, it takes you to a bar/restaurant that overlooks the river. Fantastic. Our favourite place! X

A nice walk to a different area of Prague. Not as exciting as Old Town and found more shops and tourist venues. Once was enough to visit. Homes on the hill are interesting and very large compared to the old section.

LesserTown sooo beautiful and romantic. Located on the left bank of the river Vltava. This is very romantic, beautiful part of the city. Number of old, historical houses, palaces, churches, cozy coffee shops and restaurants. And famous Nerudova street - if you keep walking up to the hill you will reach majestic Prague Castle and Cathedral. Amazing view of the city from here! This is really something.
Closest to Castle. cleanest part of the city with fewer touristy places--great cafes and restaurants and easy access to Castle and St. Charles Bridge.
beautiful. beautiful place with lots of interesting history and architectural details. people are helpful lots of cobblestones wear flat shoes

Beautiful . Prague is filled with beautiful buildings, the Lesser town being no exception. In my opinion, if you weren't planning on visiting here when coming to Prague, what were you planning on doing? It's over the Charles bridge and below the Castle, it's very difficult to miss! There is also a spectacular tram system and a metro stop. Look out for the symbols above front doors, it tells you the occupation of someone who use to live there.

Highlight!!. Mala Strana (along with Stare Mesto) was perhaps the tourist highlight of our visit to Prague. Yes there are interesting back alleys and lane-ways in other parts of the world but none that we've visited anywhere that enjoy the old-world atmosphere that Mala Strana and Stare Mesto have in spades!Pros: Very tidy and clean, easy access by tram and a pleasant walk, great variety of restaurants (sensible prices - some would say cheap), architectural menagerie (lots of photo opportunities), quieter than Stare Mesto and a great selection of shops. Cons: Shopping was perhaps a little too convenient for my wife!!Don't miss Mala Strana ..... it's a highlight!!

Worth the walk. Be sure to cross the Charles Bridge and enjoy the sites and restaurants in the Lesser Quarter. You are sure to find a cute outdoor cafe and if you have the strength you can continue walking to the Castle on the hill.

Picture-Postcard Antiquity. This oldest section of Prague is a magical place to visit. Located below Prague Castle, it's an easy downhill walk from the castle area, and leads to the famous, 14th century Charles Bridge. The buildings in Mala Strana are the oldest in all Prague. Now, beautifully restored to their historic splendour, many will awe you with their art work and statuary. This area is also the site of the John Lenon Memorial Wall, and of numerous boutique hotels, restaurants and coffee shops. If you choose to partake of these however, be prepared to pay almost the Paris- level price. The crowds can be overwhelming in summer. Consider an early-morning, or late afternoon stroll, or visit in the off-season for a more relaxed experience.Peter and Gaye. Victoria, B.C., Canada

nice neighborhood. the second old neighborhood of Prague. It is the neighborhood that surrounding the castle district. I would suggest to you, to take the tram No. 22 (stop called Pražský hrad) to the castle entrance, then leave it by walking down the castle stairs to Mala Strana and then walk around the area.

small quarter, a lot of attractions. on the small Quarter you have what to see. starting from the famous street, over cathedral and castles and palaces.everything is within walking distance, within the Lesser Quarter. And therefore the map in his hands and walking
Beautiful area. Jazz musicians, beautiful cafes, colorful houses and candy odour in the air. Wander around this area and live your fairytale!
Nicest part of Prague. Nice and relaxed after the tourist traps in the Old Town etc. nice restaurants and a chilled out atmosphere.
Lesser Quarter. I didn't find this as interesting as Old Town Square,not so much to do, but it had some good eating places

Shopping Galore. Shopping and history mixed together. Ideal shopping area and plenty of historic buildings to visit. It gets crowded by 10.00am Great atmosphere. Plenty of restaurants to choose from and food prices are reasonable.
Mala strana. We crossed the King Charles Bridge and walk to Mala Strana. It is not as nice as Stare Mestro, but the St. Nicolas Chruch.

Very pretty - calmer and less touristy. A nice break from the really busy areas but just as pretty in its own way and includes some other sights that are listed in their own right. Have a wander between Charles Bridge and the Castle, it will take you a few hours and is well worth it.
Something new in every corner. Great food here(personally felt it was better than Old town), lots of things to do here too. A lot of roads leading to new places to visit...

Less congested. We saw this area from the bridge and the team and wanted to go back. We liked to walk around here because it was less crowded then the old town area. Its also a great spot to take pictures of the streets.
Misnamed Area of Prague. Definitely not "lesser". Should have maybe been named smaller but not lesser. Jammed packed with beautiful parks and buildings that you will enjoy wandering through.
Nice. The best views of Charles bridge can be seen here in the afternoon. Just go to the riverside near the Kafka Museum, or in the Kampa Island.
Much to see. Called the lesser quarter but there is not less to see. Anywhere you are in Prague there are architectural wonders. Here is no exception, in fact it's exceptional.

busy. busy most times, quite hilly with narrow streets, lots of street cafes.
Touristy. The main church is a 'must see' ... incredible
Intresting. We walked all the way from the castle, go through the garden and wonderful view of the river. The street not so packed with tourist.

"Old Europe". Lots of lovely cafés - try to avoid the main runways.
The castle is of course a must, but very crowded even in the afternoon. A nuisance: gift shops all over the place.

Great. The Lesser Town, also known as the Lesser or Little Quarter, clusters around the foothills of Prague Castle, across the river from the Old Town.The Lesser Town (Malá Strana) is almost too picturesque for its own good - with its ancient burgher houses, quaint side streets and St. Nicholas Church, the Lesser Town is a favourite setting for movies and commercials.Prague is a compact city, so walking from the Lesser Town to the Old Town or New Town is easy. Indeed the centre of the Lesser Town, the Lesser Town Square, is only 10 minutes walk from the centre of the Old Town, the Old Town Square.

Great neighborhood!. A great neighborhood in Prague we found ourselves returning to again and again. Transportation there is easy, and it is picturesque. Sadly, it's not a quiet area since everyone else has also heard how awesome it is. There are plenty of Al Fresco restaurants and cafes, so hit one up and enjoy the people-watching!

A grand circuit of greenery, palaces and the top view over the city. While other areas of Prague have given themselves over to commerce and relevant / irrelevant commercialism, Mala Strana keeps its own counsel , remaining serene & mysterious even as tourists pour down its main artery, Neru Dova street. This is an area for exploring stairways, alleys and side-streets just to see where they go. Sometimes, what appears to be a small place from the street, can open into a large subterranean space inside. We adopted as our starting point the overlook at Prague castle. A cascade of red-tiled roofs drops to the spires and domes of St Nicholas and the church of Our lady Victorious, and beyond .... half of the eastern side of the city is visible. Down a short cobble-stoned length of Ke Hradu, followed by a hairpin turn to the left and you find yourself at Nervdova, an appealing mix of shops and restaurants and palaces. At the bottom of the hill, Nervdova opens into a large square, home to the Performing Arts Academy where we were treated to a lunchtime concert. Onto St Nicholas church which is very beautiful, after which lunch was the order of the day under the colonnade. Working off lunch was easy with Wallenstein Gardens, aviary, fountains leading to Wallenstein Palace, a massive Romanesque and baroque confection housing parliament. Our journey wend towards Kafka's Museum, after which it was time to spend the arvo exploring the riverside walk.

a great and romantic area - a must visit!!!. walk around these ancient streets and take time to enjoy, find a café and a restaurant to relax, if you can avoid the crowds and visit the gardens which hide behind the walls.
equal beauty. this part of Prague has an equal beauty with the old town area but less crowded. offices, residential and other establishments are also here.
The other side. Likes the individual shops and beautiful architecture and nothing to dislike. Many cafés and restaurants to choose from and handmade arts and crafts

Great Neighborhood of Tiny Streets for Walking/Shopping. We stayed twice in this neighborhood and I truly prefer it to the more crowded old town square. The area is much more quiet and the restaurants are superb.
Nice to visit. Nice to see. It is close to wencelas square and na prikope street, a very goo d street for the people that love shopping.
Pretty. Stayed in this area. About 20 mins walk to the main square in Old Town. Very pretty area with a park nearby and some lovely eateries
Amazing. Across the Charles bridge to the Lesser Quarter with the castle and the cathedral and so many towers and fantastic architecture.

My favorite neighborhood to stay in Prague. Absolutely charming, plenty of green space, and quieter than Old Town; great location right in between the Castle Quarter and Old Town/New Town/Jewish Quarter.

location location. great base right at Charles Bridge. Our hotel was just at the bridge. Tram 22 from the square takes you straight to castle. You can, if you like, get off at the castle hunting lodge as the gardens are quiet and beautiful, A short walk, with different perspective of St Vitus takes you to castle. A thirty minute tram ticket costs 24K. Over 70s travel free.
Great anbience. Reminiscent of Montmartre Quartier in Paris. The walk around and down to the riverside and the Charles 1V bridge had a great ambience, especially after dark Very safe area.

Pretty and less crowded. If you go up after the bridge, it will get much more quiet than the hectic Old Town Square. The buildings are pretty with soft colors and cobblestone streets. A lot of restaurants and souvenirs along the way, but still nice to stroll around here.

Mala Strana. Well worth a visit. Wallenstein Gardens and Senat are free to visit and the gardens are lovely. Also worth taking Tram 22 from this area for a good overall view of the city. A 90 minute ticket (32 cz crowns) should cover the each way route.
Tourits trap. Beautiful, old buildings well worth a visit, but so many tourists. Stay away from tourist shops and restaurants. Much better in other parts of Prague.
Quaint. Lovely, quaint little cobbled streets, with an abundance of boutiques and bars and restaurants. Bit hilly mind you
Mala Strana. Feast your eyes on the building, but don't waste time on the generally cheapjack shops, and you will derive more pleasure from slipping down side streets than staying on the main roads

Lots to see and do. Just across a bridge from Staromestska metro and near another metro. Kafka museum, lots of restaurants and souvenir shops. A bit less crowded than the old town area, which is welcome.
Full of History. Nice stroll with beautiful architecture and history. Grab a coffee or a glass of wine and just gaze at the beauty.

Thats a busy place. Lots of shops and cafes kinda close to the Pallidum which is a modern 3 floors with a food court on the top floor, rotary sushi and things and spacious. When a Czech says close take it with a grain of salt. learn your trams and where the go its cheap and fast.

Brilliant area!. We love walking around the Mala Strana area as there is so much to do with lovely bars, cafes and shops everywhere and it is a great place to people watch. It is perfect for walking up the hill to the castle area and you will get some great photo opportunities.

Lesser is Better.... A great experience on the way up... If you can, walk it all the way up to the palace where you will surely get some great pictures of Prague...
Enjoy
Very beautiful.. You coils spend a whole day here just people watching. It has everything very confidently in a very compact area so not much walking needed but steep hills . A must

Straight out of a fairy tale. So gorgeous, and medieval, you'll feel you've travelled back a couple of centuries if you see it in the early morning. Whether you're a culture vulture or a hip trendy traveller, this is the place to be. Also great fun to hike up the mountains to the TV tower. Loved it
wondeful place to eat. Many restaurants and great value shopping. Visit the Palladium, walk down to Wenceslas square. Prague is so special. I am going back.

A pleasant escape from the crowds. I spent one afternoon wandering through Mala Strana, and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. It is, as many have noted, difficult to navigate ... even with a map I found it difficult to find my way through the maze of streets, but often the most interesting walks occur when you get lost or make a wrong turn! in general, there are are many green spaces, renaissance houses, baroque churches, cafes and restaurants to see and visit. Some specific 'must sees' include the Lennon Wall, Kampa Park, St. Nicholas church, Wallenstein Palace gardens, and the Church of Our Lady Victorious.Mala Strana is by no means 'tourist free', but it is still a pleasant escape from the throngs that frequent the main square. Wear a good pair of shoes (standard advice for Prague!), take a map (It will be of some help), enjoy the sights and sites and be prepared to get lost ... finding your way out is half the fun.

Mala Strana. This is a great place to walk. Along the river you will see buildings dating back to the 17th century. Charming cobblestone back and side streets with restaurants, cafes and bars will persuade you to sit down and watch Prague go by. Lots to do and see including the KGB museum and the Lennon Wall.

Going back, again.... We decided to return for the 5th time, 2002, 04, 06, 10, now 14. Still a lot to be seen, photographed and wandered. Always great to see what changed. Stay in an apartment on Vlasska. If I tell more, I'll be giving up a great place to the masses. lol
so much to see. lots to do and see. sit and relax with a glass of wine or coffee or buzz around like a culture vulture all up to you thats the very thing about this city.

GREAT NEIGHBOURHOOD. Our bed and breakfast was on this side of the river so we spent a lot of time here wandering the streets and going into the mostly junky tourist shops. We ate in this area 5 times out of the 6 nights we were in Prague, so the restaurants are pretty good. It is but a short walk up to the castle or to the Charles Bridge. You can easily go to Kampa Park under the bridge as well.While it is still a busy area, it is definitely less frenetic than the Old Town.
Pretty section over the Charles Bridge. Take a walk over the Charles Bridge from Old Town to this lovely section--most important thing to remember: Comfortable shoes--tons of walking!

Peaceful and lovely neighborhood. We stayed in this area and it was perfect, as it was close to plenty of restaurants, great attractions, and most importantly, away from all the crowds and noise. Make sure to visit the Lennon Wall, as it is living art, representing the Czech people’s desire for freedom. John never lived in Prague, but the ever changing wall became a symbol of hope. Bring a marker with you as you can actually draw or write on the wall. If you are lucky, you might find a musician playing Beatle songs. The Lennon wall is close to Prague Castle, the St. Charles Bridge, and Old Town Square, so there is plenty to do after visiting this beautiful work of art.
Restaurants,shops and more. The most famous St.Nicholas church is here but plenty of stores,restaurants,narrow streets to wonder around.
Loved it. Very beautiful piece of architecture in here. Loved it. For me, this was best part of Prague. Very vibrant with great gothic touch

Glad we stayed on this side. We were at a hotel on this side of the river 3 days and only ventured to the other side twice. Only 5 minutes from Charles Bridge there are quiet streets and cozy restaurants with good Czech food.

beautiful area. If you go over charles bridge towards the castle go to the left at the end and walk along the streets where you we see some lovely buildings and it gets you away from the busyness of Prague

Wonderful walk after crossing the Charles Bridge. Though we saw only a fraction of the area, we thoroughly enjoyed the shops, embassies, and general architecture. A bite of pastry just over the bridge and a visit to Marionety Truhlar's puppet shop was fun and relaxing.
Peaceful sanctuary away from madness of Old City. Nice area of Prague to relax away from the crowds. The place to stay if you want to get some sleep at night

Mala Strana. An interesting part of Prague between the Old City and Wenceslas Square. The square is a divided city street leading to the national museum with a statue of the saint at the south end. Wander around. Note the Franciscan garden, a quiet refuge from the businesses.

Surpises. We hardly scratched the surface if this area and yet were continually surprised by the delights and sights of this area.
It's a case of turning every corner and saying "Oh wow look at that"
Nice part of Prague. Lots of nice eateries and shops along the way to the Charles Bridge. If you are a Beatle fan, the Lennon wall is great.
Best part of Prague. The last mohican, the last part of Prague still keeping the genius loci… at least in the less busy parts.

Find the Time. I know that there is so much to see in the beautiful old city of Prague but plan on 2-3 hours wandering the streets of the Lower Quarter where the narrow roads and Renaissance houses are a wonderful place to walk and explore. We ate lunch on the square and then walked to shopping and a visit to the Our Lady of Victory Church to view the Infant Jesus. It is an easy walk back into Prague across the Charles Bridge.
worth a visit. great to stroll round with the history and excellent squares. Quiet and beautiful as well as historical
Great Area!. We liked this area of town- a little less busy than the other side of the bridge. We stayed at the Archibald at the Charles Bridge and liked this location.
A quiet street. We walked from Petrin Hill to the street, which was nearby.The street was quiet when we went, maybe because it is a Saturday. It was relaxing nevertheless.
Good deals. Interesting place to visit, for sure prices were significantly lower, so we ate and stay there taking tram to the old town as needed.
Nice area. Would like to go back there if we visit Prague again as there seemed to be a great variety of restaurants to choose from.

More and more tourists living here now.. The Mala Strana area is very lovely. Many tourists who come for a short visit often miss out spending time here as they are concentration on Old Town square.The ancient houses are really nice and most hotels are set in ancient buildings.Many people prefer staying here as it is quieter and more beautiful than other parts of the town. The side roads are cobbled and I was told that a visit at night will make you feel as if you are in ancient Prague as these cobbled lanes are lantern lit. The churches, the cafes, the pubs and the atmosphere make this side of Prague a lovely area to take a stroll and have a meal.If you walk from Old Town square, you can reach here in just 15 minutes.Once you are at the Mala Strana square you can walk on the delightful Nerudova Street up which you can walk to reach the castle district, the Church of St. Nicholas, Petrin Hill, and the Wallenstein Gardens.The residential area is not very far as you walk in this area of Mala Strana. The houses are lovely and one would be much better off coming here to the restaurants for nice meals. The Old town is a tourist trap and though the atmosphere is good, the food is very mediocre at a very hefty price. Here, you would get great food at half the price !While you are there, don't miss the John Lennon wall !

lovely everywhere you turned you found something interesting. Quiet, cultured, interesting - the streets are maze like and I am not good with orienting myself in a new city especially not in two days. An architectural style which with the blazing sun made me feel I was in Seville not Prague.
Favourite part of Prague. My Favourite part of a Prague. Small colourful streets, full of atmosphere and history. Lovely to stroll though. Every corner you turn, you are met with more beauty.

Traditional quarter. Mala Strana has everything you need in Prague and is my most favorite quarter of Prague. The narrow street with their street lightning is like stepping hundred of years back. It's like beiging in a story straight out of a Charles Diken's book. Malay Strana is full of small shops, cozy cafés and great restsaurants but beware of Palffy Palac. It used to be the crown of restaurants in this area and I always ended a great Prague trip there. But no more!
Worth a visit. Less touristed than Old Town Square. Lots of beautiful buildings on cobbled streets. Beautiful Baroque Vrtbovská zahrada garden hidden down alleyway on Karmelitska street recommended.

Less manic !. Our hotel was in Lesser Quarter. I love this place. It is quieter than the Old town but still as historic. We made lots of friends here and there are lots of nice places to eat. The tram service at Malostranska was where we returned to our hotel at night.

touristy and not much to see. I have been here a couple of times, but I really have not discovered what all the fuss about. It is a typical tourist district near a historic area, similar to the area surrounding the Louvre and Tuilleries in Paris. It seems attractive but actually nothing much there.
Lesser Quarter. Called Lesser Quarter, but in fact, better quarter. We stayed in this part of the city and loved it. The views are awesome, the food diverse and shoping great.
Food in the Lesser Quarter excellent. Such a lovely part to walk around down by the river easy to get there on the Tram have a drink out at the river bank

The real spirit of Prague. While Stare Mesto is overcrowded with tourists Mala Strana gives you more impression of real Prague. You can simply walk around narrow streets, watch local people, drink some beer and eat something tasty. Here you have more time to stand and stare.
Worth the walk. Go back in time on a walking tour from the Prague Castle area down and through the Lesser Quarter, amazing!! (and it's all downhlll)

Best place to stay. Spend a week at a wonderful small hotel, Hotel Petre. Loved Mala Strana in that there was so much green space and many wonderful gardens. No where near as crowded with tourists as other areas.
Excellent. All of the Imperial embassies had their palaces here, and the architecture is stunning. Very hilly, perched under the walls of Prague Castle. Beautiful.

A charmingly beautiful area of Prague.. Mala Strana is an absolutely beautiful and charming area of Prague. Walking down on Nerudova Street from Prague Castle, you enter an architecturally beautiful area. The beautiful buildings, to the winding cobble-stoned streets and lanes, down to St. Nicholas Church and the Church of Our Lady of Victory, to the Maltese Monastery and the John Lennon Wall, down to Kampa Island, this area is amazingly beautiful, and wonderfully charming.
explore wonderful crafts. glass, wood, pottery, paintings , pastries and homemade beer all waiting for you in a long beautiful nerodova st. on your way to the castle

beautiful cobblestone streets. we stayed in lesser town at the foot of the charles bridge. it was a wonderful location. there are shops, restaurants, drinking places, a grocery store, and most of prague's tourist sites within walking distance. the history and architecture of the area is awesome.

My favorite part of Prague. Before arriving I had thought that the Old Town had to be the better part. But I was pleasantly surprised by the charm of the Lesser Quarter. Lots of places to eat and shop. Quaint streets to explore and easy to get around. Stay in this part and explore from here!
Great place to stay. Our hotel was in Mala Strana - lots of nice and cheap places to eat and get drinks etc. Easy to get around to the other places in Prague. A great place to stay.
Lovely. Mala Strana is a charming area of Prague to stroll around. Not as many tourists here compared to other parts of the city. Some good little bars and eateries here as well.

Romantic place. A place to get lost in, not too crowded with tourist, with cafeterias and bars with reasonable prices. Good place to go to for a walk and for lunch. I recommend the Fat mouse restaurant, hidden in one small street not far from Ujezd.
Very Charming Part of Prague. This part of Prague is very charming, and not quite as jam packed as the main square in the old town side. Definitely cross the bridge and check out this area.

A place to wander. When you cross the Charles Bridge going towards the Castle take the first turning on the left and lose the crowds! The Lesser Quarter has many nice spots to see including the John Lennon Wall, If you get down towards the river there are lovely views of the Charles bridge and the Old Town and there are places for a quiet stop to recuperate and watch the world go by.

Very Posh. This is in my opinion the posh side of the city, very stylish hotels, restaurants, and the small island that makes the so calle Prague little venice nice and relaxing at both day end evening times

An area with beautiful palatial gardens and great places to eat. This is definitely the part of town that we'll stay in on our next visit to Prague. It's at the center of everything. It has great places to eat, and beautiful palatial gardens to walk through. It's near the Charles Bridge which takes you to Old Town. On the other side of Mala Strana is the Castle District. You have great views of the castle from Mala Strana. Our only regret was that we only had a day in Prague, and didn't get to see everything. Our tour guide started our journey in the Castle District. It was perfect for my 80+ year old mother. Our walk through Prague was all a physical down hill trek from that point. Mala Strana played a great role that day. It ended up being more of a rest spot for us in between the castle and Old Town. Our guide took us to Restaurant U Glaubicu in Mala Strana square where we had a traditional Czech meal. It was a wonderful local experience that we will never forget. This part of town provided a great diversion from all the touristy parts of town. This is also where we sampled our first taste of Becherovka. That little shot of local liqueur kept us going as we crossed over the Charles Bridge into Old Town. I'd imagine it keeps everyone warm in the winter months. Don't hesitate to book a hotel here if you like to be in a calmer place (away from the masses of people).

Not really lesser at all. It is not lesser to Old Town but a little different and worth an explore. Plenty of good eating places and a different view of Prague. Get there via the Charles Bridge for full effect.

Just after a bridge.... A lot less tourists here and it is still beautiful and worth to know. This is the place where we chose our hotel to be really close but a little away from the hectic rhythm of the other side of the bridge... 10 minutes walk only ..

Nothing special, but Strahov Seminary. Nothing special to see there. If you are plenty of time, ok, you can enjoy the park and even climb the Petrin Tower. But the Strahov Seminary deserves a visit, even considering the restrictions about taking pictures.

Great Place to stay. Mala Strana is a lovely place to stay in Prague quieter than the old town but still walking distance from the Charles Bridge. It has lots of different types of restaurants including a wonderful vegan restaurant called 'Lo veg'. It has bars/pubs that sell local beer and everybody is really friendly apart from a few café/ restaurants on the hill leading up to the castle (staff in these places are pushy and rush you) so just keep walking down hill from the castle where there are plenty of nice place to eat and drink in a relaxed atmosphere. Everywhere will close around 10.30 so a good place if you like early nights and not being disturbed by revellers.

Great for walks. Just wonderful if you want to feel the spirit of the Middle-Aged Europe. There you'll see and hear street singers and even whole orchestras, eat traditional food and (of course!) drink some beer! Don't forget to visit the swans! They are graceful, beautiful and quite friendly.
Old Prague. This was the place where all the stories happened. Wonderful place and so many people. Small roads and nice pubs.History on every corner.

A new surprise in every little alley. My wife and I stayed in a delightful penzione in the Mala Strana just 1/2 block from the Kampa garden on a small island in the Vltava river and found that taking walks down each of the small street gave us something different and interesting to see in each one of the streets, sometimes a church, sometimes a new restaurant or bar or coffee shop or just a wonderful view of the river etc. we will definitely be going back and staying in the Mala Strana again.

Not to be missed. We walked from the old town to this area of Prague. What a lovely area with beautiful buildings round every corner.Don't miss the steps coming off the Charles Bridge, which go down to a canal, as well as a park which runs along the side of the river. This area is much quieter than the main drag, but equally as lovely.

Nice place to stroll around. This area is nice place to stroll around.We basically pass through this area on the way to the famous Strahov Monastery.There also we can find a lot of restaurant and typical Prague wooden toy souvenirs shop which is very interesting for my daughter.Indeed, it is a good place to hang around while you are in Prague.But please just be ready that the road is going upward so sometimes for old people it can be tiring.
Busy but nice. Wonderful restaurants, street artists, terrasses and beer :)Take a view on top of the tower of the astronomical clock, great place to be and to hang out

Easy to get lost. It's quite easy to get pleasantly lost, especially after some Czech beer. Streets are narrow and curvy, buildings are beautiful and bars have nice beer, so it's actually really good to get lost there.

The only area we would stay if we return to Prague. Without really knowing a thing about where to stay, we booked a hotel the Lesser Quarter. It was just a 5 minute walk up to the castle and 10 minutes to the Charles Bridge, but significantly quieter and less crowded than the East side of the river!

don't overlook Mala Strana. We spent most of a day wandering the streets. The quarter burnt down in the early 1500s (?), so it was re-built in Baroque style. Wonderful churches, restaurants, buildings, gardens, you name it, and not nearly as crowded as the old city centre, although it is at the end of the Charles Bridge.
Adorable!. We were just wandering around Prague and stumbled upon here. It was lovely and highly suggest visiting there!

The great Other half of Old Prague. The Lesser Quarter of old Prague, combined with the Old Historic Quarter, epitomizes what pre War, historic, Europe must have been like. It's Cathedrals, Concert Halls, narrow old cobble-stone streets, towers, exquisite as well as 'take-out' restaurants, bakeries, & spires, as well as it's many shops, make it a great place to visit. Combine this with the Old Historic area across the Charles Bridge, & it's difficult to envison a more enjoyable city in Europe to visit. p.s. as we left Prague at 4:30 a.m, the streets were filled with the young crowd finishing up the night. Prague has a very lively night life!
Just walk!. There are hundreds of small shops, coffe shops and interesting things to see without naming one. Coming down from the castle on foot, walk until you are too tired to continue.
Ancient relicts in the heart of Europe. You can see medieval citizen buildings, churches and meet amazing athmosphere there. Cozy restaurants, many of them with amazing sights.
Stroll. Lovely buildings and just a nice place to wander taking in all the architecture stopping for a drink or one of the amazing ice creams

Another part of Prague. You've come to Prague and you want to see what there is to see. You aren't going to miss Mala Strana in your wanderings so reviewing it in Trip Advisor seems irrelevant. It is another piece of the magic that Prague makes and however one rates it, you want to be there to see and to feel it. Just give serious thought to coming off season to avoid the hordes of tourists jamming every restaurant, bar and cafe and crowding the streets and squares.,

Busy, lots of tourist trinket shops. We stayed near to this area and walked through it many times. It's touristy, I prefer the back streets with less of these shops and more relaxed cafés with locals.

A must-see. The lesser quarter has it all: wonderful architecture, lots of history, cute little shops, narrow cobble-stoned picture-perfect alleys, lots of restaurants and coffee-shops!
The perfect palce to spend an afternoon!

Lesser quarter. Good to walk around, lots of interesting architecture and good view from monastery,
Took walking tour to help fill in the gaps and would recommend this

Like a step back in time. I would imagine that Americans views of Europe could be summed up by a visit to the Mala Strana. Narrow cobbled streets, baroque buildings, old men with mustaches standing in doorways staring at passers by. Beautiful part of Prague, an area where the top attractions in the city are to be found, Charles Bridge, Prague Castle, Kafka Museum etc. Bars and restaurants are in plentiful supply and they are much cheaper here than in the Old Town Square.
Beyond expectations.. Everyone knows Prague as a fantastic city. We were prepared for that. But this elegant, upscale quarter surpassed all our expectations. Splendid elegance in a wonderful city.

Good central location for all the sights. Central location within short walking distance of most of the must see sights. It is less crowded than the Old Town but does get busy in and around the area of Charles Bridge. There are some beautiful buildings to see including Prague Castle. There are many restaurants and bars some of which are cheaper than the Old Town. Good walking shoes are a must as the area has some steep roads to walk particularly towards the Castle area. Lots of shops en route for those needing some retail therapy in between sight seeing. Don't miss out on this part of the city.
Lots of activity. Excellent for sightseeing, loads to see and do. full of restaurants and museums.As for all Prague, use good comfortable shoes.Don`t miss it!

The best place to be. Discover this part of Prague - Wallenstein Palace and gardens, the Senate building and river side cafes and stroll towards the Castle. The old buildings and by ways wonderful - by no means the Lesser Quarter as it is sometime known as! Away from many of the crowded and tattier down market tourist haunts.

Good for a wander. This is nice neighbourhood for a more peaceful walk and coffee away from the more touristy places. Visited the John Lennon wall and saw all the locks on the bridge. Gardens are very pretty.

Mala Strana, Prague. Great neighborhood to have relaxing morning coffee and to explore the beautiful, hictoric city of Prague. Lots of great places to see in this area: the Petrin Hill, Prague Castle, Wallenstein Palace and it's garden... and lots of places to eat and drink as well, although most of them close before 10pm. Famous Karlův most aka Charles Bridge is right next to this area. Staying in hotel on Mala Strana area is good idea, if you want to be near by everything yet having a peaceful place to sleep. Many trams stop here and metro station is only a short walk away, so getting around and to the other side of the river Vltava is easy.
good place to spend the afternoon. best part of the town, with lots of shops, restaurants, homes to see, gardens to see. The senate gardens is a hidden gem.

just lovely. The hills offer a good work out!. Once again fantastic Prague, like walking in an open air museum. We went early in the morning, the views were a bit misty and late in the afternoon. The Charles bridge is best walked before 10am.

Very good place to walk and enjoy life. It is a very charming neighborhood, close to everything and with a amazing views to the city. It was one of our finest experiences in Prague. It was certainly much better and calmer than the old town. I cross my fingers that it remains this way for my next trip in Prague. It would be a pity that this beautiful quarter also suffers the effects of massification. Please Prague's authorities "keep Mala Strana calm."

Stay here instead of in the Old Town!. After walking around in both the Old Town and Lesser Side for several days, it seems the atmosphere speaks in favor of the Lesser Side. Perhaps less convenient in terms of public transport, but much more unique environment and less crowded.
Beautiful Place. Beautiful place! So many marvelous buildings that you should have a big memory card on your camera. Go with time, to enjoy everything.

WORTH THE VISIT. We enjoyed walking and taking pictures, so from Stare Mesto,the old town, we cross the Charles Bridge and have been at Lesser Quarte, Mala Strana, as is called. More quiet than the old part, with beautiful buildings as well, clean, with cafe-restaurants and a nice small park, where had relax.Worth the visit.

Loved the quieter neighborhood. We stayed in Lesser Quarter and loved it. It is a perfect location for visiting everything. Not only can you walk to everything, but there are Trams available too. We found many good restaurants and shops to enjoy. We will definitely stay there the next time we visit.
Worth a visit. Beautiful area of the city, nice for an evening stroll if the sun is shining. Beware of pickpockets when busy.

Definately Worth Seeing For A Quieter Time. The atmosphere around the old streets of the Lesser quarter is much more relaxed and quieter than anywhere else in the city. There doesn't seem to be as many tourist groups marching by as there is in the old town. We had lunch in a few places around here and it was nice just to sit out in the sun with a few beers on the old streets with no hustle and bustle that you get when you visit the old town square for example.
Lovely. Stayed in the lesser quarter and had a great time, so much to see, but be prepared and take comfy shoes you do a lot of walking.

stayed in the lesser quarter. we stayed at the hotel kampa garden right in the middle of the distric and found the whole area fantastic, you have the charles bridge and only a 20 min walk to the castle, there is a small park and lots of places to eat and drink
Lovely small district underneath the castle.. Lovely lovely area to wander around. Wear comfortable shoes as there are lots of small cobblestones and steps.

Nice to walk. Nice are to walk though, though it feels a bit of a tourist trap. Having had several good meals in and near old town, we elected to not eat whilst there, and went back to other good places to eat. I don't know if the mid-river island is considered part of the lesser quarter, but it is worth going down the stairs and walking though this quiet area. I would return and bring friends for a walk here.

A great place to base yourself in Prague. This historic quarter is close to all the Prague sites and has a great atmosphere. Our apartment in Trziste was fabulous and in walking distance to the castle, Charles bridge, restaurants and trams.

A nice spot to wander. Cute shops, nice cafés, wonderful architecture and quirky little finds. It was fun to spot the houses that still bore their pre-numbered signs: how of the three violins, house of the two suns, house of the white swan, house of the medusa and so on. The gingerbread museum was a cute, free spot to dash through and grab a little something to sample.

A beautiful stroll. Had an amazing morning wandering around this place. we had no map and just walked, can't get lost as you end up back to Charles Bridge, it's easy to gage by looking at Prague castle. Stunning views, nice cafe finds, beautiful architecture….a must visit
nice to see. nice to go and see the area with its ashtromical clock which strikes every hour and figureens move in /out while clock strikes bars are very expensive in this area
Nice walking around. I prefer this quarter of Prague over the even more tourist-busy Old City, the Stare Mesto. The castle is close, nice little restaurants.

Kampa island. This is a hidden gem. Explore the hidden island of kampa island with it winding canals and the artist shops. There is even the john lennon wall for you to have your picture taken by. This the place to go for the best meal in town Kampa Park with its mitchellin star restaurant visited by the stars. The service is amazing there as too is the views over the river
Winding cobblestone streets. With many shops and eateries, the Lesser quarter has a romantic feel, the entry over the Charles bridge and through the Tunnel is dramatic and stunning

What Prague used to be like!. I have been visiting Prague on and off for over 25 years and in my last couple of visits, I've noticed how commercialised and crowded the old city has become with a proliferation of tacky souvenir shops and fast food places, especially in the roads between the Charles Bridge and the Old Town Square!However, the Lesser Quarter still feels to me like "Old Prague" with interesting shops, wonderful buildings and architecture, and hardly any people! Start in the square outside the castle and walk across to the wall which overlooks the city - a wonderful view (if the weather is good) and it's free! Then take the road down to the right - its quite steep and the cobbles can be slippery in wet/icy weather.This will take you down into Nerudova where you can wander gently down the hill. When you reach Malostranska Square, do go into the church of St Nicholas - a riot of Baroque decoration ( there is an admission charge) and then continue on down Mostecka which will bring you down to the Charles Bridge. On your way down from the castle, explore the side streets - some hidden gems of buildings and palaces, and some friendly little cafes and restaurants. A lovely area and well worth exploring.

quite spot at night. I suppose February is out of season, but this part of the city is perfect for an evening stroll, as we had the streets to ourselves. We visited the Lennon Wall, which some say is spoilt but I thought was vibrant and unexpected. There are many pieces of sculpture here, including the babies with disturbing faces and the peeing men! You can find busy bars and quiet coffee shops and I liked this part of the city a great deal. And don't forget to take your padlock!
Good view. It used to be a residence of aristocracy. Many embasies are located here. Nerudova street connects Lasser Town and the Castle.

St nichloas location. Go here by walking across charles bridge away from the old town and towards the castle. The Church is the highlight. One of the best i have ever seen. A must see. Lots of places to eat around this area and the british embassy is also located here. Some of you may need it ;) Hope this has helpful!

Best part of Prague. We stayed in this area of Prague for a four day visit at recommended hotel.We found this area ideal as we were only a 30 minute walk to the Castle area and there was a wide variety of shops, restaurants and cafes.It was more enjoyable than the Old Town area which was too touristy with too many tacky gift shops.
Top shops. Very nice area, nice location with lots of designer shops near Old Town Square. Very nice just to do window shopping.
A different feel..... A much more relaxed and picturesque part of Prague, plenty of little shops, restaurants etc. we preferred this part of Prague to the Old Town, not so many people either :)
Fav side of river. Love Prague our third trip but much prefer this side of the river some great resturants great views some great little gothic bars hidden away on side streets will be back .

Get to Know Mala Strana. Wander down meandering alley-sized streets to be transported back in time. Don't miss Novy Svet, a most authentic walk through medieval days. Each doorway is unique. Great way to set the mood.

Awesome. Very close to the Charles bridge and just a walk down from the castle we stumbled upon the Lesser Quarter. Very neat cobbled streets. Also came across the statue of the 2 peeing men, quite funny as they move in all directions. We also could walk down to the river and feed the swans. There's also a small area off the main streets where you can view the bridge and river.
Lovely!. Found some amazing antique books that detailed the history of prague & important architecture. Beautiful part of Prague!

Pleasant enough for the centre of Prague.. This area has ten tram routes linking it with the centre of Prague and a very large internal shopping precinct, including Tesco, M&S and Swarovski. There is also a metro station to the centre of the city. In the daytime, it might be decent but at night there are a few beggars and drug dealers.
Nice bit of town. Lots of good bars and restaurants, lots to see and far fewer tourists than Old Town. Also great views from up the hill.

Touristy, but Beautiful. Prague as a city is bursting with history, and none more than the Lesser Quarter. While it is a bit touristy, with people trying to sell you things everywhere, the atmosphere is amazing, and the buildings and statutes and sights are endless. Great way to spend an afternoon marveling at everything around you, as well as get some souvenir shopping done.
A place in Praha next to Old Town impressions. Crowds, crowds, Charles' Bridge, countless inns, toverns and restaurants, untold impressions and atmosphere of old Praha.

The road less traveled. To get away from the throngs in Old Town cross the Charles Bridge and keep on going. There will be lots of pool but it's much, much easier to bear. The walk to Prague Castle is a great one, all uphill until you come back down!

Little Gem. Spent our last day in Prague exploring this side of the river, just wished we had done it sooner. We walked over Charles Bridge and came into the Mala Strana that way. The narrow streets and little shops were nice to browse through and then St Nicholas Church was nice to look into, although we didnt go inside for a proper look. We continued up to the castle - major trek - be prepared for the hill...and the views were amazing!Having been on a tour earlier during the trip we were glad to get the chance to go back up...On our return back to the lesser town, we went to the Church of our Lady Victorious to see the Statue of the Infant of Prague. Although not dressed in the fancy costumes, the statue was part of a beautiful scene prepared for the Christmas season. The adjoining souvenir shop had all the usual medals and rosaries, and we ended up staying for an English Mass (Thursday, 5pm). It is a beautiful church with free entry and well worth a visit.
Amazing Shops. I was fascinated by the glass on sale in the shops. Bohemian glass is on sale almost everywhere you go. Shop assistants all spoke English and were very helpful.

You want to walk? You get to walk.. You'll have to walk quite a bit for this one, but then, it's already expected - how else would you admire the architecture around you, and the overall "feel" of the place? It was very busy when I visited it (on St. Nicholas Day), but I thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere. There are a few interesting shops, although the stuff sold here isn't exactly cheaper. If you're near this place, it doesn't hurt to drop by; you just might find a thing or two that captures your eye. Watch out for pickpockets though; you don't want to lose your valuables and cause a row.
A taste of Bohemia!. We loved the Barogue architecture and the mostly non-commercial perspective of Mala Strana - lovely area to walk around in the evening.

A bit more Bohemian and less polished. If you like things a little less polished and a bit more vibrant, there are some interesting shops, bars and cafes. Maybe not ideal for families, but interesting all the same

Mala Strana is not Lesser Town. Tons of things to see in Mala Strana, besides the funicular which takes you to the top of a hill so you can see all of Prague, there's St. Nicolas Cathedral, Embassy row, the statue of the Infant of Prague at Our Lady Victorious church and of course, Prague Castle and St. Vitus Cathedal. There are many small and large places to eat along the road leading to Charles Bridge. You can sample genuine Czech Food or if you are homesick, you can have a "Happy Meal" with a toy.

Lovely.. Expensive looking area in parts, narrow streets and quaint buildings alongside more elegant ones. Definitely worth a wonder round. You'll probably come across the John Lennon Wall but I wouldn't go out of your way and risk missing out on places like The Jewish Quarter for it as it's been over covered in so much colourful graffiti there is little of John left!

Beautiful. I really enjoyed the lesser quarter and the old town equally. They both had beautiful architecture and charming old buildings with winding streets. I liked that the lesser quarter wasn't as full of tourists as the old town.
anice place. we saw there the John Lennon wall. ducks and gooses in the river, the bridge with the locks on it. the place is very clean and peaceful

Beautiful part of Prague. We were fortunate to rent an apartment in this area. It was a perfect location. We were able to get away from the crowds and enjoy the city the way the locals do. We were just steps away from the river and great places to eat. Visited the Jazz Dock on our first night, which was just a block from our place - fabulous music!

Bustling. Mala Strana is always bustling, full of life/many people/tourists, lots of cafes, bazaars, peddlars, restaurants, bars with many things to do.There's action here, full of energy and vibes and the main part leading to Prague Castle via the Hills

Well worth a visit. Make sure you take the time to visit "The Lesser Quarter" which is far from what it's name implies. Lot's of lovely architecture, nice shops, parks and restaurants. Our hotel was this side of town - and we were glad it was. Take a day to stroll around here when you are bored with the hustle and bustle of the crowds on the other side of Charles Bridge.

Great place to walk around. Going down from the Prague Castle take Nerudova Street (named after Jan Neruda a local artist) and see the old houses with their symbols on the front. They were used to identify the houses before the streets numbers were used. Nice places to eat and plenty of small streets to walk through. Get lost to find beautiful places out of the touristic routes. It's easy to find the way to Charles Bridge later. It's worth a visit.

"My first choice prague as a traveller". This square, like most of Prague, is picture perfect, and very touristicy. You have all the needed stores and convenience for tourists. There are many charming alleys between beautifull renovated old houses. Nerudova street is very nice with lots of restaurants, cafes, small shops.

A very pretty part of town. Having visited the castle, I decided to take a couple of hours to wander around Lesser Town and I think it is well worth the effort.The area is generally quiet, with many beautiful houses and little alleys and squares to find. I walked up Neruda and then took a left, down some steps, into the heart of Lesser Town and just walked around for a couple of hours (with a guide book) admiring the facades on some of the buildings and stopping to look into some of the small craft shops on the way. I strolled through the town, ending up at Kampa Park, where you can get some great views, across the river.

Cute. Lesser Quarter is definitely worth a visit. We went as part of an all day tour to ensure we saw everything. We were taken down some lovely winding streets, learnt about all the history and the buildings significance. Worth the walk to get there!

Worth the Effort to see. This part of town is on a hillside so combining it with a visit to the castle will make it a little easier. see the castle first and then walk downhill through the Lessor Quarter. Lots of restaurants and places to shop.

this is where I would stay. Great, under-rated side of Prague. While the old town is all over priced, tourist driven tat, this side of the river has cute shops, great bars and restaurants, still the same amazing churches and buildings (although maybe a tad less opulent). We didn't stay here, but spent considerable time in the area. Next time I'm in Prague, this is where I would stay.

My favourite part of Prague!. Very nice part of Prague for a relaxing walk. There are many charming alleys between beautifull renovated old houses. Nerudova street is very nice with lots of restaurants, cafes, small shops.

Better than other places!. Staying in lesser town of Prague was the best decision my better half made. You are closer to all the attractions, but far enough. It to deal with the craziness of tourism. It's a bit off the beaten path if you take the time to explore all the amazing side streets that hold countless hidden gems. When I visit Prague again, I would only consider staying there, considering I've walked the rest of downtown Prague. Recommend staying in Prague for at least 3 days, so you are able to see all the sights and not be rushed.

Gorgeous. This square, like most of Prague, is picture perfect, and very touristicy. You have all the needed stores and convenience for tourists. It starts at the edge of the Charles bridge... A must when in Praha!

Stay, walk, and eat. Staying in lesser town was the best decision we made. You are literally minutes away from prague castle, St.Nicholas cathedral, and charles bridge, and the old town can be easily reached by tram and metro or just a stroll across the bridge. We stayed at hotel Sax which is in a quiet neghbourhood away from tourists and cheap trinket shops, but still just minutes away from Charles Bridge. Many great restaurants to choose from. The best part about lesser town is the walk along the river from malostraska station to Legion bridge (one south of Charles). A must do in Prague.

This is the place in Prague to go. The Old town has lots of tourists and some great sights, but get off the beaten path in Mala Strna and you will find some great little resturants and nice small attactions. An not as many fellow travelers
Beautiful. Lovely place to walk and browse. Very clean. A very good vibe, especially on an evening. Good restaurants and cafe's.

Stay in this part of town. This area of Prague, just over the river from the Old Town, is our favourite part of town to stay in. Situated only 5-10 mins walk from any of the major sights and attractions in Prague it is very convenient but also perfect in that it is that little bit away from the crowds and noise. Just the fact you have to walk over the King Charles Bridge at night time to get back there from the town centre makes it worthwhile, never mind the beauty of Mala Strana once you get there. We found ourselves just wandering around by the river or The John Lennon Wall taking in the ambience or the quirky artwork that you encounter. There are also some excellent places to eat in the area and is a stone's throw away from the castle or Petrin Park We are travelling back to Prague this November and while we are in love with the whole city, we have gone to some lengths to find a hotel specifically in this part of town. It just makes us feels so happy being there.

How was this dubbed the "lesser" quarter???. This part of Prague was hands down my favorite area to wander. Bring your walking shoes, a sense of wonder, and a camera if majestic visions don't naturally imprint themselves onto your head and heart! No matter how hard I tried to branch out I kept finding myself wandering the meandering paths of the hillside vineyard, ambling down steep hills past shops and cafes and admiring every intricate detail of a city that seems frozen in time. I visited the Gingerbread museum almost daily and even brought home a tupperware full of cookies for my kids (also there's a great ATM right outside of here that has a great exchange rate). There were so many areas that were secluded but occasionally I'd wander into a crowd of tourists and duck down another path that led to a beautiful vista or a quaint alleyway restaurant full of flowers and colors. At night when I close my eyes I dream of Prague and Lesser town, a place that part of me still remains.

Quieter side of a beautiful city. Stayed at the Charles Bridge Economic Hostel in Mala Strana. Just take a brief walk for half a block away from the bridge, and you're away from tourists in a quiet, outstanding neighborhood. Be sure to visit St. Nicholas Church (on this side of the river), especially for an evening concert.
Underrated part of town. This is a quieter, but vibrant part of town. It is less crowded than old town, so pleasanter to wander. The churches, shopping and restaurants were all fabulous!
Interesting area. We spent quite a few hours just walking around this area of Prague. Some very interesting buildings to see, and more relaxed and less hectic than the more touristy areas of Prague.
Time travel on foot. Loved the old buildings and the comfortable feel of this area. It felt as though one had been shifted one to a different time.
lesser qtr. What a fabulous place just to wander, busy, bustling, gorgous buildings, nice shops. Suggest finicular up then walk over to this area and down or tram 22 up to monostry and wlk dwn

exploring Mala Strana. Beside the Hradcani castle, must see the gardens below, and the jeweler street. Do not miss the Bambino de Prague in the Church of St Victoire, and the Kampa Museum of modern art on the river. Many other baroque churches to visit.
Take a slow walk through. Wonderful neighborhood, shops reataurants and wonderful old buildings. People are friendly and it is a safe walk, day or night.
Nice neighbourhood. Great neighbourhood to take a walk. Not as crowdy as the city center. There are plenty of places to eat or drink and there are good connections with the tramsystem.

Less crowds, lovely area. This is a lovely area on the way to the Castle, much less crowded than the other areas and great to wander the cobble stone streets and get lost. Some nice restaurants off the beaten path. If you are short on time in Prague, I would prefer Old Town and the Jewish Quarter.

Don't miss this area. It is so beautiful and charming. There are views from the hills and down the narrow streets and there is a lot of greenery. You feel like you're stumbling across hidden sights a lot. Have a look at the pictures contributed by people because it really captures the look and feel of the place. Its is less crowded and there are a lot of great places to eat and shop. We stayed a week and our hotel was in this quarter and it was really nice to be able to get away from the crowds at the end of the day.

My Fovourite Part of Prague. With slightly narrower streets and less people this was probably my favourite part of Prague. Lots of fantastic architecture and some great walks up the cobbled streets. Take time to visit the gardens leading up to the Castle.
Prague without the crowds. Mala Strana is the place to stay if you want to experience the city without the crowds. It is on the other side of the Charles bridge just below the Prague castle

A concert in style. We attended a wonderful concert in this charming palace!!! What more could one so for!!! We loved the concert, but were glad we had allowed for extra time in locating the palace & the right place for the concert!! It's a large area!!
Walk this area. Go in the St. Nicholas church and go up stairs in it. The Church of Child Jesus is great. The John Lennon Wall isn't worth it. The orginial graffihe is been painted over by new
Nice area. We walked through this area to get to the monastery - quite a walk. We stopped at a bakery and bought some ginger cookies. Cute area and streets.

Not as many historic sites, but great food and fewer people. I love to walk the side streets of the Mala Strana, just across the Charles Bridge. I think there are fewer tourists, the restaurants are better on average, and you get a sense of the real Prague. While the walk up to the castle is well marked and the route most take, it's worth exploring some of the side streets. Find the high water marks shown on the side of the buildings near the River, and visit the current exhibition of the flood damage of 2013 (walk south on the street below the Charles Bridge).

Our favourite little piece of Prague. We were so thankful we were staying in the Little Quarter area of Prague as we found it much nicer than the Old or New Town. We felt it was slightler quieter to walk around with more open spaces. It seemed more traditional Czech and full of bustling little bars and restaurants that were reasonably priced. We visited the others areas every day on our three day break but always returned to the Little Quarter for food and drinks.

love prague. loved all prague watch out for over charging taxis and people giving you the wrong change. metro and trams are the best way to get around fantastic service and worth checking out. its the only city that i dont like using taxis.

suprising and charming. A graet place to get lost in. here and there are modern sculptures, lots of green and river view. I loved the minuture museum in Strahov monastery, and the view tower in petrin hill

Home away from home. I stayed in Mala Strana, which I think is the best location in Praha. Very charming, easy to get around in and close to all the sites without the heavy crowds in Old Town, New Town and Hradcany.

Our favorite place to stay and wander. We stayed in an apartment in Lesser Quarter, not far from the Charles Bridge. It is a wonderful area of Prague. Less overwhelmed by tourists than Old Town, less filled with tourist attractions, and much more inviting for simply wandering and getting lost. The architecture is magnificent. The people are friendly and helpful. Even more than the sites and attractions, we will remember Prague by the hours spent wandering and getting lost, discovering little shops and cafes, knowing we were in a different world than our own!
One of the most gorgeous places in Europe. the history of these streets, their buildings will simply blow you away, there's no other place quite like it.

Not as publicized as the Old Town but just as nice. The Lesser Quarter is not as publicized as the Old Town but is very nice. It has interesting streets with restaurants and shops. The St. Nicholas Church is not to be missed. While not as massive as the very large Cathederals it is very interesting. If you have the time allow at least an afternoon and probably could spend a whole day in Lesser Quarter.
Many things to see here.. Make sure you include this area in your tour. Every one goes to Old Town but this area also has a lot of history and amazing buildings such at the St. Nicholas Church.

Peace wall. It's a lovely place just to stroll and have a drink, we didn't have a chance to visit the park, but we certainly will make time on our next visit!Visit the Lenon wall, not a lot of people were there when we visitid it. The Pub is just around the corner!
Great place to stay. We were fortunate to have a great hotel room just 60 yards from the Charles Bridge in the Lesser Quarter. The area is vibrant, lots to see, do and enjoy.
Could walk non-stop. The area is just superb, offering hours of romantic walks and relaxation. Hungry? You can stop anywhere and enjoy a fine meal, ice-cream or a refreshing coffee.

Soak up old Prague in Mala Strana on your way up/down the hill to/from Prague Castle and St Vitus Cathedral. Allow most of a day to visit Mala Strana, the castle and cathedral so that you can properly wander the streets, sit at a cafe and have a meal while people and cable car watching. There are loads of wee boutique shops and eateries. The view back over the city is fabulous.

Quirky. Plenty to photograph here. Nerudova is famous for the plaques that were the forerunners of the house numbers.Good value for souvenirs and coffee. The roof terrace of cowboys is wonderful. I did not eat here on this visit so cannot recommend the food however it has amazing views and a charm of its own.

Less tourists over this side of the river!. The lesser quarter is located the other side of Charles' Bridge and is definitely worth visiting. Whilst we were in Prague, there was a Meditterannean market on but, I'm not sure if it is permanently set up. It is a lovely market though, with a wonderful ambience, food tasting and live music. During our visit, there wer latin american singers performing which got a number of tourists dancing!

Amazing. This is on the other side of the river then Old Town but well worth the visit to walk around and look in the shops and stop for a beer or lunch. St Patrick's Cathedral was beautiful in this area. Visit the Trulfar Marionette shop just off the Charles Bridge.

Great market.. On Thursday 5th September while walking over Charles Bridge we saw a small market down in the Lesser Quarter, when we walked down to it we found it was selling all types of food an drink to eat there or take away, we brought some champagne and a selection of cheeses in a bowel and sat under the bridge to eat it, it was great a must see if your there.
Worth the walk. More history about Prague. What can I say, Prague is such a beautiful and romantic city. You can walk anywhere in the lesser quarter and in Old Town. There is so much to take in.
Just Great !. I was here 40 years ago. I was drawn like a magnet to this place this year. Nostalgic memories brought great solace. I would love to visit again. and soon.

the best part of Prague. We enjoyed the 'hop on hop off' guided bus tour on our first day and returned to the Lesser quarter the following morning. Late breakfast at Cafe Savoy followed by a combined stroll and tram ride along the historic lanes, streets and 'piazza's' culminating in a walk across Charles Bridge on a bright sunny day. Not many better ways to enjoy a Saturday morning!
Lovely streetlights and art deco details. took loads of pictures here...this is Kafkas Praha at its best :)looking forward to visiting again...
Very nice and no so busy. Mala Strana is less busy than Old Town Square and still has numerous buildings with very interesting architecture.

More Romantic than the Old Town. It is actually 2nd part of the historical center. Lesser Town is much more romantic place than the Old Town. It is more quiet and there is more (and larger) parks. Views are nicer here as there is hill and you look down on Prague and river. If you like sitting in the park by the river, this is the place. It is more quiet here.You just have to cross the Charles Bridge (or another) to get to the Old Town. It is actually not important if you stay here or in the Old Town, because you will walk through both quarters every day...If you need some sport, go to nearby "Letna hill" or "Landronka park", where is possibility of running, skateboarding or inline skating. There are also tenis courts.
Quiet quarter.. Much quieter, less tourists south of the Charles Bridge by the river in the Male Strana. Lots of Embassies, quiet streets and nice cafes.
Another good walk. All of the places in Prague are just good to walk around, again with a tour guide is awesome, but you are perfect on your own as well.

So elegant, so unique!. The most elegant buildings In a continuous row , street after street , I have ever seen. You can imagine carriages with horses going along these streets, in another far time.....
Great area, highlight of our Prague trip!. Nice area, great view of Prague ! Lots of restaurants, John Lennon Wall full of beautiful graffiti , love this area!

Small pace. Same as the old town, it has amazing architectures but some are more modern. The shops that I love live here. Gosh wish i had the budget to shop. On the other hand, the Jequarter where the old new synagogue is here. Can be very packed tho with tourists.

Passing by. Nice area for walk aroung going to somewhere near the old town. You can see a lot of great and old buildings but nothing is breathtaking.
The sidewalks are wheelchair friendly (little stone squares. Not flat).

One of the reasons you want plenty of time to explore. The small streets. I saw a raft trip in the canal near the Lennon Wall. Several small inviting restaurants. Lots of embassies. The Kampa Museum. The Lennon Wall. The gate with all the locks. Pilsner beer.
Great way to pass the time. Loved walking through this are. Great buildings, good bars, Czech entertainment interesting and full of character. Really relaxing

Must See!. Lose yourself in the tiny streets, discover a hidden gem of a garden, visit a baroque church (St. Nicholas) (and experience what that word actually means, in real life), and wind your way up to the Prague castle. One of the most beautiful and magical parts of Prague.

Take a self guided walking tour. This was my third time visiting, but I saw a completely new area since I was doing a walking tour in my book. It is nice to see some off-the-beaten path area, which have more locals than tourists.
Bad food lots of nice buildings. Great buildings, lots of restaurants, but food was terrible, besides the bad treatment we suffer. We could eat much better away from the center.

Best place to see Charles Bridge. Walking along Charles Bridge seeing those sculptures up close will thrilled you but if you see the whole picture of this bridge, you should try to walk here first to catch the glimpse of the beautiful bridge in a distance.

The quieter side of Prague. For those of you who do not want the crowds you get in August try Mala Strana which has good hotels and a lot of good places to eat also. Not much cheaper in August but quieter and more pleasant.
Less Crowded Option to Old Town. Much more quaint and less crowded than old town. shops were more reasonably priced and less touristy souvienors

Full of souvenir shops. Visited this area due to the reviews but all I find are endless souvenir shops, bars, restaurants. Really not what I would call "small streets with interesting shops". In any case, in summer, it's impossibly crowded.

nicer site of Prague. When you will go to the other site of Vltava you will find nice and quite streets with many butiques and restaurants. Can go on the bank of the Vltava where is beautiful view to the Charles bridge and you will find here swans as well.
best place to wander. As a rule, this area is much more beautiful and the atmosphere of old time Prague is easier to sense than in the old quarter. Great place to wander.

Picturesque. Located just across the Charles Bridge from the old town this is a must see. Very picturesque to the point I felt I was in Disneyland looking at their perception of Prague !! Some nice places to stop and have a beer and people watch

Quieter side of Prague. Mala Strana is tucked away under the shadow of the castle. Take time to explore the side streets and squares . Palaces, embassies, parks and gardens are all tucked away and just a stones throw from the hustle and bustle a street away.

A lovely experience when in Prague. The Lesser Quarter is a much quieter experience away fro the push and shove of the old square.
A good idea is to walk down from the Palace through the Lesser Quarter with all its lovely streets, shops and cafe's, across the Charles Bridge and into the old Town.
Well worth the time to explore another area of prague.

Pitoresque neighborhood. ...you should walk through (better when there is a nice weather...) - do not miss the Kampa island with preserved wooden water mill. There is a nice park upstream from the bridge, a lot of nice small streets downstream - I would also recommend the terrace view from Hergertova cihelna restaurant on Mala Strana - which has both the great view and food. There are also window tables as an option inside (for winter time 8o) but better reserve in advance as there are really hard to get. The bees way how to visit Mala Strana would be to walk down the Castle - yo you can plan the Castle sightseeing, than the walk through Nerudova steet, walk Mala Strana and have a break in some of its restaurants before you go o to the Charles bridge and Old town...

More than Less. Located on the other side of the Charles Bridge, Lesser town offers a fair amount of green space where many people stopped to sit or lie down to enjoy the tranquility. After the hustle of the bridge, it was so nice to enter this peaceful world as it stretched along the river. There is also the usual urban scene with shops, restaurants and tourist sites.
Great Atmosphere. Loved the lesser quarter bustling cafes and bars, different from atmosphere than the old town. more laid back feel. Not to be missed castle and Petrin Tower
Very cute. Like any other city that has been marketed beyond belief. The souvenir shops are pretty much all there is with cafes.

Quieter Side of Prague. Mala Strana is tucked away under the shadow of the castle. The main route up from Charles Bridge, through Malostranske Namesti (with St Nicholas Church) and up to the castle is a busy tourist route with many bars, restaurants and shops - selling all many of different things. Take time to explore the side streets and squares and discover a different pace of life. Palaces, embassies, parks and gardens are all tucked away and just a stones throw from the hustle and bustle a street away. Much to see and do or alternatively a great place to sit in a quiet garden with a book.
Beautiful, interesting, clean, safe. This area was amazing!! Our first exposure to Prague and we were spellbound. SO much nicer than "new town".
also a must see. As with so much of Prague, another quarter of the city in which the visitor must spend time wandering the streets. The Kafka Museum is a must.

history at every corner. Prague is the most beautifull city in the world and if not not then one of the most beautifull surely, But Prague is without a doubt the most magical, mysterious and romantic city you can find worldwide. Walks around the lesser Town part in Prague will prove me right after you have done one or two, You will enjoy it
Cool district. This area has lots of cool shops and a park that makes you believe you've left the city! Shakespeare Book Shop is a must.

nice walk. A nice place to walk around with shops, lovely building and cafes. A suggestion when walking around Prague in general is keeping your 10K coins restaurants don't let you in to use the toilet, there is clean toilets to use but they do cost.

unique atmosphere. its the nice area close to the city centre between castle hill and charles bridge with many bars, pubs and restaurants, there are also 2 small bridges where lovers left padlocks with their names,
Buzzy area, lovely place for a cool drink... We found ourselves sitting out in this district quite often. Nice vibe. Happy just watching the trams go by..
Lovely to stroll around. Winding streets with historic buildings and little surprise parks and squares, a beautiful area to wander around.

Wonderful place to stay. I loved being at a hotel in the lesser quarter, there was so much to see, but wasn't as loud as the Old town once night fell. During the day it is full of great restaurant options and all kinds of vendors.

Charming and Peaceful City Sight. This area is situated at an elevation across Charles Bridge and under Prague Castle. It is the area where the less privileged used to live, hence the name, but now is just as elegant as the Old Town area. There is a lovely garden in front of the original palace, definitely worth visiting. It's quiet and much more peaceful than the hustle and bustle in the Old Town or near the Castle. There are plenty of cafes and restaurants as well.
