I'd recommend taking two hours or so walking around and relaxing with a quiet meal before returning to the more tourist focused areas.I do have to say, it is a bit steep and on a cobblestone street, so strollers and wheelchairs may be difficult to maneuver.

Stroll around and enjoy this lovely part of Prague. I enjoyed this part of Prague more than the actual Old town Square.You seem to have less tourists, more lovely buildings. There is less a crowd and here are so many small places to explore. Stop pass the many restaurants which offer plenty of quality food!

A real cultural experience. Make sure to go across the Charles Bridge into the Mala Strana. It is very charming with cobbled streets and beautiful buildings, a lovely place to explore or even get some beers and watch the world go by.

Mala Strana - Preferred area to spend time in Prague. Mala Strana, also referred to as the "Lesser Town" or "Lesser Quarter" is one of the ten listed old districts of Prague. It is located just past Charles Bridge and encompasses much of the area between the banks of the Vltava River and the Castle District. It is a place that Mozart and Casanova loved and are rumoured to have spent much time during their days in Prague, and it is a lovely and quaint area to explore and experience for today's visitors to the city. As you enter Mala Strana, from Charles Bridge you are immediately met with what has become a rather touristy scene on Nerodova street. Fast food eateries, souvenir shops and the likes now dominate what used to be a very charming scene in the past. However, Nerodova remains an attractive thoroughfare and as soon as you get off the main street, you can quickly find yourself in cobblestone passages and places that feel much more authentic, genuine and what you were probably hoping to experience in Prague. In addition to the quaint alleys and tiny streets you can experience while wondering through Mala Strana, there are several garden/park areas, which are beautiful during much of the year. There are countless places to stop for a drink or meal, a couple of good museums, including the popular Franz Kafta Museum, which also boast a very interesting statue creation by David Cerny called - Piss. You'll just have to see this one for yourself, its actually quite interesting. Mala Strana also hosts two very good church visits that can be made and which are highly recommendable. These include the the church of St. Nicolas which is arguably amongst Europe's more attractive Baroque style churches that also features the largest ceiling fresco in the continent. Further, you can visit the Our Lady of Victorious church, which hosts the Jesus Child statue, an important local relic that has been visited by worshippers and visitors the world over as well as having recorded three papal visits since the1890s. Overall, Mala Strana, while having become quite touristy in parts, is probably our favourite area in Prague and an area we will purposely spend more time during future trips to the city.

Charming, quiet Mala Strana. Mala Strana is much quieter than Old and New towns across the Vyltava River, except right around St. Vitus and the Castle entrances. The hill offers incomparable views of Prague.

Our Lady Victorious. If you have any interest in Late Medieval history you MUST visit this church. It is on the Number 22 tram line. You will see the one, the only, and the original Infant of Praque! Check it out, boys and girls!

A great area in Prague. I prefer Mala Strana over the Old Town on the other side because it has less tourists, better food and in my opinion more to offer. Walking around in the narrow streets is something I could do for hours and hours. And I did, and I didn't get tired of it!

Mala Strana. This neighborhood was so quaint and you could easily escape the crowds by wandering onto any side street off of the main attractions. One of my favorite things was the Lennon Wall, which I didn't even know about before my visit and could have stayed there staring at it for hours!

Walk around to know the historic facts of the past. Cross the Charle's Bridge, get on a tram, go to the upper side e come down walking through the narrow streets. It's the best way to visit that part of Prague.

A quieter, but still beautiful, part of a beautiful city. Have to say that the Mala Strana and adjoining Prague Castle area were my favorite parts of Prague. The beauty of the architecture matches that of the Stare Mesto and Novy Mesto, with fewer crowds and no cheap souvenir shops to speak of. Views of the city from the hill next to the castle are absolutely incredible. Beer lovers should be sure to visit the microbrewery and brewpub operated at the Strahov Monastery; Sv. Norbert's, as they call it, makes some of the best beer I have ever tasted.

Old city with splendid views!. After Charles bridge you enter Mala Strana and there you have to stay for a good time, or visit it again next day, there are so many places to see, excellent restaurants, cafes and bistros, folk art stores with the artisans doing a craft they learned from past generations, a splendid view of the city buildings, river and gardens, interesting statues, and street art.

My favourite part of town. Castle side of the river between the castle and the Charles Bridge this part of town is quieter with smaller crowds than the Old Town. Little back streets with great restaurants and shops and hidden squares. Don't miss the John Lennon wall.
Petrin Hill. Take the Funicular railway to the top of Petrin Hill. Need small change for the ticket machines. Lovely walk back down through shaded area.

walk around!. I can really advice to visit this neighborhood, leave your clock and map at the hotel and just spent some hours wandering around. You will be surprised what you could find by just walking around (outside the touristic path).
Wedding stay.. Perfect, a lovely and quiet side of Prague, very hilly but lovely and great views of the City below. Public transport to the area is great.

Unexpected gem. This was perhaps the most beautiful section of Prague. The streets wind around and it's fun to just wander & get lost. The houses are picturesque & you can't stop taking pictures of them.

Feel the noble life. Good vendors for souvenirs, cheaper prices that in Stare Mesto (Old Town). Embassies and consular offices. Good noble life. Go to the top of the hill until Petriny to refresh a bit, to breathe a cleaner air.I have even found Lavender small field. Excellent smell to complete the view.

Quaint, quiet and and a living history museum. This area of Prague is across the Charles Bridge from Old Town. It has some great restaurants, easy access to metro and trams, and is not overrun with tourists in the evening.
Viewed from the Castle. When we got here on Saturday afternoon we olny saw this from the Castle. It looked delightful. Another time, less rain, and more access we would love to explore this region.

The best base for your Prague trip. The Mala Strana is the perfect area to stay while exploring Prague. It is within walking distance of most sites, but is set back just enough to offer you a little peace at the beginning and end of each day. There are many restaurants and little bars, but not the kind with a man out front trying to lure you in. There are many little shops that are NOT repeats of the same fake crystal and tacky knick-knacks that line old town square. Mala Strana has pottery shops and books shops and other specialties. Just a charming little area.

Go to Kampa!. Near to the Mala Strana tram stop, walk down to the base of the Charles Bridge (to the right as you come off) and go to the little island of Kampa. Very charming, with canals, an old water wheel, and a cute old square with traditional street food vendors purveying delicious treats.
Hills. Loved this area.St. Nicholas church,church holding the statue of the child of Prague.Lovely to have been there for Sunday mass in English at 12m.d.Some lovely side streets and great resturants

Awesome. One of the most popular areas in Prague, great to wander around and discover. It is a residential area with many embassies, cafés and restaurants, only 5 minute's walk from Charles Bridge that leads you right into the heart of The Old City.

Real Prague.... That is the most popular part of Prague,after Stare Mesto,but a lot less touristy.There are some nice parks,a lot of cafes and restaurants,nice buildings and cobbled streets.If you want to flee from crowd just walk over Karluv Most and stray through Mala Strana.We went there late in the evening one day,and it was perfectly safe and nice to walk there...

Pubs and great little shops. A wonderful area to walk and discover. A great place to stop and enjoy after being at the castle. A fun sculpture at the front of the Franz Kafka museum is unique and worth seeing.

Lesser Quarter. My sand and I set out to find out what a large building that looked like a church was and stumbled on an amazing quaint area with lots of quiet streets, cares, and when we did find the church...an amazing interior. Worth getting lost in the Lesser Quarter

A nice place where to stay. Close to many important monuments, and there is still quiet Streets without any tourist. And not far from the astronomical clock square and so on. It is a residential area with many embassies, cafés and restaurants.

This is the location to Stay. It is away from the Old City, big plus, but only a 5 minute walk to The Charles Bridge that takes you right into the heart of The Old City. It is quiet, safe and picturesque. The other side of The Bridge is far too crowded and far too hectic.

Visit the "real Prague". While the old city gets all the tourists, this section across the river is where the everyday citizens of this beautiful city live and work. It has beautiful 19th and 20th century architecture, terrific cafes and restaurants, beautiful parks and a funicular to a miniature "Eiffel Tower" that's worth the trip.

just wander here!!!!. Perfect streets to walk without map and discover houses & shops of different colours...you can go to the castle or the hill of Petrin, or the brigde Charles...so nice....
I advise to go very early to avoid the crowd, otherwise for sure you will not be alone!
Don't read too much about it, just got there!

Prague Castle. We took a 6 hour tour which started at the beautiful Castle.The cathedral was very beautiful. Then we went down the stairs to the bottom. Many restaurants and nice shops. From the hill we saw a fantastic view of all of Prague.

picturesque!. That is one of the most picturesque quarters of Prague. You will have plenty of views to shoot with your camera, and plenty of atmosphere to experience! Very beautiful and very interesting!

Beautiful. We stayed in Mala Strana. It is still very busy during the daytime though not as crowded as Old Town. There are plenty of local restaurants. I love the romantic feel of this part of Prague. Lots of pics to be taken if you like architecture. The place is somewhat deserted after dark which only adds to the ambiance.

lots of little eateries, and a good bit of street cafe style.. One of the nicer parts of central Prague, where the embassies are so good food and drink too. Check the prices though as they can be inflated due to the proximity to the embassies.
Heaps of restaurants. Lovelly part of Prague with heaps of clean inexpensive restaurants and cafes.a surprising find!No dislikes.

Beautiful quieter side of Prague. Wander around here on a nice day and you'll have no reason to stop into one beer gardens and sample the local lagers. A lot quieter than some of the other areas of Prague but just as beautiful.

Romantic. Loved the quaint houses, cobbled roads, caffes and the fact that its not crowded with tourists...
The petrin hill is awesome... We wandered through mala strana n it's lanes n by lanes and loved it so much. There are parks, museums, cellars.... Deserves a day....
Many sights all within walking distance. Many beautiful buildings in this area. Lots of shops to buy food and souvenirs. The Vrtbovska Garden and the Wallenstein gardens nearby are worth a visit
well preserved. Very well preserved quarter. Like travelling back 500-600 years in time. Very house had its details. A must see!

good place to stay. We stayed in Mala Strana right in Malostranske Namesti and it was perfect. Be careful about stopping for food or drink as you get closer to the Charles Bridge, as a beer will go up in price just a short walk closer to the bridge.

Visit Prague and Meet Czechs. I just love the Mala Strana because it is full of Czechs being Czechs, whereas the Old Town is full of Czechs working hard to look after tourists and you feel like a tourist in the Old Town, with more tourists than Czechs.It is more fun in Mala Strana and you feel that you are visiting friends and you do not feel like a tourist.

Some actual quiet!!. Quite a number of streets and byways, most of which are not overwhelmed with people. There are also a substantial number of restaurants (some high-end) that offer a respite from the masses.

A Collection of old Palaces, Embassies and churches. Lots of cobbled streets with tourist trap shops and restaurants. Our worst 'tourist' meal was here, but we should have spotted the tell tale signs of 'cocky' waiters and extras brought to the table without comment. The shops are often duplicates of tourist 'tat'. The graffiti is everywhere - sadly lacking any sort of originality or artistic merit. The 'John Lennon' wall is worth a look and the quirky railings with hundreds of padlocks that seem to represent couples locking in their love for eternity - a nice touch. As ever you should watch out for the trams and the road traffic.

By far the classiest area of Prague and the greenest.. Much better range of restaurants than in Old Town. You can also easily escape the City by heading to the Petrin Hills, on foot or by funicular. Wonderful panoramic views from up there.

Definitely worth a visit. It's much less busy on this side of the river and feels more genuine than the other parts of Prague, which you literally can barely move through because of the throngs of tourists.

If you're wanting to eat/drink this is where you should be looking to head. Prague suffers from being so popular. The old town and Wenceslas Squares are too full of tourists, jumping across the river makes things cheaper and nicer. Some lovely bars and restaurants in Mala Strana. All different kinds, all nice and good value.

good but not spectacular. Lots of trinket shops, mixed with cafe bars some nice churches, buildings were very nice but very crowded having to compete with cars and trams who don't like to give way on crossings

Pleasant walk. With houses of many different colours and typical Central European architecture, a stroll through Mala Strana will mould your concept of Prague. The church of St. Nicholas and the surroundings are definitely the high points. Holds many small surprises, like the narrowest street in Prague.

Quiet side of Prague. I had been to Prague twice before and stayed in a fabulous hotel in this district. Unfortunately, this time, I was traveling with an elderly parent, and the hills which can be quite steep were just too much. This area lies right below the castle. If you have the stamina, it is a terrific walk up to the castle area.

The best area of Prague. For us this is our favourite area of Prague. Wander around this area and take in the beautiful buildings and gardens. As you get nearer the castle district it can be a good workout with the hills but a must visit is the Vrtbovska gardens, a paradise, a hidden gem that one must discover.
Lesser Quarter - Mala Strana. Don't miss the Lenon Wall as well as the rive side, the pointed building with the line of the flad in 2002. You can enjoy it by doing Segway.
Don't Follow a Map - Just Wander. I just wandered around without an itinerary and found lots of wonderful sights. This is a great place to get lost!

Tram Hub and Ultra busy, but easy. The crowds here are sometimes very dense, but the people are so friendly, it doesn't matter, locals and tourists blend here amongst the architectural history of a great site seeing City.

Beautiful Area. Really enjoyed crossing the Charles Bridge and walking around Mala Strana. There are lots of great small cafe's and places to grab a beer along the river. If you venture in further, you can find lots of cool shops, churches, and parks.

Good for a stroll during the day. We went there during the evening looking for a nice bar/lounge for a night cap and had heard this was a very romantic area. But we found most of the places to be almost empty or closed on a friday night, which we found very surprising. We also saw a number of tourists with maps apparently trying the same thing as us, with no effect as we saw them again and again, still looking, just like us :) During the day however, we found it very charming with its little shops and hills.
city break. Much quieter than the Old Town but still plenty to see and do.Small artizan shops to browse through. Nice River side bars and cafes to sit and watch the world go by
Best part in town.. Kampa Park and lunch at Maltezske Namesti.Dinner at Kampa Park restaurant is great.Modern Art museum at the island highly recommended.

Great Side of old town to Stay. We stayed in both old town and mala strana and we preferred the quiet of the mala strana. It was less crowded with people and seemed like a more upscale neighborhood to stay. It was also very convenient to just cross the Charles Bridge and have easy walking access to all the attractions, restaurants and shopping in old town Prague. We also found many excellent restaurants in the Mala Strana.

Make time for this. The one regret from the trip was not leaving enough time to explore this area. Don't make the same mistake - visit early in your trip so you don't run out of time. Maybe spend an hour less in the Castle and then get more time here when you walk down?

Charming.. A walk in the little quarter takes you back to the Baroque age, as there are hardly any modern buildings around.There are many churches and palaces to explore in the quarter, plus the Charles bridge and Kampa island are just nearby.2-3 hours should be enough to explore this area.

Very Charming Neighborhood of Prague. Our hotel was in the Mala Strana, a very charming old neighborhood. There are lovely little piazzas, old buildings and streets, and lots of shopping and restaurants. This was my favorite part of Prague.
Beautiful buildings. Lovely restaurants and places to stop for a drink. Truly lovely part of the city. Slightly less hustle and bustle so more room to stop and see things.

Worth a visit. This is the kind of place where you just wander around the streets from sight to sight and discover much more to see on the way. Many beautiful old buildings, churches and palaces to see. Stop for a coffee on the way and soak up the atmosphere!

The best part of town and much quieter. I loved this area more than the old town. Lesser crowd of tourists and a great selection of bars and pubs at much reasonable prices. Also a great selection of places to eat. A great place to sit out with the locals and taste the various beers they have to offer. Make sure you enter the cellars of the bars or restaurants as the old city is a storey or two underground( as the city levels were raised due to the constant flooding from the river).

My Favorite. Over on that side, you get a better experience of Prague. less touristy. On this side of the bridge you can see The John Lennon Wall, infant of Prague, Kafka Museum, and meander your way up to the castle. I was fortunate enough to be staying on this side of the bridge where the prices are better and you don't feel like your in a sea of humanity.

Quiter than the old town. Not as much going on here but a nice break from the old town and the lesser quarter is below the view point where you get a great view of the citiy - if you don't like steep climbs better take the venicular (?spelling?) up the hill. The monestary is at the top also.

Walk to the Castle District!!!!!. I couldn't imagine taking a crowded tramto the castle district if your hotel is located in the Old Town. Yes the walk is uphill- but you will miss the wonderful sights, sounds, and shopping of this wonderful strollable place. This area is what makes Prague, such an outstanding city- you find that around every corner it just keeps getting better and better- every view is picture worthy.

Quieter area of the city. Not as touristy an area but still enough to make it interesting with St Nicholas Church, the funicular up Petrin Hill and the Music Museum plus access to the river and Kampa Island
Lesser Town. Small compact with lots of little bars and shops. Quaint but the Czechs certainly know how to charge for f ood

Lesser by Name Only. It may be "Lesser or Little Quarter" by name but it's only by name . There are as many wonderful buildings ,churches and squares as on the other side of the river! Everything is that little bit less ,price wise( not that Prague is expensive anyway.) The tower at the end of Charles Bridge is as impressive as on the "Old Town " side.  If I were visiting Prague regularly then I would stay here. You can play spot the embassy! All the foreign embassies are here, including the{ search before you enter OUR AREA ( cameras on poles under your cars and open your car bonnet)} American Embassy .The river area is fantastic including Kampa Island. Art galleries and parks and places to eat or relax.. The churches are more" interesting " than the grandiose Baroque show pieces of the main city. If you're of Catholic upbringing and know anything of "The Infant of Prague" then you must visit the church that houses it. The Lennon wall is a must just to say you've been there.The Kampa Island area is beautiful and also has some very classy restaurants .In other words get over the "Bridges" to" LESSER QUARTER". If you don't go there you've missed one of the best areas of PRAGUE
Another nice part of Prague. Lovely Quaint area with more amazing old buildings, shops nice places to eat & drink. Well worth a visit.

one of the better areas to stay. Quieter, cheaper and a stones throw away from Charles Bridge what more can you say, plenty of excellent restaurants, bars, cafes and places to see, plus a short walk up to the castle.
Hotel location. Very nice area. Hotel was in this area-shops, pubs and cafes are witihin easy reach. Would stay in this area again

A quiet and interesting part of the City. We stayed in this part of the City and find it to be delightful. It is much quieter than Old Town with excellent Czech restaurants and some beautiful and interesting buildings many of which now seem to be used as Embassies. The Kampa Park has some very entertaining modern sculptures and this area gives access to Charles Bridge and the Funicular

Respite from the crowds. There are plenty of streets and alleyways to explore in this area of the city where you can briefly escape the throngs of people doing the usual tourist thing of shopping!Take your time and explore off the beaten track to see where the locals hang out. You'll be rewarded for your efforts!
Just nice to pass through. Between Stare Mesto and the Castle, very few people acknowledge this area of the city. Of course, almost everyone passes through it, but there is little to see.

Lovely district. There's a real buzz about the place when you enter via Charles Bridge - restaurants, souvenir shops, etc. Winding streets full of charm. Great place just to wander and enjoy the atmosphere.

Very pleasant. We had a very pleasant stroll around Mala Strana on our first day in Prague. Took in the Hunger Wall, the mini Eiffel Tower and avoided the crowds. Some great views of the city from Petrin Hill. Then through Mala Strana itself and on to the John Lennon wall.
In Between. This is the area of Prague that owes its architecture to the Hapsburg's.... I.e. very Austrian. Pleasant enough, but not startling. Most people don't linger, but continue onto the Castle.

Beautifully Atmospheric. In this jewel of a city, there are many places to explore but none comes close to the streets and hidden corners of the Mala Strana. My advise is to go there at night when the gas lit streets at at their best and the people are at their fewest. Stroll in the footsteps of Jan Neruda and soak up the atmosphere.

very pretty more gardens and trees. Enjoyed walking in this area. I found it to be more open with parks and unexpected courtyards..very pretty walk along the river. It seems as though you can get away from the hustle and bustle here even though you are still essentially in Prague..

Even on a freezing cold day, it's worth the walk. I had such a great time exploringnthis area. It felt extremely safe and there were so many wonderfully interesting streets with cafe's, small shops and restaurants. It's a really cool neighborhood to walk around and explore.

pretty. such a photo opportunitie, if you love old buildings, nice little cafes and little squares you'll like this. Take a few street off the beaton track you'll find some little gardens with table's and patio heaters for you to sit and enjoy some local food

Lovely area.. Once away from the castle area which is busy you can walk along very quiet streets and soak up the atmosphere. Definetely visit the Loreta which houses the treasury full of amazing pieces of silver and gold. Also the monastry area and grounds are worth a visit with views over terraces full of vines.
What can i say?. Most places were to overwhelming for a short trip!Busy and Bubbly! Too many beautiful sites! Fantastic transport to everywhere

Brilliant location. Lesser town is perfect for a Prague city stay. Its only moments walk from the Castle, Charles Bridge, shops, great cheap restaurants, yet not filled with tourists. There are great walks and parks by the water within a few minutes walk, and the Charles Bridge (whilst quite an attraction itself) leads you right to the old town. would not stay anywhere else!

Beautiful Part of Town. If you you trying to decide what part of town to stay in book your room in the Mala Strana. It's within walking distance to the Charles Bridge, Old Town, New Town and Prague Castle.

lovely place to stroll. Malá Strana is located between the Prague castle and the left bank of the river Vltava. It is possible to appreciate its many roofs, as soon as you go down the slopes from the castle.It's a magic place to stroll, with lovely small streets, baroque buidings, nice restaurants, cozy cafés and little shops with many souvenirs. We felt as if transported into the past. We went there twice, and the snow was falling, making everything especially beautiful. A place not to be missed.

*TOP area *. Beautiful area below Castle complex, short walk to Charles Bridge. Central bit less crowded than around the old town square. Look out for symbols above houses used to identify families/trades before numbers in nerudova street, Pop into the puppet and absinthe shops, sample traditional food, take a walk through park to Strahov monestary, have a local beer and don't forget the castle tour!
Lovely part of town. We loved the old buildings, the statues that serve as a decor to them. You can see a lot of embassy's here, and they know how to pick a place and the building.
Less is more. Perhaps the nicer side of town - well worth going to and I'm glad we stayed there rather than the old town

Reserve some time for this part of Prague. I went to Mala Strana straight after my visit to the Prague castle, I followed a neighbourhood walking tour in my guidebook and was in this area for a good few hours until I found my way back onto the Charles Bridge.It was nice when I got to some quieter parts, different from the really touristy parts in central Prague.Many restaurants and souvenir shops, I didn't go into any of them but I thought that some of them look fairly intriguing, I reckon you'd probably find some hidden gem here if you're lucky!Be prepared to be tired if you combine this with a trip to the Prague Castle, but do not miss Mala Strana if you're in Prague!

Castle are around St. Nicholas Cathedral. This was a pleasant area to walk around just below the Castle on the other side if the bridge fromOld Town. the churches are the draw in this area, also many little restaurants and cages, and souvenir shops. On a cold day, the hot wine sold outside establishments is great.

Most beautiful part of Prague. Reserve enough time for this part of Prague, connect the visit with seing Prague castle and Petrin Hill .Enjoy walking also aside the main touristic paths, absorb the atmosphere of this charming corner. If you take tram 22 from Malostranska to Prague castle, you will get there later quite easily and make your sightseing from the castle downwards to the Vltava river.

The Quieter part of town. This is a good place to get away from the crowds and also where the Government sits. You can find many good places to eat here and see beautiful architecture of the grander kind. There's also a Thai Massage parlour here with a tank full of fish that nibble on on your legs & toes while you look out onto the passers-by in the street.
Very enjoyable. Enjoyable walk up to the castle. Plenty of souvenir shops with a range of quality and prices. Quieter than the Old Town and great views from outsid ethe Castle
Great Place. The Mala Strana is where we stay when visiting Prague. Lots of hiostory / architecture etc as well as a modicum of shops and a plethora of eateries to suit every budget.

Charming. A lovely part of Prague to wander around. The climb up to the castle is quite tough if you struggle with inclines but it is well worth it. You are spoilt for choice when it comes to bars and restaurants, but the sheer number means they compete to keep prices low. We had an excellent 3 course meal, for three, with drinks, tea and coffee and tip, for under 1000 kc in total, or around £11 each.

A little Touristy. We went through the lesser quarter on our way to the Castle and went back over for a better look around before we left. Such a shame that all of these lovely buildings and tiny shops are now dedicated to selling things to tourists, would have liked to have seen 'proper shops'

A hidden gem. On my recent trip to Prague I stayed in Mala Stana. I loved the quaint houses and cobbled streets, winding streets and original house signs. It is quieter than other tourist areas and shops and restaurants seem to be slightly cheaper. It is a great location for Prague Castle and Petrin Park.

looks like a fairy tale. Was so interesting- wear comfy shoes- lots of cobblestone streets, and hills, snow while we were there and can be slippery. wonder thru the streets and go up to the place from charles bridge for a great view.

A brief visit, but we'll be back!. We only really passed through this district on the way to the castle, but if we had had more time in Prague we would definitely have gone back. A lovely old street (although a bit steep in places on the walk up to the castle) with a large selection of bars and restaurants that we will be back to try one day!

As much if not more to offer.... Loved this part of town and regretted not staying here as opposed to the Old Town. Lovely side streets and much quieter than the Old Town. Some lovely shops and pubs, and significantly less touristy. Definitely consider this area for your accommodation.

More to explore. Don't miss the higgledy-piggledy streets of the Mala Strana and some very welcome coffee shops. Spend some time at St Nicholas Church and the Church of the Gesu Bambino for some cultural input.
Nice part of town. Nice part of town with many restaurants and shops. The best thing to do is to stay away from the main tourist streets and visit the not so touristy side streets.

Nothing "lesser" about it!. Walk over the Charles Bridge and get lunch or dinner here. There is nothing "lesser" about it! Beautiful, with great restaurants and shops, and lots of roads to explore. Recommended!

Less hustle and bustle. The Lesser Quarter is less crowded that the Old Town side of the river, but has just as much to see. Walk across the river and see some of the hurches on this side, you won't be dissapointed.
Off the beaten path. A little off the beaten path but well worth the trip. Beautiful churches, lovely residential areas, cool monument to John Lennon,too
Good for building viewing. Lovely buildings around... seriously. This is a good place to stroll around in but you will probably get somewhat lost too. The buildings just literally exude history.

Great area to explore. We stayed in the Lesser Quarter - 1 min walk to Charles Bridge. It was an area with great restaurants, cafes and grocery stores. Not as crowded as the Old Town and lots of locals going about their daily business - a perfect spot rich in history.

jam packed. we just about got across the bridge without having to fight our way through...which i believe is the case in the summer months.It is worth doing once and taking the bridge next to it if you want to go across again.
Great Hotel Pod Vezy. Not as crowded as Old Town and very convenient to Charles Bridge, Castle District and Jewish Quarter.

Take a stroll through this lovely, historic area.. The "Little Side" rests on the slopes just below the Prague Castle and it is a pretty place to take a two-hour stroll through. Predominantly Baroque, there are plenty of interesting sights, shops and restaurants littered all around this area. This is one of those place where you take it easy and take in all the milieu these charming streets have to offer.
nice but have seen better jewish areas in other countries. we visted this in daylight and at night. Daylight was best time to visit it as after dark it is a bit sombre. Lots of nice architechture.
Beautiful!. Loved this are of Prague! A bit cleaner in architecture, and a nice sight on your way to Prague Castle! Very good food around here too.

Have enough time. Enjoying all that Prague has to offer takes time. The Lesser Town - on the other side of the Charles Bridge - is perhaps not as glamorous, but delivers some jewels of its own. Take the tram (I think it is #22) up to the castle but rather keep going another two stops and start at the Strahov Monastery, with its beautifully preserved library. Take care of their breaks during the middle of the day. Instead of losing your temper, rather go to the restaurant on the left and try the excellent locally produced dark ale. It has a kick too! Be careful before you pay the extra to take photographs - the light is low and unless your camera can compensate enough, it will be money wasted.Walk down into the lesser town again and eventually over the Charles Bridge.
Walking distance to everything but less packed with tourists.. Lovely area that is still walking distance to everything. Worth staying here if you prefer to be a bit further away from the crowds.
Nice place for a walk. Enjoyed to walk along the streets , without map, just exploring the zone, the architecture. Even in the evening it looked safe, some good restaurants can be found there.

Little Town. This is another beauty of the capital city.If you visit the Prague Catle, you must take the walk through the Lesser Quarter where all of the embassies are located! The street the U.S Embassy is on is cosidered the "safest street in Prague"

Little streets to explore. Loads of little streets and shops to wander round with plenty of bars and shops and the beers here is cheaper than the old town square!
Check out lennons wall for beatles history and St Nicholas church for fantastic art

Lovely, lovely area.... We loved the Mala Strana's winding streets intermixed with its historic sights and modern bars, cafes, restaurants. Don't go to Prague without take a few minutes to walk through this area. We did do so on foot and although tired, all agreed that this was likely the best way to see it rather than from a tour bus or car.
Safe area.. Plenty of restaurants and shops that are an artist dream with the beautiful handmade wooden puppets. A charming and safe area.

Less crowded that Old Town with lots to do. Walk across the Charles Bridge from Old Town on your way to Prague Castle and enjoy the sites of Little Quarter. Kampa Island and the Lennon wall are nice places to linger. St. Michael's church and the Church of Our Lady Victorious with the statue of the baby Jesus with healing powers are here. Good restaurants are also found easily. Lots of embassises. Check out the houses on the way up Nerudova to the Castle --- each one is unique and displays a distinctive image above its mantle
lovely. lovely old area of the city, near the castle, very low lying, amazing to see the line where it flooded in 2002, must have been devastating.

The place to be. During a walk at night, we visited the Mala Strana. Unless we amlost didnt pass.any other person, the mala strana was very busy. The little streets remind me of Vienna and the candles floating on the water are so romantic... Don't forget to bring your pwn padlock with the names on the lovers on it to symbolize your eternal love.
Romantic. Just walk through this area and u will fall in love again....pretty, Cosy, reminds of old world....typical old Europe...

Charming. This area just on the other side of the Charles Bridge is charming and a little less hectic than the Old Town. Full of picturesque squares and little nooks and crannies, it is an area of Prague worth getting lost in.We had lunch twice here, once in a little square and once on the river and both were a nice break from the cold and hustle and bustle going on outside.There are many shops as well and we found the prices to be a bit better than on the Old Town side of the bridge.Definitely worth a stroll across the beautiful Charles Bridge to explore this unique area of Prague.
Cozy little street. I love hanging out in small streets of this part of town especially late at night when the place is empty

Charming place the best area in Prague.. We loved Mala Stran area where the local people live their lives.
Se the area Na Kmape and the Petroin Hill with the park and the wiew of all Prague.

Peaceful. This area was very peacful compared to the old town. Our fantastic hotel (Roma) was here too. The funicular is well worth it as the view from the hill and thetower is superb. We also very much enjoyed our visit to the Czech national Museum of music. If you are intersted in instruments and their sounds this is a must.

Go off the beaten track. Much of the area is newer (by a century or so) than the Old Town, but still has magical corners and beautiful quiet streets. Prague can seem awash with tourists and tourist shops, so step into the side streets, and really appreciate the beauty and peace.

NICE AREA ACROSS CHARLES BRIDGE. It's right across charles bridge and has loads of cafes and restaurants to visit before or after you go up to Prague Castle. It's a little more quieter than the old town

Beautiful and charming. I stayed in Mala Strana and the area was absolutely beautiful - mosaic style paved pavements, cobbled streets and tramlines and charming buildings really made for an enjoyable atmosphere for browsing the shops, eating at a restaurant or enjoying a warm drink.

Interesting place to hang out at anytime. Malá Strana is the area that meanders down from the Castle Hill to the Vltava River. While it might not have the grandeur of the Old Town across the river, many find it more charming. Because the area was razed by fires in the 16th century, the architecture here is mainly baroque. Its finest site is the Wallenstein Palace with its fabulous walled garden full of fountains and statues. There's also the Church of Saint Nicholas and, high on Petřín Hill, a miniature replica of the Eiffel Tower.The Lesser Quarter is fun place to hang out if you don't want to do anything else for the day, you'll find music playing, people dancing, brides/ grooms have their wedding photo taking around and about the square, ..etc. You also find fine dinning with reasonable price at the square, the food cooked to perfection, but beware the tip - some restaurant added tips but some place tips are not included (check your bill carefully for tips before you leave the restaurant or the manager will come after you if you forgot to pay tips LOL)

Don't miss this part of Prague. Agree with others that this is a really nice part of Prague which is far less touristy, has enough to see and do and has a lovely feel about it. This is a place to slowly wander through, take in the details and loiter in the many bars and restaurants. And when you are ready for the fray again there is the Charles Bridge and the Castle District nearby!

Stay here!. I had a great trip to Prague, stayed in the "Lesser Quarter"...meaning the west side of the river. The east side of the river is where the throngs of tourists and tourist groups stay...big crowds all times of the day...if that is what you like, cool. But the west side is so quaint, quiet, peaceful....what a difference from the east side. It all depends what you are looking for. If you enjoy nightlife, clubs, people, stay on the east side. If you are looking for a peaceful oasis after a day of touring, the Lesser Quarter is awesome.
Dont know. this is where my hotel - park inn - was and there is very little to see. apparently pragues second castle is here but i couldnt find it

Mala Strana (The smaller Side) is the bigger beauty of the City. You can spend a lot of time on this side of the river. Cross the Charles Bridge to get there and you get into the middle of small and cosy streets and squares with lots of small shops and beer houses and restaurants. Many amazing buildings - remember to look up, and you will see beautiful houses.

Quiet, Elegant Quarter of Prague. I stayed in Mala Strana on a visit to Prague in October. Easy tram ride from the train station, it's a lovely, quiet and very elegant area of the city. Below the castle, it's at the western end of Charles Bridge and the home to many embassies and beautiful buildings. Quite a few nice restaurants and bars. Be sure to take in Petrin Hill and the Novy Svet (new world) area as well. Just walk about and explore, it's a wonderful area to wander. I recommend walking up Trziste past both the American and German embassies and up the stairs to the Strahov Monastery, by Loreta and then to the castle and St Vitus. Absolutely stunning architecture and great views of the red roofs of Mala Strana.

Perfect. We stayed in this quarter and it was nice to get away from the crowds of the old town. Lots of places to grab a coffee or a beer plus nice restaurants to eat dinner in. Not fancy just traditional and affordable.
magical. a must to see and walk round.Take the time and just sit and take it all in.There are too many cities been modernised and the historical side is been lost.

Red Roofs Galore. This has got to be the most picturesque part of Prague. Walking through it is like walking through the centuries. Looking from above, it looks like a sea of red roofs accented by an occasional spire or a dome.

No lesser or smaller. Nothing is "less" in Mala Strana, a great neighborhood where most embassies are located right under the calm Petrin Hill. In Mala Strana you can spend several days visiting churches, castles, parks and museums. You risk forgetting that there are other places to visit on the other side of the river. Don't miss the John Lennon graffiti wall near Kampa Park, Neruda Street and Vojan Park, they may not be listed among the main attractions, but you will enjoy them. Interesting to see, though not a tourist sight, is how all cars are carefully searched before entering Trziste Street where the US Embassy is located.

Very pretty. We walked around Mala Strana a few times. It's was all very pretty, and clean and civilised. I have no idea why it's referred to as the lesser quarter, it was nicer than the other quarters! It felt like being in the posh end of town.
Lovely quaint winding streets. Definitely the nicer part of prague. If I come to prague again, I think this is the area I would stay in. Some lovely quaint shops scattered around.
Great little shops.. The shops were wonderful, I found my favourite shops here. The visit was finished off with lunch at Bohemian Bagel.

Gorgeous. Lots of walking involved but well worth it, so much to see and do, from the charles bridge to John Lennon wall, and so much in between, just wander at your own pace and there is something new at the end of every street, from the river to the park, all in all well worth your time

Great area to stay, eat and see!. The Lesser Quarter was named this hundreds of years ago due to it being actually lower in altitude than the Old Quarter. This area is certainly historic and picturesque, with winding cobblestone streets, unique little cafes and restaurants, shops, and many sites to see. Do not think that since it is named the "Lesser Quarter" that it has less to see or is not as nice! Our hotel was on this side and we loved the entire area.

Lesser Quarter. This area is at the foot of the castle district and just across the Charles Bridge. A nice visit is to go to Old Town Square and absorb some of it , walk across the bridge and go to this square for awhile.From here you can take a walk up the winding, wide steps to the castle. This square is not as big or crowded as Old Town Square. St. Nicolas church is here an worth a peek inside. High Baroque. Often there are concerts here so look to see if they are having one.
Nice Area. There are many interesting sites around Mala Strana, including the Lennon Wall, old street scapes and the river.

Friendly and romantic. A wonderful place for couples - you will find a lot of nice places to sit and have a drink and meal, the variety goes from top restaurants to budget pubs, music clubs and (unfortunatelly) some overpriced places for turists. Dont be afraid to ask some locals to navigate you to a good restaurant.

A Quieter Place. Quieter streets with delightful range of less imposing buildings, than the old town across the river, with the hill and gardens leading up to the Petrin Tower . If you can make the walk to the top of the tower, you are in for some great uninterrupted views across all of the city.
Walk. Please, take a walk across the Mala Strana streets - without goal without time limits. The best time is Autumn evening. Look at the people faces and up to the Hradcany Hill. Dream...
Quite pleasant area. All of central Prague has great architecture and this area is no exception. Not quite as attractive as the Old Town Square area but still very pleasant.
Quiet walk. A quiet little part of Prague just off the Charles Bridge. Make sure to see the sculpture park along the river and check out the Lennon Wall. Walk over to the Infant of Prague Church.
Lovely area for a stroll, eating and dining. Great historic area, lots of palaces converted into embassies. Good for shopping, eating, drinking and general wandering about.

Great. This is easily a place where you can get lost and not even care. In every alleyway there is something to be seen and the eyes never tire. If you happen to have the time put your map away and just start to walk in whatever direction you feel inclined to, I promise you will discover something possibly amazing.
Very quite. Its a quite place ,but a must-to-visit area of prague. you should walk there on the river banks , its paradise.
too touristy for its own good. Beautiful butler a bittinen likellä Venice: outdoor museum without real life. Too many tourists, souvenier shops and restaurants with the same old menu offerings.

lovely to walk around. Take sensible shoes to Prague as the streets are often cobbled and the beautiful concrete mosaic pavements get quite slippy if it rains. It's nice just to walk around really, we had mushroom and potato soup in a bread bowl which was beyond heavenly.

cute & quiet but don't blink. We went to this area just to see the locks and wandered right into the Lennon wall and the quaint restaurant right next to the bridge. Little did we realize we were in Mala Strana. We walked through the park with intentions to go to the tower (which we thought was in Mala Strana). If anything, this place is worth taking a walk to get away from all the madness of the busier areas. It is very peaceful, cute & scenic.

Smaller than you think. We went past the Lesser Quarter while taking the tram up to the Castle. It looked very cute. The next day we walked over the Charles Bridge from Old Town. The Lesser Quarter was smaller than we expected in terms of areas to roam, shop, and eat. We much preferred Old Town.

Full of Great Restaurants and Galleries. Mala Strana is the less visited, quieter part of Prague. Most people just walk over the Charles Bridge and continue up the hill to the Castle. However, if you turn left once you get off the bridge or take one of the staircases off to the left before leaving the bridge, you'll discover a part of Prague many people miss. It's got a great free sculpture park (Museum Kampa), the John Lennon Wall, tons of wonderful restaurants, a restful park, zero touristy stores, and is away from the hustle and bustle and noise of the thousands of tourists who are in Prague at the same time you are.
Best Part of Prague. Many buildings date to the 9th century. Stroll the streets, have a cuppaccino and Trdelnik pastry and enjoy the area!

More lovely Prague. We walked through the lesser quarter while on our tour from the Castle to the Charles bridge. It's another of Prague's great areas where you can roam a little away from the most tourists but are still only a couple of minutes from the bridge. Lennon's wall, a tribute to Beatle John Lennon is here to enjoy.

Deserving of your visit!. This area was one of my favorite within Prague. The narrow hilly streets are very picturesque, there aren't as many cheesy tourist souvenir shops as in other districts... the buildings are beautiful! You can wonder thru' many side streets and avoid all the throngs of people who tend to stick to the main footpath. A few streets are very steep, so older folks may have issues making it to the top of the hill where the monastery and the castle are located. Lots of little hidden gems in this area... we had a great meal here too!
Nice and cosy. Nice and cosy surroundig of Prague. A bit more expensive to eat near the Charles Bridge. If You like a reasonable price for dining: go more to the side of Ujedz

great place to stay. This is a really good district to stay in in Prague. Quieter than the usual noisy tourist squares but still very central and 2 minutes from Charles Bridge and all areas. Prague is very navigable once you've found the river and all areas have something to offer but we had great sleeps in Mala Strana.

You wont be disappointed. Lovely - all Prague is lovely though, clean and people are very friendly and non intimidating. The Mala Strana is very 'chilled' but busy at the same time. Go - you will love it
Old town lite. Similar to old town, but less crowded. Great hotels away from crush nearer to old town. Good restaurants, close to Prague castle and foreign embassies

Wonderful streets filled with history. We got to this area by first taking a taxi up to the Prague Palace and Monastery/Library and then walking down beautiful winding streets without the tourist crowds 2x's. If you are visiting these sites, start at the top. It can be the difference of enjoying it. Walking up can be exhausting and the beautiful views will be at your back. There are magnificent views to be seen from many of these sites while walking down. We again returned via the Charles Bridge and Manis Bridge We would have returned to this area again and again if we had more time.

Best place to stay!. Stayed here in Hellichova , quaint and quiet , lots of old interesting bulidings. Lovely area to discover, all on foot, take your time and discover little alleys and tiny bars and restaurants! Definitely worth exploring and seeing what living in Prague is about.

Mala Strana is timeless. Embassys,castles, palaces, cathedrals, the Lennon Wall, charming pubs and excellent restaurants all inside a very accessible community. It was also an excellent launching pad to the other quarters for sight seeing and entertainment.

Great place to walk around. We didn't stay here long. We walked through it from the Castle on our way to Charles Bridge. It's a cute area though overlooking the River and Old Town. I would explore this area more on a repeat visit to Prague.
Worth the walk. A quaint and easy to get around neighbourhood of Prague. Lots of nice little shops and historic sights. Thoroughly enjoyed walking around Lesser Town.

Charming & quiet alternative to Prague's Old Town. We stayed at the Hotel Julia in the Lesser Quarter for a three-day visit in the fall of 2012. Prague's public transportation provides cheap and efficient transport to more famous tourist sites across the river in the Old Town and New Town sections of the city. There's plenty to see and do in the Lesser Quarter, including baroque churches, parks, a funicular to a 1/5 size replica of the Eiffel Tower, riverfront strolls and pleasant neighborhood dining. If you are visiting Prague, you should definitely tour (or stay) in the Lesser Quarter as part of your trip.

Lesser town. At the end of the Chales Bridge is the lesser town.Full of shops and restaurants, including one that does a proper cup of english tea!!The castle is in the lesser town up a steep hill.St Nicholas church is also well worth a visit for a small entrance fee.

Just walk around.... If you're in Prague you don't have to make an effort to find something interesting or historical to see, you really have to just walk around and you will find an infinity of small paths and wonderful buildings.
My favorite part. This area was great. There were less tourists and it still had all of the beauty of Prague! The stores are cheaper and the people are friendlier!

Great area to walk around. We stayed at the Hotel Pod Vezi which located just to the riight of the tower at the end of the bridge on the Mala Strana side of the river. It's a great place to just wander around the narrow sreets. Lots of interesting shops.great little restaurants.Very busy on the main street when coming off the bridge but go down the sides streets and it will get a lot less busy. St. Nicholas Cathedral is beautiful and worth taking some time to see. If your fit enough walk up to the castle. You may find a resaurant you may want to stop at or come to later. Go see the John Lennon wall.It's a wall that was first used as a fourm of protest during the communist rule. Now it's like a large colorful message board of hope and peace. Just walk around ,sit down and have a bite to eat and people watch ,just enjoy.
Nice restaurants and walking site. We liked the casual eateries and just walking the narrow streets and sites. Church is worn going through as well

Well worth a visit. Lovely part of Prague, with the castle being a must visit in this traditional part of the city.If you can muster the energy, then walking to the top of Petrin Hill and climbing to the top of the observation tower is a great way of spending an hour or so, with beautiful gardens to see whilst being there. For the less mobile there's a tram that you can get at the metro stop Ujezd at the bottom of the hill for 32CK - a bargain!!!There are plenty of bars/traditional restaurants and shops in this area, with the odd tourist exchange thrown in for good measure - be aware of being approached by strangers in the street offering you a great deal on currency exchange - this is a problem that we faced on most days but a firm 'no' usually did the trick, although the hubby had to be quite insistent on a few occasions.All in all a beautiful area with lots to see and do. You won't regret giving it a whirl!

Beautiful surroundings. Picturesque structures and streets everywhere. A highlight of this area is Karmelitska, where, in the Church of the Victorious Lady, Catholics always visit the image of the Infant Jesus of Prague. During our visit on Sept 18, it was a pleasant surprise it coincided with Mass at which a very meaningful homily was delivered by the officiating priest.

Don't discount the fun of the Lesser Quarter!. The Lesser Quarter is the city section on the west side of Charles Bridge. There are many shops, restaurants and sights to see there. You should walk along the river for a great view of the Old Town from the other side of the river and then enjoy the Lesser Quarter with all it has to offer. It is best to allow about half a day for this area and like the Old Town, allow yourself just to wander not staying just on the main more busy streets.We stumbled upon a Thai massage down a minor road and for 350 czk each (USD 17.50) we had an absolutely heavenly and relaxing 20 minute foot massage that was worth every bit of what we paid and more!Experiences like these cannot be planned. Just let yourself go where your feet direct and you will have a terrific day and an authentic experience.

Definitely worth spending time here!. This is a not to be missed area of Prague. Most people visit the Prague Castle complex and the views from the staircase which is great but there is a lot more to be explored. Kampa is a beautiful little island with a park that is lovely to walk through and is located at the bottom of the steps as you near the end of the bridge to your left (if coming from old town). Also, if you have time it is worth renting a bike or taking a bike tour to Petrin park and Petrin Hill. The trail is well paved and the views are beautiful. You can also see the monastery. At the top is a beautiful rose garden....it is an elevation so good shoes and healthy knees required!

Enjoy antient narrow streets and small restaurants. I would advaice first to visit a Castle on the top of hill and then investigate Malastranska and Nerudova streets. Visit small restaurants. Pay attantion on house signs - small pictures or sculptures on walls of houses - they are beautiful.

Lovely architecture and quiet.. Once away from the base of the Charles Bridge, you are in a residential, diplomatic neighborhood that has some lovely old buildings. Take a walk in and around Kampa Park.
lesser. This place is truely loverly holds the park, petrin tower, you can get to the monestry and the castle and palace, truely great
Our favorite part of Prague!. This area of Prague has the most interesting buildings, museums, and shops -- definitely be sure to visit it. Also be sure to see the John Lennon (graffiti) wall.

Quiet and beautiful. We toured Kampa Island as part of our Magic of Prague tour with Discover Walks, but it was by no means a touristy area. There was plenty of room to wander and take in the scenery without being run over or worried about pick-pockets. Of course, the John Lennon Wall was very cool and yet another piece of Prague that makes it so unique compared to other European cities.

Time is passing without making changes at this wonderful place!. Great place to be Mala Strana, young and old is walking trough this ancient past of Prague. Take the time to look to the wonderful grafitti paitings on the many facade of this grand houses!

Nothing LESS as far as beauty goes!!. The quiet area west of Charles Bridge in the Kampa Island area is a "little Venice" with its mysterious canals, the cute Water mill churning away, the John Lennon wall & numerous cobble stone streets to savour with quiet leafy parks to spend sunny afternoons in!
Not Bad. We tended to overlook this area as the other places were just that little bit better and had more appealing qualities ..... Still worth a walk around though :)
Love Mala Strana. Petrin Hill and funicular railwayCantina Mexican (Best steak dinner ever for 299kc)Thai massageWatch out for nuns! Nasty bit of work
peace wall. we went here to see the John Lennon peace wall which you can write on and take pictures of as it changes all the time . there are also other works of art on the way there

Don't leave this out of your visit!. The Lennon wall is easy to find if you ask at your hotel reception. A defo must-see - it is near all the embassies. Also just the other side of the Charles Bridge there is a beautiful avenue. There was a food festival there this time. When we last went it was winter and the lights on the trees were just breathtaking.

Great value restaurants and bars - Peaceful Hotels. A real nice change to the Old Town Square side of town. The restaurants are much cheaper, and on the whole more local orientated. Of course that is a generalisation, but I prefer to base myself on this side of the bridge when visiting Prague.Top coffee shop - Cafe SavoyTop hotel - Red and Blue Design HotelTop restaurant - Kolkovna OlympiaThese are just my personal opinions, but all of these can be found within walking distance, and all have good positive reviews available on here. An excellent, quiet part of town to base youself!
Mozart was here. This is probably one of the prettiest areas of Prague. Mozart lived around here. It is not as busy as the old town square.

Very busy by the river. Although there are churches and the terraced gardens, this area is very commercial! Private tour cars for rent here and lots of eateries. It's a very busy area by the river but quiet further up.
The tram runs through with the Infant Jesus of Prague church here.

Best place to stay. Stayed here in Nerudova , quaint and quiet , lots of old interesting bulidings and also wander to see John Lennon wall , maltese suare , walk behind the river and down to Kampa island , lovely areas to discover , all on foot , take your time and discover little alleys and tiny bars and restaurants, just perfect !

nice afternoon wandering around the lesser quarter.. after visiting the castle we had a nice walk around the lesser quarter. it is quite quiet with lots of quaint little streets which seem to be endless. there are some lovely small restaurants too. shops selling the usual tourist souvenirs. there a few embassies with police around them. this quarter has a different feel to it to the other areas of prague. a very enjoyable afternoon's stroll.

I love the history. When visiting Prague, be sure to learn about the history before you go and spend a minimum of three days to tour, eat, bike, hike, and museum hunt. Shopping is typical tourist stuff. Great to spend extra days in Tabor or Ceske Budjovice too
Every street a charmer. We found so many lovely curving streets and lanes in this area, and restaurants with river views, terraces, great czech beer. Much quieter than Old Town

Mala Strana. Great place to walk, quiet streets. We visited three garden complexes: Wallenstein gardens: free, Palace Gardens, fee and Vrtba Gardens, fee. In a busy city we encountered only a few people, in the height of summer. There are also small restaurants where one can eat a crepe and have a drink. We strolled to Kampa island and wandered around under the Charles Bridge. Definitely worth a visit!
Not only embassies. Amongst the embassies in the lesser quarter are restaurants and hotels which whilst away from the centre are a few minutes walk or even less by tram. I liked the area alot

Nice living quarter in Prague.. If you go away from the popular streets linking the Charles Bridge and the Castle, you start seeing less tourists and more locals. Same applies to shops and restaurants. Definitively worst exploring and seeing what living in Prague is about.

Quaint area with lovely shops. I really enjoyed walking around the Mala Strana area. There are lots of souvenir shops to look in (we particularly liked many of the shops along Nerudova street). There are lovely red clay roof buildings here.Restaurants seem to be cheaper on this side of the Charles' Bridge but one that we visited had a 20% VAT tax where the Old Town side was only at 15%.

Climbing up to the castle. The streets of Mala Strana are really typical. If you have enough time, take a stroll in Voyan gardens, Wallenstien gardens, or take the stairs before the end of Charles Bridge and go eat on Kampa peninsula.

Quaint atmosphere of the past. It is a nice part of Prague with a lot of old houses, pubs and shops.There are beautiful baroque churches, e.g. St.Nicolas Church to name a few. You can have a nice stroll and if you feel tired, find a place to sit down and taste Czech beer.

Lesser crowds, do not miss this neighborhood. Highly Recommend you don't miss this area, and give several hours to explore, longer if you go to Petrin Hill , or the Monastery ( eat outside in the far back, fantastic view and very decent Italian meal) or for mediocre food but great beer, the eatery that's on the left side. The area has the best boutique hotels including one with an amazing spa ( Indian theme) , a roof top restaurant at the Aria Hotel, and gardens behind the Aria ( if you go inside they will tell you how to enter), small fee.I can't say enough about this neighborhood. You can also incorporate it after viewing Prague Castle area, depending on your depth of interest.

Nice afternoon. Well worth making it over to the Lesser Quarter, plenty of places to eat with loads of shops to wander through. I particularly enjoyed wandering through the back lanes off the main tourist runs.
Loved this area. The character of this area is great. Felt it was more relaxed than the new town. Not so busy/crowded. Not as much traffic.
Best place to stay and eat.. Stay at the Alchymist Grand Hotel and Spa and eat in Lesser town. It's more reasonably priced and less crowded to eat there.
The quieter side of Prague!. A much more relaxed atmosphere and a lot less tourist orientated. Plenty to see and do and some gorgeous restaurants!

Just lovely. It's less crowded, has lots of interesting side streets and is filled with beautiful buildings. Prices at the stores are more reasonable than in the Old City Center and there are many shops with more unique items for sale.
Worth Visiting. We took a private tour on one of the red mini open vans which also had an audio explanation in all languages. You get to see more and leaern more about the history of Prague this way.

Quaint, quiet, nice. Mala Strana is nice. There are crowds trudging up to the castle but the Mala Strana area below it is quieter just a street or two away. The architecture is smaller than the old town but still quaint.

The best of Prague. For me Mala Strana is the heart of Prague - less comercialized than Old Twn on the other side of the river, full of charming cafes, restaurants and little shops. Tiny, cute streets and amazing building to be seen on every step.

A charming must-visit part of town. Cross the Charles Bridge. If enough time take the stairs down to the left and walk through the Kampa Park.
If not, walk on passing small shops trowards the square with the St.Nicolas Church (often small concerts there).
Also an ideal walking from here and up to the Castle Hill...
surprise find. thankfully not as touristy<yet still busy>area with the usual bars,cafes,moneychangers etc.enjoyable afternoon exploratory stroll for lunch and drinks
lovely area. this area is a beauty in itself, lovely walks by the river and little streets to walk round gift/souvenier shops plentiful

A great way to spend a day. Does not receive the attention it deserves. A wonderful way to while away time. relaxing and enjoying. Walk around the lesser town, enjoy the food, tastes, people. look into shops, try the little cafes, and eating places. Visit the museums, and don't forget to come back for more.
Interesting. Enjoyed walking around here and sitting outside the cafes absorbing the atmosphere, lots of nice eating places to choose from.

Kampa Island Prague a perfect haven - The Real Prague. This is a must see. The thousands of tourists never really find this perfect place. It has fantastic promenade gardens with spectacular riverside views, plenty of shade and really good restaurants serving real Czech dishes. take some time out to explore its quiet paths and lanes of the Real Prague.
other side of brige. so glad i didnt book my hotel on this part of prague, seemed a lot further to walk to old town square etc . still lovely to visit but glad i booked my hotel by old town square.

Good for Walking. The Mala Strana has some interesting architecture, a great atmosphere, plenty of shops and cafes. It is good to loiter some here before walking up the to castle or across the river to Old Town.

A bit of peace and history. Lovely part of town. Really felt in places like it had not changed in centuries. However, also easy to find cafes to sit and watch world go by. The parks are excellent for a rest and some shade.

Great for a self-guided walk. We loved this area. Took the better part of half a day to walk across the Charles Bridge from Old Town, see St. Nicholas and Our Lady Victorious churches, browse through shops, stop for pastry snacks and lunch, and then visit Wallenstein Gardens/Palace -- all the attractions at virtually no cost. To me, the Tower entrance from Charles Bridge into Lesser Quarter is the prettiest of all. Once you've done Old Town, Lesser Quarter is you next must-do. Great half-day walk!
Lovely old buildings and fantastic parks. Canopied streets with chestnut trees and original old buildings set the scene of this lovely district. Check out the parks....lovely!

Wonderful Area. Visit St. Nicholas Cathedral and the Church of St. Thomas. Also Check out the gardens of Wallenstien Palace, the current seat of the Czeck Senate. Lots of good places to eat and easy access to Kampa Island.
Lesser Quarter. Our hotel U Pava was in this district and it is a great location to stay. Tons of great nooks and cranies to explore, great shops, churches and restaurants close by.

Best part of the city!. We stayed in this part of Prague, and it was perfect! Since it's the area where all the embassies and none of the clubs are located, it was peaceful, clean, and within easy walking distance of everything we wanted to see. From our location about halfway up Nerudova Street, we had the most amazing views as well as a great selection of cafes and restaurants without the huge crowds.
Beautiful Old Town. Lovely architecture, great shops and restaurants. Hard to find your way around at first, but once you get your bearings, it is a cinch and well worth exploring.

Very nice to walk through. Many jazz bars. Might be worth trying. Athmosphere seems nice in medieval settings. Many open late at night and are open into the early morning hours. Easy to return via steps to old town

Good for a stroll and sightseeing.. We went here because our tour bus passed through and we came back for a visit. The St. Nicholas Church, the old town hall, the palace and other buildings are worth seeing. It is also a short walk to the western end of the Charles Bridge.

Mala Strana - too special to miss. Mala Strana (the Lesser Town or Lesser Quarter) is something special in Prague. Cross the Charles Bridge, and either go down the steps towards Kampa Park and Nosticova, or continue right over the bridge and join the bustle of the tourist-oriented street for a few metres before diving off to the left and in to the network of cobbled and sett streets. A few metres along Karmelitska, just past Trziste (excuse the lack of accents, Czech speakers!) and an unimposing lane leads you into a restored Baroque garden, a haven of peace and tranquility, with terraces leading you up to a fine view of the city and beyond.Walk up Triste and past the American Embassy: you can lose yourself in the little maze of quiet streets that run parallel to the busy Nerudova which carries the tourist up to the castle. Here you can find little restaurants, imposing hotels, beautiful former palaces and, eventually, make your way up the hill to Petrin, the fading but still fascinating park.Petrin houses small treasures, like the hall of mirrors and diarama, and an observatory, as well as a smaller version of M. Eiffel's tower. It even has a funicular railway to whizz you back to reality!On your way there look round the back of the German Embassy where they still display the Golden Trabi (that's one for you to research!). And keep an eye out for Dum U Velke Boty, a rare, quirky, traditional and original guest house on the square opposite the German Embassy. From Petrin you can easily access the Strahov Monastery, and from Vlasska a ramble through a little maze of streets will bring you back to Nerudova and the crowds. If it gets a little too quiet, head for Malostanske Namesti, the busy square surrounding St Nicholas Cathedral. Lift your eyes up from street level and admire the fantastic and beautiful architecture. Prepare to be over-awed!
Beautifully preserved. The Parliament Buildings and surrounding gardens are very attractive.
What a Bridge. We spent a long time just soaking up the atmosphere on the Bridge. The Towers at both ends made you feel as though you had stepped back in time.

Especially magical in the evening. This area is genuinely enchanting and the perfect escape from the Old Town circus! You just have to get a hundred meters away from the tourist throng near the Charles Bridge to find yourself more or less alone in Mala Strana, under a golden belle epoque street light and surrounded by towering townhouses, disturbed only by voices from the many little alley bars and restaurants and the streetcar bells. We stayed in Smichov (cheaper) but walked or took the tram up there several times, wish we'd had much more time to explore!

Lovely area to wander. I actually preferred this area to the Old Town, lovely cobble streets, gardens and squares. The tiered gardens coming down from the Castle walls to the town centre was just lovely.

go back in time. go back in time ,this part of prague is old ,narrow streets many cobbled,great eating places and several old beer cellers hidden in various back streets.some high class restaurants bordering the river.you can catch a tram on the old square corner of mala strana to take you out to smicow with its super shopping precinct and the famous stramopraman brewery which has vistors tours,on the way back get off the venicular train that climbs up the hill giving a full view of prague
worth the time. Good eating a few streets back. Wander the streets as you come down from the tower. Nice park near the art gallery and watch the water activities

Nice area to stroll and eat. This is a less touristy area of Prague. It is on the other side of the Vltava river ( opposite the touristy old town). It has some really nice courtyards that we stepped into and also nice restaurants. There are also several restaurants that have a terrace on the Vltava river. We did not eat there, but they did seem a great place to sit in the evening for a drink and meal.

Charming and quiet area - a nice change from the Old Town. Prague is stunningly beautiful but much of the city is crowded with tourists, especially in the Old Town. It can be a little overwhelming at times. However, the Lesser Quarter is a nice change of pace. It's peaceful, quiet, and just as beautiful but without the crowds! We wandered over here after visiting the John Lennon Wall and I'm so glad we spent some time on this side of the Charles Bridge. It quickly became one of our favorite parts of visiting Prague. There are parks, flowing streams, colorful pastel buildings, cafes, and cobblestone streets. We spent a few hours one afternoon just wandering around and taking it all in. I suggest seeing the unique "bridge of love locks" as well as the John Lennon Wall while you're in this area.
well worth a walk around. quiet beautiful area which is great to discover. take you time to examine all roads

A personal guide. Having a very limited amount of time we hired a personal guide through our hotel who drove us around Prague for three hours. This was the way to go if you have limited time. We were able to stop and see many areas that we normally would not have known about. A great city and a wonderful experience

Intriguing little streets and pretty details to spot.. We wandered through this area to get up to our hotel in the Castle District, and it was picturesque, lots of winding alleys, steps, pretty windows, railings, gates, quirky shops.
The Hip Area. I found myself going here more than any other district in Prague. Embassies, restaurants,wonderful buildings and located close to the river. This area is a local favorite.
Great place to stay. Hotel at the Green Grape is a marvelous small hotel in the Lesser Quarter, conveniently located, quiet, and close to a lot of different restaurants.

Just beautiful!. The quiter and much more beautiful part of stare mesto Praha is something you just don't miss. All of it's roads, and side roads are beautiful, during the evening it's filled with a very charming smell (evening primrose, most likely). It less crowded and you wont see as much turists. Don't miss the John Lenon wall, where new greafiti is always added, the wall with the lockers (don't know how it's called exactly but it's just a couple of feet away from the John Lenon wall). In generally just a slow walk in the heart of Mala Strana will make you fall in love with the city.
Kampa island. A quiet oasis with a good restaurant (Kampa island) very close to the bustle of Charles Bridge. Also worth a visit is the Kafka Museum, 5 mins walk away

Get out of the Old Town, and wander here. Loved the area, and especially the little streets, and the John Lennon 'peace' wall. Lots of cute cafes and interesting shops once you are out of the main thoroughfare.
Very pretty. A boat trip across the river brought us to the little Venice with some awe inspiring evidence of the last time it flooded
Stay in this district. Less busy than the main old town, this was a great place to stay and wander safely late at night. Good restaurants and plenty of history here too!
Interesting. this was one of our favourite places. Take the time to wander round, there are lots of places to stop for refreshment or sit in one of the little parks for a while & chill out.
a must see.... definitely worth the visit, loved the sites and sounds a picture perfect place!
Lovely Area. We stayed at one of the lovely boutique hotels in this area. There are so many inviting and refreshing parks. We wish we had more time.
Cute as a postcard. the whole place is a picture postcard and no establishments are really expensive. try it and take a camera!

Nice historic walk through Lesser Town. Again, like most places in Prague, it is very crowded in this area. But there is lots to see and do. So take your time. Don't miss all the little narrow streets. As you steer away from all the major attractions you find some interesting and beautiful little streets.

I stayed in this district. The park there is beautiful. The funicular ride to the top is a must! Make sure you have good walking shoes because it can be challenging. Good shopping and decent food options.

Despite the name, by no means lesser. There are still many, many attractions, restaurants, shops and other things to keep you busy for many hours. Great hotels, wonderful walks, and carriage rides add to the experience. There really isn't a single place in the city that is better than others, try to see them all.

quaint, charming quirky. The Mala Strana is across the bridge from the central square and is more quiet especially off the main street. There are charming little sqaures with galleries and cafes, embassies parks as well as
St. Nikolas church, the Kafka Museum, the Wallenstein Gardens,
the Artel Crystal Shop etc.
