Charming beauty. This part of Prague is a must see. Sit a while at a cafe or stop into "Lokal" for some amazing (and inexpensive) local beer and yummy food!

Great place to stay in Prague. So close to everything if you like to walk to restaurants, historical and scenic sights. If you are a jogger, Kampa park and by the riverside are great places to jog. Also a lot of activity around here. Lots to see and do! Very lively area and SOOO close to everything!

Stay here. Our hotel was in this pretty and lively area. Lots of good restaurants and quaint streets for wandering. People seem to live and work in this area, so it does not feel entirely touristy. We used the tram system to get back to Mala Strana from the Old Town, saving some of the uphill walk.
I wouldn't call it Lesser!. We stayed thi side and definately the prices were lesser!

Jewish Quarter was so interesting. We found ourselves immersed in the history of the Jewish Quarter, also know as Josefov. If you enjoy 15th-20th century history, you will be completely enlightened by what happened here over the past several centuries.

Two sites to visit in the Lesser Quarter. First, the St. Nicholas Church is well worth the admission fee which I believe was about 60 CZK. The church is absolutely full of golden cherubs. Even the pulpit has cute little cherubs surrounding it. There is a huge statue of St. Nicholas in the center of the altar. The church was built in the early 1700's in the Baroque style. Pictures are allowed in this cathedral. Secondly, go to the lesser known KGB Museum located a block from the U.S. Embassy. For a family of 2 adults and 2 students it was 660 CZK total and it was well worth it. The owner/collector gives a wonderfully informative guided tour as part of the price. There are so many authentic pieces such as guns, uniforms, Lenin's death face mask, knives, and spy equipment there. Some are not behind glass, and the owner will let you touch/hold them.

Lovely area. This area was near the celebrated Charles Bridge and worth a visit. Underneath the bridge are lots of lovely cafes and bars with an inket from the Vltava river running by. The flowers on the houses were a picture so chose your timing carefully of when to visit.
great value. go here for cheaper food, great beer and a taste of what the outer parts of prague are like. it is close to the castle and the park where the old wooden church is
Peaceful. A quiet change from the hustle and bustle of the city - lovely area to walk around and not be rushed.

My favorite part of Prague. This section of town might be tiny but its worth it. Charming squares, hidden gardens, great places to sit along the river. Its really a perfect place for a relaxing afternoon.
Loved this area. Found some brilliant restaurants (Cantina being a favorite!) and it was where our hotel was situated. Nice and quiet but easy to get to the main attractions. Felt safe and at home!
Very interesting. We walked up from the Old Town Square and it was very enjoyable. Had some lunch here as well it it was good
A special area. Wandering the narrow, curved streets is an adventure! Lots of cute little shops, great restaurants, and historic sites! Enjoy.
A must see. You have not been to Prague if you have not seen Mala Strana. Definitely worth spending time there.
Pragues Best Kept Secret. Quiet, green, less expensive are of Prague. In the evening, unlike in the Old Town, you can actually hear yourself think.
Nice shops. I was looking for some nice Polish pottery and found a great shop in the lesser quarter about two blocks from the American Embassy.

Spend a few hours walking around here. We really enjoyed hte Lesser Quarter, probably more than the Old Town. There are very interesting shops and restaurants and we likely had the best meal of our trip at a small restaurant at the bottom of a set of stairs to the bridge. And unfortunately, paid cash, and can't remember the name.

Historially authentic place of Prague. Lots of churchs, palaces, and parks. Situated in the hill below Prague Castle and beyond the Lesser Town Bridge Tower of Charles Bridge. It is one of untouched beautiful historical area with little shops, restaurants, and government buildings, and embassies and parks. The finest and the most prominent architecture in Mala Strana is St. Nocholas Church. A famous statue of the Holy Infant Jesus of Prague is located in the Church of Our Lady Victorious. Take a stroll around Lesser Quarter. Another place to worth visiting is the Grand Priory Square. There is slow moving mill in the Devils Stream. This area is more famous for its graffiti.

A nice respite from crowds. As with the rest of inner Prague, interesting and well preserved architecture, much more residential. More green areas/parks than across the river, also a modern art museum with interesting collections.
Great hidden restaurants!. Loved wandering through this area. We spent many afternoons there and had amazing food and drinks in the sidewalk cafes!
Nothing lesser about this!. Again, lots of interesting history and buildings. Arrange a tour guide to give you the story behind the story.

Excellent area to stay in.. Excellent part of Prague to stay in, just steps away from Charles Bridge. Quieter than the Old town, but with just as much atmosphere and character. Within easy walking distance of all the major tourist sites and the Castle District. Good shops and restaurants. We loved staying here!

back to the past!. At the end of Charles bridge in Prague you find the beautiful Mala Strana. It is an unbelievable place: you are very close to the centre and at the same time it seems an old town from the past. Silent, quiet, giving the sensation to be in another century!
Back to ancient times, a place with soul. As I walked this part of town I could imagine the Prague of that time

Lots to see. See St. Nicholas Cathedral, US Embassy, Vrbta gardens, Churches, John Lennon Peace Wall, Kampa Park. Beautiful, reminds me of some places in Paris. Check out the craft beer store on Lazenska - many hard-to-get beers and glasses for sale. My favorite place to buy beer for the hotel room.
Worth visiting.. Tha garden is very nice, also the views are good:)
Near the Alchymist Grand hotel. Don't miss John lennon wall, and Kampa Island with it's big wooden wheel of the former mill
Nice & quiet area good place to stay. Really nice area to stay because it's a lot quieter and a short walk from Old Town.

Best part of Prague. If possible, try to stay at Mala Strana. It is the best part of Prague. Not too busy, not too touristic, great atmosphere, shops, restaurants, you can walk from here to every tourist attraction. Close to Petri Park, the Castle. We loved staying in this part.

Lovely to stroll around.. Lovely place to stroll around. We went to John Lennon's wall which was good to see and quite interesting. Lots of nice little shops and cobbled streets just of the Charles Bridge. Good for a wander.
Walk through this wonderful neighborhood. This is the section of town to stay in! visit the Infant of Prague church and tour the upstairs.

A gem. Despite tourist cafes and hotels being legion, the area has lots to other things to offer in terms of walks, interesting architecture, views, the funicular, plus many surprising bars and restaurants meeting the needs of all pockets. Tram 22 is ubiquitous, usually packed and the lifeblood of the area. Get a 24 hour pass for buses, trams and Metro to hop on and off at each stop to discover new bits and get another scenic view of the castle, river and environs. It changes daily.
small amazing streets. small streets full of beauty and history and art. You feel in heavens.
JEWISH QUARTER. Very sad, but interesting. We visited all the synagogues and this should not be missed as very much a part of Pragues history.
A grand large history. Beautiful palaces all in one area. Gardens and palaces. Lots to see.

The best part of Prague. If you are staying in Prague for a long weekend or just a couple of days, the Mala Strana is the place to base yourself. Whilst the Castle, Charles Bridge and the Mostecka are always packed from around 9.30am onwards, just metres away are some very good places to stay and eat and drink, that are not packed with the usual tourist tat and overpriced dross. Though generally slightly more expensive than the Old and New Town areas, the quality, generally is superior enough to justify it. It became our favourite area of the whole city, with unexpected discoveries in all sorts of nooks as well as the more famous ones dotted around. The perfect place to base yourself in the city and if you do spend an evening in the Old or New Town, the perfect walk back to where you are staying over the incredible Charles Bridge.
Mala Strana. an interesting area and well worth wandering around. Make sure you visit the Wallenstein gardens - part of the parliament buildings.

Charm and fun. Plenty of embassies, the narrow streets invites to walk and discover secret places. You can find different restaurants and bars, with very affordable prices and good quality.From here you can reach the Prague Castle and the Saint Nicholas Church. The tram helps very much there.
mala strana. very nice quarter with small coffe houses and gifts shops

Restored old Buildings with plenty of character. Cobblestone side streets with small shops, churches to explore and lots of traditional Czech pubs and restaurants to discover.Mala Strana clusters around the foothills of Prague Castle,
Lots to see. Many hidden gems in this histpric area of a delightful city. Wonderfully preserved!
A Great Place to Visit and Dine. Excellent shops and restaurants. Check out the Alchemyst Museum and coffee shop, including the Edward Kelley Tower

The town to base your Prague adventures from.. Satyed in Mala Strana at the Aria Hotel. Best place to stay in terms of access to sites. Walking distance from everywhere. Plenty of shops, cafes, restaraunts, bars, currencty conversion desks. Tram runs through the town, streets are clean, subtle police presence - you never feel threatened or insecure. Prices are very reasonable everywhere, my wife commented she couldnt believe how cheap Prague is (eating, drinking etc). It's almost as if the Czech's undersell the beauty, mystique and wonder that Prague offers. Only tip - look out for dodgy taxi's (like every city has). My advice - stick to the 'AAA' taxis - they have a '14xxx' phone number on the side - they are clean, safe and fully licensed - average fair for 10 minutes about $10 aussie dollars. English understood in 90% of places - even if it isnt, staff are always happy to help overcome and mis-understandings. Mala Strana is a great place to stay and start your love affair with Prague

not very impressive. Perhaps since it was easter sunday and the shops were closed, we couldn't find much here and it wasn't that interesting. we did pop into a restaurant for lunch where we could get authentic czech food which was nice.

A lovely area to explore. I loved this area of Prague. Full of cobbled streets, small shops, a myriad of eating houses and cheaper than central Prague. You can explore the monastery up a steep hill where you get such fantastic views of the centre of Prague. St. Vitus Cathedral and Prague Castle are both nearby and I was surprised just how quiet it was for Easter compared to the central area which always seemed busy. It is a very unhurried part of Prague and with lots to see and do it is a perfect way to explore a part of Prague where there aren't too many tourists bustling around.

like a secret locals keep to themselves. We never would have made it on our own, good thing our guide (discover walks) took us there - totally magical, totally delivers on what "Praga Magica" is supposed to be about.
Make sure you find the back alleys. Very romantic.

Music to my ears. This was my favourite area of Prague because, in my opinion, it offered the best bars and restaurants and had a less touristy feel. I recommend visiting U Maleho Glena which is a small pub along Karmelistska offering live jazz and blues every night.
Tower worth a climb. Petrin Hill tower is worth a visit. Great views of the city. Use the funicular to get there. Only a short trip but worth it. Can walk too.
stay here. Definitely a better place to stay, eat and drink than the old town area!! Better value for money and less touristy!
Lovely views. Great bustling area with lots of shops and restaurants. Very steep hill / stairs to climb but worth it for the wonderful views.

NICE AREA TO WALK AROUND. Although there were plenty of touristy type shops, there was some lovely little restaurants, and some great architecture. Great for a walk round and to get away a bit from the maddening crowd.
Nice place for dining. The restaurants close to the church are good and fairly well priced. Good place for dine out
We stayed here. The park on the island was lovely in the sun and the strange figure sculptures on the steps worth a look. Charles Bridge on the edge is a must see.
Quaint. Not as busy as the Old Town or Wenceslas Square but filled with interesting shops and restaurants

Great neighborhood full of fun cafes and restaurants.. We didn't explore lesser town as much as we would have hoped, but what we did see of it we loved. Not as touristy as the other side of the river, Lesser Town's winding streets are full of quaint little cafes and amazing restaurants and shops. Will definitely spend more time exploring this area next trip out. Don't miss the Lennon Wall, too!Full Prague Review: http://www.brettandmandydatenight.com/2012/03/prague-243-2732012.html

Little Gem. Preferred this area, less crowded and the bars and restaurants much better value. Especially liked Joe's bar. Great food and drink and the music added to a great ambience. popular with tourists and locals alike.

Quiet elegance. We were lucky enough to stay in Mala Strana, a few hundred metres from the Charles Bridge. It's a fascinating historical area and very quiet in the evenings. Strolling around the tiny squares and sitting outside their charming tavernas was one of the highlights of our trip.

full of shops. this was a lovely area to buy things to take home. Prague is into its glass, jewlery, and lots of souveniers.The charles bridge is off this area and you can get a boat trip from this area too.We brought a bagette from here for lunch, but it cost us £6 !!!, so ne careful, and dont buy food in the tourist area

Emotional drawings; sad rememberance. Moving stories to be found here, both in script and drawings. Could not believe the graves that housed the Cemetry, lots of messages written and placed upon headstones. my only negative is that why would anyone wish to capitalise on such grave reminders????
so-so. The famous cathedral there is only open to you pay a fee to enter the church. Seems like they have gone commerical.

the only way is up!. Lesser means somethign for sure: it stands at the bottom of the way to the castle and the only way really is up1 This is where all the shops begin all the way up to the castle district ,but i advise you buy on the way down (unless you have some strong biceps). Just like the rest of the city: Beautiful!
eat and drink. some good local pubs and restaurants with a authentic czech feel about it.

The most atmospheric part of Prague. The route from charles bridge to the castle (Mostecka and Nerudova streets) is choc-full of tourists but still you cannot deny the beauty of these quarters. Once you're done with that walk, you can really begin enjoying the place with walks to Kampa island and around the lesser trod parts of the lesser quarter. As always, the best time to visit is early in the morning, before things get crowded.
Look out of the window. The view from our Hotel, (The Golden Star) looked down across the lesser quarter, a good mix of restaurants, bars and shops as you walked down toward the Charles Bridge.
Visit St. Nicholas Church. The church was the only thing worth seeing. Use the cable lift to get to the top of the hill. The views are spectular.

Great architecture, neat old-town feeling, nice for a stroll. We live nearby and stroll through here often. You'll find the narrow alleys and passageways to be quite charming, and while there are still plenty of tourists meandering through here during the high season, you won't feel quite as bombarded by "tourist traps" as you might on the other side of the river in Old Town. Prices are slightly better here than near the Old Town Square (Staroměstské náměstí), but if you want genuine local prices, head a short ways south along the street Karmelitska/Ujezd (the trams run north-south along this street).
Lovely walk. along the river then into the little streets- loads of antigue shops to check out and the coffee seems to be cheaper this side of town

A great place to wander. You can't go to Prague without wandering through this district at least once as it's between the Stare Mesto/Astronomical Clock, the Charles Bridge and the Prague Castle/St Vitus Cathedral complex. It's still touristy, but much less so than just across the bridge. Be sure to get lost on any side street and have lunch or an espresso at the first place you come to. Also, you'll notice that many of the foreign embassies have opted to locate in this neighborhood which seems like recommendation enough.
Worth a look.. We only did Church of St.Nicholas which is vast and ornate. They love to decorate there churchs.
worth a visit. lesser quaters is quaint with lovely buildings and little side streets. well worth a visit.

Where to eat.... Great place to find cheap eateries with loads of character. Can recommend the tiny restaurant on corner of Malostraneska namesti and Mostecka. It is where the executioner (Jan somebody) visited! Still original features from 1400s and serves up 3 course traditional lunch for £10 (2500 Kruna)

Bars and shops. Great place to drink, eat and shop and not as busy as the Old town, you will need to enter Lesser quarter to get to the castle which is up a big hill, so it is great to have plenty of places to stop off at en route.
Beautiful. Very beautiful as all the other parts of old town. The restaurants are cheaper here...
Be sure to explore. Visit St Nicholas church (watch for closing times!) and try out some of local eateries (we enjoyed both Nos 8 & 10 Malostranske namesti)

Quieter & artsy. A great place to escape the crowds for a bit. You can wander the little streets, check out some funky shops, grab a coffee & sit by a canal A bit more bohemian with fabulous architecture.
Lesser Town. I would advise staying in this area. It is a neat area and you are close to everything. It felt very historic.
Another Must!. Plenty of medieval buildings, churches, and historical palaces. Take your time strolling around - there are plenty of restaurants and watering holes if you get tired and thirsty.
So full of atmosphere. Walk and look around, it's amazing. Go in late spring and visit the Castle Gardens, lovingly taken care of. Walk in the steps of the Bohemian kings....
shops and restaurants. The lesser quarter has beautiful architecture as does the rest of prague. There are plenty of shops and restaurants for lunch/dinner or just to stop for a snack.
One of our favorites. Our hotel was here and we loved the stylish historical part of Prague. Great to wander around and find some delightful little streets and cafes.
Wonderful. Loved Mala Strana, narrow streets and atmosphere. Very nice place to take a walk.

Interesting area. We took the tram down from the castle and wandered the streets as you come across the river from the Charles Bridge. There are interesting shops and buildings and we found a lovely cafe for lunch called Cafe Victoria.It is about 100 yards from the bridge on the right hand side and there is a Starbucks opposite. It was very new and modern inside but sold Czech food as well as more Italian type dishes. We had a Czech burger which was nothing like what we would know as a burger and it was served in a huge pitta bread. Highly recommended.
Just get lost!. This is the best way to see the area, walk up one street, down another, up little alleys you see much more that way, but as you do all over Prague keep looking up at the buildings.
Gorgeous. Take in Lennon Wall, and some of the galleries along the way and you will not be disappointed.Without a doubt one of the most beautiful parts of Prague.

One of the most atmospheric places in Europe. Some streets are among the most crowded in Prague, but there are many cute corners off the beaten track... It's all very serene and atmospheric and just pleasant
tiny streets. beatiful atmosphere, tiny streets, cosy restaurants
quiet and charming. This is the quiet old Prague and we felt it was the best place to stay. We were close to the castle and not very far from the old town.

worth a stroll across the bridge.. Some amazing architecture, cafes, restaurants and gift shops. Pretty cobbled streets with arcades on some.Shops are small gift shops , all the big stores are near Wenceslas Square at the other side of the river.
Must see and wander about. Spent alot of time walking about here. Very atmospheric
Nicer part of town. Stayed this side of Prague and liked it better then the other side. It is a great location and near to everything including Petrin Hill and tower, Prague castle and Charles bridge
Lovely place of Prague. So many architectonical styles, old houses lot of renovated for hotels and restaurants. Pitoresque streets-

A walk with Jan Neruda. Having studied hard before my visit to Prague, Neruda, Capek, Kundera etc I was ready for a walk through the Mala Strana up to the castle. Fabulous atmosphere, and lots of small details to catch the eye and gladden the heart!

I want to live here!. Beautiful, interesting, historic and full of wonderful hidden surprises! You might even get to meet the lady who walks her cougar on a pink lead! The river path is wonderful and a welcome break from the hustle and cobbles of the Old Town
Under the castle. At the far side of the famous medieval Charles Bridge, you pass through this impressive square on your way to the castle and cathedral.
Our hotel was here.......thank goodness!. This area where we stayed had quite a different atmosphere to the centre. We loved it because it was less brash.
A great base camp!. We stayed on the Mala Strana side of the river which was great. However we spent most of our time on the other side. Easy and quick travel time- walking!

Full of treasures. Such a difference between one side of the Charles Bridge to the other - you seem to move from the hustle and bustle on one side to a more tranquil place. It is full of little restaurants and bars (if you ignore the McDonalds!) and little alleys to explore full of unique shops. On the way there we found the Museum of Franz Kafka with the 'urinating figures' outside.

It is hard to have a "tour" of Prague and not see Mala Strana. Most everyone comes to Prague and sees the castle and of course walks to Charles Bridge --- but do make sure to take at least a half hour or so and walk around the bridge ---- to see the often overlooked sites in the Lesser Quarter - Mala Strana. You can see St. Nicolas Church, St. Thomas Church and the Infant Jesus of Prague --- all of which are within 5 min of Charles Bridge. But you can also drop by to see the Knights of Malta's church of Our Lady Under the Chain and the Grand Prior's Palace --- both next to each other and 1 min from Charles bridge. Steeped in history, the Knights of Mala have had a continuous existence here in Prague for over 800 years !!!
Underated. Mala Strana is full of very good restaurants, activities and cultural sites. definitely worth a visit. The tourist shop there is fantastic full of all sorts of information.

Beautiful part of Prague. When you walk over Charles Bridge to the Lesser Quarter, you find the most beautiful buildings there. It is clean & well kept. We walked all the way to the Castle (on our second day we took tram 22, but you will miss most of the beautiful places). We came upon a little shop that also sell crystal glasses that wasn't that expensive as in town centre. You need to wear comfortable shoes as it is cobble stones all the way. Make sure you also take some water with. There are so money things to see & do on this side of the river, we spend 3 of our 6 days this side

Best area in Prague. I was impressed by how clean and well-kept this area of Prague is. Other parts of the city has not been as well preserved as this area. This area also has a lot of nice shops and cafes.
Old & Pretty Area in Prague. Here you will find St Nicholas Church, amongst other churches and also many bars and traditional restaurants. You could also shop quite a bit in this area

A much quieter part of the city. Being on the other side of the river makes the Mala Strana a little less hectic or so it seemed. It was lovely to walk the streets, even in the rain, and see the various palaces (which some house embassies) and the special touches over the small streets and buildings. I think the next time I visit Prague, I would like to stay on this side of the river and explore more. The shops and cafes are numerous and quaint. The restaurants have interesting names and it just seems to be a lower key place to be while imagining yourself in the place of royalty.

For Lesser Quarter read -- BEST BIT !!. This is the jewel in Pragues crown , where you can escape from the madding crowd slip into a truly " local " beer hall and drink with only Czechs , where there are wonderful " one off " shops selling hand made clothes , crafts and paintings ; antique shops not yet in the guide books but superb value and quality .Too many wonderful restaurants to sample in less than a month nd with the best view of Prague from the monastery gardens . I could go on -- Suffice to say this is the best of Prague !!
Excellent location. So much to see in such a little space! Mala Strana is beautiful, a little bit busier than expected but they have some very nice restaurants and gorgeous sights!
picture perfect town. lovely part of town with lots of chocolate box type houses on cobbled streets.

Little Quarter. I recently took a trip to Prague in December & I loved this area. When you cross the Charles Bridge from the Old Town, you're in Mala Strana. You continue through the neighbourhood & can hike up the hill to the palace complex.The Little Quarter is full of small shops & streets, cafes, squares & lots of historic buildings to admire along the way.I would go to this district again.Prague people are a little more cool and quiet than other Europeans, but they are helpful.
Brilliant. The opposite side of the town across King Charles Bridge, lovely small restaurants,stall and shops...cheaper to eat here.Tram 22 from here goes straight up the the castle.

Lesser doesn't mean inferior!. Well, this area is a hidden gem - restaurants are plentiful, and checking the menu prices against those over the bridge, quite competitive in price. Trams are frequent, and there are lots of walks and interesting sights to see - public street art, sculptures on the stepped monument to anti-communism. One good restaurant not mentioned in the lists is Stara Pradelna , Ricni 9. with a cellar restaurant. Try the Malostran basta for two if you are hungry - a huge dish of mixed meats - and yes, you've guessed it - dumplings!

Iconic but touristy. Go up the Nicholas Church tower, which is both interesting and offers fabulous views. The restaurants and other services are more expensive than you can find just a few minutes off the beaten path. Good access to trams and taxis, but walking is the best way to see the city. Take the back roads.
Beautiful buildings and a great range of restaurants too. Don't miss this bit particularly if you like to eat well.
We stayed in this area. Our apartment was located in the Mala Strana. Great shops, restaurants. Better to take the tram to Old Town vs walking.

simply gorgeous. when you step off Charles Bridge, you are automatically in Mala Strana and it leads to the Cathedral and the Castle. I found this area more touristic, narrow streets and great to wander.
Nice to stroll around. It's a nice rambling area, good for wandering and window shopping. Small Christmas market and lots of nice cafes.
Not so lesser IMO. Have a nose about over the river and see the John Lennon wall.
The Lesser Quarter Magic. Wander through the quaint streets at night for a trip back through the centuries..
Little stube. lovely little restaurant with excellent food and lovely atmosphere.

Diamonds are forever!. If, like me, you love seeing beautiful artefacts and precious stones you must visit the Loreta. However, if you have a guide book don't pay for the audio guide as it doesn't tell you anything you don't already know. If I go to Prague again I will go again to see the treasury at the Loreta.

Narrow, dark streets. Mala Strana is the area between the river and the Castle district. I had a great time walking around (and getting lost on) the small cobblestone streets. Fantastic old buildings line the streets, painted in faded pastel colours. The area has a dark atmosphere, which I loved. An excellent part of Prague to throw away the map and just go walking.

good for eating. We stayed in this district, it was ideally placed for everywhere, and lots of cafes , bars restaurants and little shops. Also two good parks to walk in kampa park is in stunning loation and has incredible variety of birds including woodpeckers
Quaint!. Lovely restuarants by the river with amazing views, but these come with a cost.

Best location in Prague. When researching where to stay in Prague I read about the neighborhoods. I chose this area even though Old Town seems to be "where its at". I am so glad I came here instead. It's just a lovely spot and the climb to the castle is full of little shops and panoramic views of the city. Spend a day here and if you can, choose Aria hotel. You will be close to the Charles Bridge and walking over to Old Town area via the bridge is no trouble at all.
we stayed in this quarter. We stayed at the Santini and loved this area of town, you must travel up Nerudova to see the house signs, it is a pleasent walk to the castle

My Favorite Area of Prague. Mala Strana is seductively picturesque and rich in beautiful lanes and buildings that look like they are right out of a fairy tale. It's a great location to stay during your visit to Prague being less crowded than the other side of the River but at the same time offering easy access to all the attractions. Be sure to plan time to just wander the wonderful lanes filled with historic buildings, shops, restaurants, pubs and exquisite boutique hotels. We stayed for 10 days at the Golden Well top notch boutique hotel tucked away at the end of one of the many historic lanes in Mala Strana and were so happy we did. We loved the pace and old world feeling of Mala Strana.
Fab. Loved the buildings and atmosphere, hard to believe it's real

Atmospheric Prague. This is how you imagine prague lots of cobbled streets plenty of
bars and restaurants and quanit hotels.
Enjoyable. Loved the little Ferrari Cafe and the atmosphere of the whole place - cakes were to die for! The whole lesser quarter had a great atmosphere too and another little Christmas market.

wonderful place to watch the locals. while still touristy, lots more locals and young people are in this neighborhood. The shops are not overpriced as much and the parks and museums in this area feel less crowded.
Lesser Quarter. Stayed in Lesser Quarter-prices were better than Old Town-closer to attractions we wanted to see.

amazing anytime of the day. best place to just chill and people watch..the attractions are all nearby.. places to have coffee or pivo are quiet near.. tho' pricey.
at dawn, quiet magical.. and turns even more mystical at dusk..
Our favorite area in Prague. Magical and romantic- perfect place to get lost for an evening

Mala Strana retains the medieval ambience. Mala Strana has its own character -- less commerical than the larger quarters on the other side of the river. You'll find lesser known, but no less lovely churches -- its own St. Nicholas, St. Katejan and Our Lady Victorius which houses the famed "Infant of Prague." Malna Strana has great restaurants, interesting shops and nice hotels. It's also convenient to the castle and St. Vitus.

round and round. Lovely quaint area, got the Lennon Wall and Kafka Museum, take a padlock/bikelock/anykindalock if u wanna' seal ur love' on the bridge by the water wheel-just round from the wall- fab area
good place to stay. Quieter than the Old Town. Some great pubs {I used the Timeout guide which had some great recommendations}. Very convenient for the castle {hilly}.
Musical instrument museum. Excellent display of instruments with some sound recordings. I always wanted to hear what a quarter tone clarinet sounded like. Now I know.
professional. I liked the signs that it gives this clock sun set time sun rise time etc.,

Don't miss Lesser Town!. I wandered into Lesser Town not really knowing where I was and I fell in love!! Nice and quite...it wasnt full of tourists like Prague Castle's area and it was really old european charm! Once you get to the top of the hill you get a gorgeous view of the city!! Stop at any of the food vendors on the sides of the buildings for a snack! The waffles on a stick were awesome!!
Nice area. Our apartment was in this area and it was such a nice walk at the end of the day. We liked just walking up and down the narrow street popping in and out of shops.

Just wander through the streets. Like the Old Town this is a place to just wander about through small winding streets. Lots of the streets are steep so a good plan could be to start at the top and work your way down! Beautiful buildings, churches, squares there is so much to admire. Shame about the Starbucks!

Less crowded but just as lovely!. We wandered through the streets. Especially liked the embassy row, and Senate garden with the Owl aviary and Dripped stone wall was most interesting. Don't miss the John Lennon graffiti wall!

Cafes, Restaurants, Tourist Menus!. A busy area just up the road from our hotel, overlokked by the stunning St Nicholas church and round the corner the much quieter and very impressive St Thomas Church (sv Tomas). Quieter at night than the Tyn Square / Old Town area but plenty of choice for eating

John Lennon Wall in Lesser Town. Go to the Lennon Wall and you will meet people from all over the world who loved John Lennon's IMAGINE and GIVE PEACE a chance. I met some young students from Turkey who told I was so lucky to have been in high school when the Beatles were singing and they insisted on taking a picture with me in front of the wall.
My favorite area in Prague. A lot of fun! Many boutique shops, cafes and music bars. Good food and drink choices.

Fabulous building and friendly people. We stayed in this area and loved it, the restauranters, bar owners and shop keepeer seems friendlier than on the other side of the bridge and the atmosphere is great. We had some wonderful meals and the churches and building are fabulous!!
great neighborhood to walk in. also had great restaurants, recommend BarBAr for atmosphere and dinner

Too touristy. The only real disappointment we had in Prague - the whole area is too commercial and it was the only time we felt we were being ripped off. We happy to get out of it although it was very pretty

enjoyed shopping for crystals and amber. if you like shopping for jewels made of amber and granade it´s a nice spot. Also I found a fantastic shop for crystals right at malastrana square. it´s a expensive spot to eat but not so much for shopping.
Really Lovely. We stayed in this quarter in the Golden Star hotel. It really is one of the prettiest parts of Prague and just a little away from the tourist crowds

Beautiful, picturesque; essential Prague. Many tourists feel the pull of the hurly burly of the other side of the river, or just look down on Mala Strana from the castle. This results in less crowded streets, but still has all the medieval charm of an old city. If you can take the time the walk the small streets of Mala Strana, sample the eateries here, and just sit and people watch you will have soaked up more of the atmosphere of Prague.  Cross over the Charles Bridge and just keep walking, and walking, and walking. The sit and sit and sit. Lovely.

most beautiful quater of the city of prague. A lot of the prague attractions are in or near Mala Strana. It is busy day and nightbut a must see and it is a very pleasant place to dine so you will be attracted to it.Only walking and looking the small shops en beautifull houses is allready a pleasure.

Still touristy, but a little less crowded than Old Town. There are some really great shops with authentic Czech souvenirs and crafts of lesser price and higher quality that Old Town. Less bustle. Malostrenka Pivnice is HUGE and has great food, beer and service and takes up almost a whole block. You have to also go by the Kafka Museum and Cerny's statue of two men peeing. Very fun. The John Lennon wall is very close to the main drag.

a place to walk around and enjoy. Mala Strana - The Lesser Quarter is a historic part of town which is less crowded and less expensive than the other side. The main square - Malostranske namesti, is surrounded by a number of restaurants where you can have a very nice meal, and also great coffee.I got lost a few times in the streets which often turn out to be dead ends, but It was not an unpleasant experience. Somehow or other you will always turn up at the main square. if you like to walk around a city, just to get a feel of the atmosphere, without any particular sightseeing, this is a very good place to do it.

Lots to see in Mala Strana. When you walk over the Charles Bridge from Old Town, you're in Mala Strana. This neighborhood is full of small shops and smaller streets, cafes, embassies, cafes, and squares. St. Nicholas Church and the Church of Our Lady Victorious are both in this neighborhood. We especially liked Nerudova Street- it's a good little hike with lots of cool buildings and shops to admire along the way, many with the famous pictures over the doors. At the top is a cafe (something like the Golden Star?) that is perfect for watching tourists come down from the castle while sipping Pilsner and yumming down some fried cheese. :)

Wonderful, more quiet section of Prague near Charles Bridge. My family took a last minute trip to Prague in July, at the height of tourist season (we live in Munich). I booked a very clean hotel via a Czech agency, we were extremely pleased with the accomodations, the area, and the city. The people are a little more cool and quiet than other Europeans, but they are helpful. I'm going back in 2 wks with my mother and we will stay in Mala Strana District again.
